147840172.review:
What makes Rabi-Ribi so special? (Spoiler: it has less to do with the anime girls than you think)
Well, it's special enough that I bought the game TWO TIMES.

Of course, the anime style is the first thing many notice and can put some people off, but it's all because the creator, GemaYue, genuinely loves bunnies. As such, this game is full of heart and passion in every inch, from gameplay to soundtrack.

If you can get past the artstyle(or if you love anime), you will find yourself with a hard game in any difficulty from normal to above. As a combination of Metroidvania and bullet hell, this one is about finding new upgrades to make your character stronger...and then losing to a boss for three hours when you realize you need to get good at dodging. This is a game about knowing when to attack and when to dodge, and as it progresses, you will need to learn how to evade the attacks if you want a chance at actually dealing damage. 

Not to worry, though! You have some useful temporary buffs you can buy from the main town after you defeat some bosses, and as you find new items, your attacks capabilities increase. You even get a dedicated item that gives you invincibility for a few moments. And there are consumables to recover health that you'll need to manage on some marathon bosses to get to their next phase with enough HP to give on a fight.

The story is okay, can be kind of confusing at moments, can be cute at others. Nothing extraordinary, really. 

The music, on the other hand... Holy moly there are absolute BANGERS here. Tracks that don't have any right to be this good in a game about bunny girls and bullets flying on the screen, and yet, you'll find a mix of cute and relaxing tunes from the starting forest to threatening boss themes and exhilarating songs that will give you enough confidence to try again just one more time and see if you can defeat that one obstacle that you've been wanting to clear for the past few hours.

Much of this review has been about the bosses and their difficulty, but that's not to say the platforming is bad. It's standard platforming, but there are some genuinely difficult challenges here and there, and even more with the free Halloween DLC and the Order DLC. If you buy this on Steam, there are even custom maps that will teach you useful techniques to break the game and conquer some of the hardest custom made challenges!

Btw, did I say break the game? Yeah, so Rabi-Ribi is proudly a Metroidvania where you can beat the game with 0% items (there's even an achievement for this). A game where you can wall-jump without the item needed to wall jump. A game where you can use a slide attack to gain height without double jump and so on. There are so many little things about the controls here that make it an incredibly satisfying game to master. Good luck on those achievements, though, the highest difficulties really need you to master everything about this game, from platforming to combat. 

So, what makes Rabi-Ribi special? That it's clearly a game made out of love for games, with so many small details in its gameplay department, challenging bosses with enough leeway to give everyone a fair chance if they want to face them with or without buffs, the possibility to complete the game without collecting any item and it being an actually doable challenge encouraged by the game, an amazing soundtrack and ultimately the feeling of conquering the trials (and bullets) and seeing the credits roll after getting your a** handed to you by every boss.

Don't let the anime style draw you away. This one is special, and very much so. A game that has truly stood the test of time after 7 years, and hopefully will do so for much more.

(Also play Tevi, which is the spiritual sequel to this, there's even a demo)

147741581.review:
I'm always impressed by games that blend two uncommon genres together to make something different. Rabi Ribi takes both metroidvanias and shoot'em ups. I'm a big fan of the former, just "sight" about the latter. The end result is mostly great, but the game does inherit a lot of both genre's most notorious flaws.

OK, its a game I recommend for sure, but lets start with the bad first because I'm an asshole. Boss design is... Not great. The flaws it inherit from the metroidvania side of things: bosses have invincibility phases; design usually ignores your mobility options and devolves to what I call the "skip rope then mash button" type of fights; and tons of bosses have "quirky" hidden mechanics that you'll only ever discover if you look up a walkthrough. From the shoot'em up side: it has bullets that blend with the background; regularly throws pattern shots and targeted shots at the same time, creating some real checkmate situations; an overreliance of both memorization and extremely precise inputs required.

Still, despite being one of the game's flaws, its not even close to the worst the genre have ever seen. You even get to enjoy them if you're right at the middle of a Venn diagram of "Ikaruga's diehard fans" and "metroidvania enjoyers". But for anyone else, for the most part you're just stacking attack buffs and saving resources to dump them all on the bosses before they get to do too much damage on you. Funnily enough, you'll even get some SSS and Max ranks doing this. My worst ratings in the game were the ones I tried to engage with the bosses on the game's terms actually.

Anyway, the second thing the game does poorly is story. I'd honestly recommend just skipping everything and enjoying the game for the gameplay quality only. The plot is a fever dream of multiverses that never explains itself and by the end even seems to actively mock you. Like, there's 3 "final" bosses in the game. The first two have understandable motivations and seem to raise interesting questions about the truth of Rabi Ribi world. You would expect the last one to be the sort of "mastermind" one that'll explain why and how everything happens and... Well it does. It felt like I was just served the dog ending from Silent Hill 2 with a straight face.

Despite these two major gripes I have with the game, it really is a good metroidvania when it comes to mobility, progression, level design, and regular combat. The difficulty is really hyped up in this game, but it's honestly just your average metroidvania curve. Starts off incredibly hard, gets progressively easier as you get more and more abilities and items. The last minutes of the game are pure kaizo design nonsense, but road until there is good enough that it doesn't really ruin the experience. Soundtrack is good, artistic design good, overall gameplay is good. Rabi Ribi is a good game. It's only ever "great" if you're an huge shoot'em up fan with a soft spot for chibi animal girls though.

And for posterity, don't make boss respawning a default feature. Makes post game exploration demotivating...

146805440.review:
If the game had ended after chapter 6, I would've easily recommended it. The ending there is decent, the final boss is challenging but fair, and the game up until that point was super fun, albeit perhaps a bit too big. Chapter 7 is fine, but the massive boss rush is very, very hard on the wrists. 

The issue comes in Chapter 8. There's a boss fight, I'm guessing the final boss fight of that chapter, that is such a massive difficulty spike after a fairly reasonable difficulty curve for the rest of the game that it honestly soured me on the entire game. I'd been pretty thorough with item collection so I was decently powered and still could only get through about a quarter of the boss's health before dying. She does so damn much damage compared to everything that comes before, takes far less damage, and has incredibly obnoxious status effects.

The issue is that the game suddenly went from demanding skill to demanding perfection. There's little to no room for error in the fight, which given how long it would take to kill her makes it a miserable experience. And this is on novice difficulty, the second lowest. I can only assume the higher difficulties are even worse.

If you're going to play the game, play through the first ending at chapter 6 and then just stop. There's some okay content in chapter 7, but stop at the first ending and be satisfied.

145167446.review:
I really, really, really wanted to like this game. I've attempted to play and enjoy it three separate times, this last one being my longest. Despite the clear amount of love, effort, and attention that have gone into this game, I found the world to be bland and confusing to navigate, the 'story' to be so nonsensical I couldn't follow it even when I wanted to, and the area to area combat mostly monotonous and repetitive. The one element that stands out in this game is the boss fights, which are basically just Touhou bosses you fight with a character bound by gravity instead of one that can float--though in some sections they do just straight up turn you into a floating Touhou character and do the homage point blank.

The bosses in this game are genuinely fun, though most or all of them suffer from 'learniness' in their attacks and patterns, which could easily be solved with clearer telegraphs of some kind. The characters seem interesting and have unique attacks, but something about the art-style, dialogue, and meaningless character interaction made them all sort of blur together. A world full of anthropomorphic magic girls seems like a premise sure to invite delight, but by the end of my experience I was just annoyed with everyone in the world and wanted them to stop talking and teleport me to the next boss fight.

An additional shame is that this game has a ton of extra content, like free DLC, post-game fights, and some paid DLC which seems quite robust in terms of playtime. The problem is that I can't see wanting to replay this game in any capacity, let alone to elongate my experience with something other than just a boss rush. I've put 20 hours into this game and still haven't finished a single playthru, and at this point I probably won't, because I don't think one tiny piece of good gameplay makes up for the slog that is everything else. I don't think I'd enjoy replaying the story no matter whether I was doing a speedrun or low% run or whatever, and doing any of these bosses hitless seems a lot more like a chore and excuse for padding out playtime than an actually enjoyable experience.

Despite everything, I would still recommend you check out this game if you think the aesthetic is cool or you want to try the boss fights. Chances are you'll have a much higher tolerance for the nonsensical banter that is the game's excuse for a plot. But if you need a higher standard in your narrative, and want something fun to do from place to place instead of bombing random floors and walls for pointless upgrades, try a different metroidvania.

144968767.review:
What a weird world we live in, where the best metroidvania game is a bullet hell with a bunny girl, and a supporting cast of questionably aged characters with perhaps more questionable costumes. 

If you're here for the art style, what you see is what you get. Cute chibi pixel sprites for most of the game. Portraits of cute girls in cutscenes and dialogue. Occasionally CG of a little bit more (no actual ero though). If you're here for the gameplay, you're in the right place. Because Rabi Ribi feels absolutely amazing to play.


Movement in Rabi Ribi feels basic at first. Your character snaps directions instantly giving you full control and you get the typical items as you explore that make progression faster: dash, wall-jump, etc. But you'll quickly come to discover that Erina (our bunny girl) has tons of techniques available right from the beginning that the game never tells you about. You can wall jump without the item with precise timing, you can springboard off walls for some insane sequence breaks (the game is beatable with 0% item completion). Most fun, you can quick-fall from the apex of your jump for a burst of movement forwards and down. It's so fun to loop and honestly the only thing I could compare it to is a Melee wavedash. Movement tech with items consumes stamina, which regenerates when not being used. This might seem limiting at first, but you have such a variety of ways to zip around the map that finding fast stamina neutral movement is honestly so fun in and of itself.

Metroidvanias, and to a larger extent all non-linear games, have the issue of managing difficulty with player progression. Rabi-Ribi allows you to tackle its massive roster of ~25 unique bosses (which in a very cute themeing choice are all townspeople you can recruit upon beating them) in almost any order, with bosses having a certain level based on your story and item progression when you meet them. What makes this especially ingenious is that higher levels does not just mean more health and damage, but also unlocks new patterns that become progressively more difficult to dodge, sometimes requiring movement tech specific to a certain item. While the player is expected to do the bosses closer to town first, you can technically travel around the map completely freely and still have a difficulty curve that feels completely natural. Overworld travelling is a lot more about navigating around spikes and platforms instead of fighting enemies, so mobs on the overworld don't play into this difficulty curve too much.


Combat in Rabi Ribi is one of the most enthralling video game experiences. It pulls the bullet hell trick, where your character's hurtbox is tiny, making you feel like a god as you weave back and forth between thousands of bright lights and beams that go clean through your character's legs. But by adding gravity and changing the plane on which the game is played, the challenges increase, and you feel so much more skilled than any typical bullet hell. Ribbon, Erina's fairy friend, gives you a ranged attack that can (and should) be charged at all times, and released completely independently of Erina's actions. This always gives you something to manage, and lends to a bit of a more typical bullet hell experience, taking potshots while you sit back at a distance so you have more time to react to the enemy's light show. But the real star here is when you close in for big melee damage with Erina. Erina's hammer has an auto combo which can be mashed for decent damage, but the real fun is that most of your skills can be cancelled into one another. Provided you have the stamina for it, and with some help from Ribbon, bosses can be kept in hitstun for quite lengthy periods of time, effectively turning every one of your openings into a fighting game freestyle combo. 

I can't stress enough how freestyle the combat is for this kind of game. It seems like every main item you pick up has uses, not only for exploration, not only for movement, but also has 5 different uses within a fight, either on offense to extend your attack or on defense to help you dodge. Rabi Ribi's items really are some of the most exciting pick ups I can think of across all the metroidvanias I've played. The shining jewel of these items, the standout for multifaceted item usage, and probably my favourite video game item ever is the Bunny Amulet. 

Erina's Bunny Amulet is a pretty early item that has multiple charges and gives brief invincibility when used. It's immediate value to the player is when you reach an "oh sh*t" moment, where you've positioned yourself poorly in a fight or you are met with a new attack that you have no clue how to dodge. It can also be used in the overworld to cheese some otherwise difficult platforming sections. This puts the item in the unique position where it is not ever necessary, but is probably the most valuable item in the game as it lowers the execution demands from the player considerably for any fight, by allowing them to make more mistakes. As you become more familiar with game mechanics though, you'll notice the amulet releases a wave that stuns enemies for a very short duration when used, which can give you an opportunity to attack if you've already closed in considerably on the enemy. The coolest feature of the Bunny Amulet though, is that it resets your stamina bar if not empty, giving you more juice to combo the boss with. Every charge of the Amulet is so interesting since you have to decide whether to save it for a defensive use or spend it to squeeze out some more damage while you can. On top of this your combos on bosses need to be carefully managed to not fully deplete your stamina bar (which doesn't allow for the reset), but you can't rely on having the same amount of stamina every time since you don't know how much you'll need to spend to close the distance between you and the opponent. 

The amount of active, on-the-fly decisions you make, even subconsciously, during combat in this game is wild to me, all while dodging a barrage of bullets at lightning speed. This erratic combat during boss fights is what makes Rabi Ribi truly such an incredible game, and I don't think there's another single player game out there that replicates this. 


Rabi Ribi's story is worse than the average good game, but better than the average good anime game. There are exactly two (2) characters who's personality would take more than one sentence to describe. The girls are all very likeable, and there's a little bit of an emotional arc near the ending and in the post-game and DLC, but I won't pretend like the game's saying something profound here.

The music is mostly forgettable, but perfectly pleasant. [i]Speicher Galerie[/i] is the only track I'd say really sticks out, with its heavy, somber piano chords that are atypical to the bubbly electronic tone of the rest of the game. It makes for a perfect ambiance in the area leading up to the end of the game, and the last and best fight.


I hope I've managed to explain a little bit about what makes Rabi Ribi so special to me. I played this game for the first time 7 years ago, played it most recently 3 years ago, and it still lives in my head. I've never met anyone else who has played it, so I finally took the Steam comments after so long to gush about it for way too many words. If you're not weirded out by the artstyle (and especially if you're a weeb who enjoys it), I implore you to explore what I think are some of the greatest battles video games have to offer.

Really fun metroidvania with good exploration and a ton of challenging boss fights. 
Combat is satisfying and the game's combo and ranking system heavily rewards you for playing well. 
There's a lot of freedom in exploration once you're past the prologue, with many achievements pushing you to experiment with how you progress through the game. It's even possible to complete the entire game without picking up any items!

Overall, I feel like a lot of passion went into making this game and I'm excited to play anything GemaYue makes in the future!

141731748.review:
I played this game back around the time it came out and decided to pick it up again since it's been a while and I've been wanting to replay it. This is literally one of the best games in the Metroidvania genre and is a prime example of "don't judge a book by it's cover". I know the cutesy anime style art style might turn on lot of people off [I like it personally] and you're really doing yourself a disservice if you don't open your mind and give this a try! It has some of the most enjoyable gameplay and boss fights I've ever experienced in a Metroidvania game, and I stand by it being one of the best Metroidvanias to exist in recent history.

I first played Rabi-Ribi back in 2016 I saw cute bunny girls and great electronic music (I had already heard 3R2 in some rythm games I'd played so the soundtrack really was a treat, triodust is equally as brilliant) and thought "yep, that's for me".

However,
I was terrible and inexperienced with the genre so it was a BIG learning curve for me
Safe to say, I came back to it and love the game so much more now!

But, if you go in aware that every difficulty presented to you is basically "normal is hard, hard is extra hard" and so on, you'll be fine. 

The game contains SO MANY SECRETS 
So if that's your thing then you'll love this!
It however isn't necessary, depending on what mode you decide to play on, to collect everything.
But it will give you an edge if you do decide to go the extra mile. 

Like any metroidvania, you get more abilities/ attacks and the combat system becomes more fleshed out and fun to use as you do so. 

At the time of writing this review, I'm on the final main storyline boss and I'm well aware there's so much more content for me to uncover, both boss fights and secrets like badges or upgrades. 

If you like metroidvania games, or just think this looks cute and has funky music like I did, I highly recommend this game as it only gets more rewarding the more you play.

137241228.review:
In a few words, the eastern version of Hollow Knight.

A colorful, bright platform that rather than plays with the darker, morbid themes of Dark Souls (Hollow Knight), this touches the Shmup genre specifically Touhou. There's a lot of strong throwbacks to many other parts of culture but it brings together a Touhou game (a shmup that's light in story but very strong music) to the usual platformer game in a cutesy way. I highly recommend it to anyone interested in either genre and it answers both well but also adds a few new twists of its own.

134152070.review:
Don't let the cuteness of this game fool you, this game is really challenge to beat. At first glance you may think this is simply a yuri game with some metroidvania and bullet hell elements, but let me say, this is by far the best metroidvania I ever played. The story is there just to connect the stuff happening, nothing spectacular, but it's something fun and cute, but what this game really shines is on the gameplay: is so much fun.
All the main elements of a metroidvania game is there, you often have to go back to previous areas after getting a new move to try and reach different areas you couldn't before, exploring will also reward with itens (if you find them!) that increase your HP, MP, attack and other stats. The bullet hell side of the game is part of the attack patterns of every enemy and boss, some are simple and easy, while others will remind you a lot of Touhou with a lot of stuff happening on the screen.
With different difficulty levels, you can pick the one that fits you better, and if you really want a challenge and suffering, you can pick the Bunny Extnction once you unlock.
The graphics are simple but really well done, it's a very cute 2D pixel game with a pretty art style.
The map is huge and there's a lot of places to explore and secrets to find, and it isn't linear, you can go to different routes in different order. There's a lot of different areas that have some unique elements on them and also there's so many bosses on this game and they are all fun and really hard to fight.
If you like to explore, you will have a lot of time on this game, there's also a lot of optional bosses, and after beating the main game there's more post game story, with new areas and bosses, and then after you finish this post game, it will have another one, and another one, with again new areas and new boss. The last boss of the post end game is extreme hard, probably the hardest boss I beat.
About the music, this game have one of the best soundtrack I heard in a game, it have cute and funny musics but also some epic ones, they all fit with each area of the map and with the boss battles.
And last but not least, the replay value is extreme strong here. You can replay on higher difficulties, try different routes, try to get every achievement (and there's A LOT of them), beat the post end game stories, try the DLCs, try the speed run mode (that also allows you to play a complete different character, if you have the DLC), face the boss rush modes, and probably more things that I'm missing right now.

With all this stuff together you can see how much love the devs putted on this game, I never expected a cute pixel game with bunnies to actually become my favorite metroidvania, but here we are. It was worth! This game deserves a lot more attention than it gets. Can't wait to also play Tevi when it's released, from the same devs of this game.

132794023.review:
Compared to other metroidvanias I played, I didn't feel as invested as a did with this one. Story is simple, cute and lighthearted at times but isn't afraid to push it in a scary direction, or include dialog to make you stop and think for a bit. It has a great soundtrack, downside being I've only noticed on the second go cause I was too concentrated on beating the boss and dodging tbh lol. The feeling of achievement after finally beating a boss, learning the unique patterns and fitting damage combos in between attacks is an amazing feeling. You can also beat many of the bosses with minimal items and upgrades, which can be quite satisfying too, but not necessary if you want to progress the plot. Even exploring the map and finding its many secrets is fun, many of which can be mostly accessible with the base move-set and hidden techniques. Only reason why my playtime isn't longer is cause I played on another console before for 40 hrs (I think game is up there with SotN in terms of quality)
TLDR if you're looking for a fun semi-long (~15-20hr) bullethell metriodvania, give this bunnygurl game a shot

132044029.review:
TL;DR : This is a difficult, but really well-made Metroidvania game that surprisingly doesn't go down that "lewd" angle that the "picture poses" would have you believe. If you like good Metroidvania games that give a challenge, you will probably like this game.

This game is a classically well-made metroidvania and word to the wise, it's actually quite difficult but not quite in the unfair "well that's just plain stupid way" but more in the "HOLY HECK THAT'S CRAZY, now I know how to deal that craziness I can adapt my approach" kind of way (which is the best way of doing games in this genre). 

So let's just talk about that elephant in the room: Yes those "poses" and "pictures" are rather suggestive and contrary to what you might think, the game actually doesn't go down that route and more pokes fun at the entire idea (kinda how doki doki literature club or spec ops: the line subverts the whole narrative that it seems to start with). So if you're questioning that the devs were just going for the "lewd" angle, don't worry, they aren't (though good luck trying to explain that to anyone who just happens to randomly see you playing this game with one of those pictures on screen)

If you've ever played a good metroidvania game (though it's more Metroid than Vania as there's not that whole swapping weapons RPG game-style going on and it's more of getting permanent upgrades which allow for both more traversal and more options in the moment-to-moment action). As a nice touch in this, the game will show you like two possible bosses that you can reach and fight but if you look around, you'll notice that you could probably reach and fight about five other bosses at that time, all giving a different access to other areas, abilities and extras that is honestly an awesome touch that just proves this is an amazing game. And none of this touches on the post-game stuff.

I remember seeing Rabi-Ribi a long time ago. It piqued my interest since it was a Metroidvania, and I am a huge fan of the genre. However, once I realized that I would be playing as some bunny girl fighting other cute/hot girls, I wrote the game off. How great could a game be if it's trying to attract players with an ecchi style? A few years passed, and Rabi-Ribi came up again as being recommend to me. I noticed that the game has an "Overwhelmingly Positive" rating on Steam with a LOT of people having played it. So I thought fuck it, why not try the game and see what all the fuss is about. After having played the game, I agree that this game is really good…..but I still wish it didn't have an ecchi style to the whole thing.

One of the most unique things about Rabi-Ribi is that while it's a Metroidvania, it's also basically a bullet hell. Normally, I don't like bullet hells since they're typically very "simple" and yet insanely difficult. This is because the bosses can do all sorts of crazy shit but you as the player can simply hold down the attack button while moving around slightly, praying to God you don't get hit. Rabi-Ribi is totally not like this. While the bosses can still do a bunch of crazy shit in Rabi-Ribi, the way you dodge them is not just by moving around (though quite a few attacks are dodged like that). There some attacks where you have to jump to dodge, some attacks where you have to air dash to dodge, some attacks where you have to slide to dodge, etc… You also have access to a "Bunny amulet" that can hold up to 4 charges and recharges after a while. You can use this bunny amulet to make yourself completely invulnerable for a brief period of time, which is really useful if there's an attack that you simply have no idea how to dodge (obviously, you want to use this sparingly since if you try spamming it, you'll run out of charges very quickly). I really enjoyed the fact that dodging these bullet hell type attacks was more "complex".

Not only is the defensive aspect of Rabi-Ribi more "complex" than typical bullet hells, so is the offensive aspect. This is because you're not just holding down the attack button throughout the entire fight. In Rabi-Ribi, you have 3 different forms of attacks available to you:
	• Shooting: You can press the X button to shoot bullets. You can also hold this button and release it after a while to release a charged shot. There are like 8 different weapons you can equip on the fly, and there's a homing type weapon you can equip where you can fundamentally just hold the X button and release whenever it's ready. HOWEVER, this typically does the least amount of damage, so it's much more effective if you can equip a weapon that's harder to aim (e.g. travels in a straight horizontal line), but now you have to dodge the boss's attacks AND try to line up your shots. I really like games where the defensive and offensive options are interconnected in that you have to think about the best way to dodge attacks while at the same time figuring out the best way to deal damage to the enemy (i.e. the optimal way to defend is not the optimal way to attack, and you need to balance the two)
	• Regular attacks: You can press the Y button to do a short range melee attack. Obviously, because it's a short range melee attack, you have to go up to the boss if you want to deal damage to them. The thing is, after a boss has finished using their attack, it's not too long before they move onto their next attack. So while you might be tempted to try and stay as far away from the boss as possible at all times, if you always try to do that then you might miss quite a few opportunities to deal damage to the boss. Again, this is going back to how the defensive and offensive options are interconnected, which I love. Furthermore, there's a decent amount of depth to how you want to attack a boss. You have a regular attack, rising upper, downwards attack, air dash, etc… While you might have a "standard" combo that can deal like 5% of the boss's HP in one combo, I've seen videos where players take off like 50% of the boss's HP in one combo! So the game really rewards you for mastering its systems.
	• Boost attacks: As you deal damage to enemies, there's a boost gauge that increases. You can use this boost gauge to unleash a type of "ultimate" attack that does a decent amount of damage. While you might be tempted to use it as soon as possible, there's a trade-off in that you can't shoot while the boost attack is happening. So there's a bit of planning involved in that ideally, you want to use the boost attack when the boss can't easily be shot at (e.g. in the air).

So there's a lot of depth to the defensive and offensive aspects of the game, which is great. Furthermore, the game has a great progression system and rewards you well for exploring. This is because there are a LOT of different upgrades you can find. There's stat ups, which can increase your max HP, SP/MP, S/MP regen, attack, and pack points. There's badges you can equip that provide strong passive benefits, but you need a certain amount of pack points to equip them. There's items you can get that provide all sorts of permanent passive benefits. All in all, the entire map is filled to the brim with a variety of upgrades to find, so you'll be finding upgrades like every few minutes basically.

Rabi-Ribi also has a great difficulty curve. A lot of Metroidvania's run the risk that the late game can be easier than the early game since you can get so many upgrades that you out-scale the bosses. Rabi-Ribi doesn't suffer from this problem. While I'll say that the mid-game can be easier than the early game, the late game is definitely the hardest part of the game. I was trying to go for a no healing items run, in that I tried not using any healing items ever. However, once I got to the "post" game, I had to use pretty much all my healing items for every boss I faced. I enjoy a good challenge, so I am happy the bosses kept up/outpaced how strong the players could get.

The only "flaw" with this game is that I wish it encouraged the player to get hit less. For pretty much every single boss, I was using my HP as a resource in the sense that I had no problem getting hit a few times if it meant that I was hitting the boss back. For example, if the boss was sitting in one place shooting hard to dodge bullets, I would quite often just go up to their face and start damaging them, not caring if I got hit or not. I think I would've liked the game more if taking just 1 or 2 hits is a huge deal like in Dark Souls. At it stands now, you can take like 10 hits before needing to heal. But with the bullet hell type nature of this game, that wouldn't really be feasible unless the developer severely toned back the crazy shit bosses could do (or else it would become frustrating). So this is a pretty subjective flaw.

In regards to the story, it's nothing special. You're a bunny transformed into a human being, and you have to gather a bunch of cute/hot girls (i.e. the bosses) into town so that they can help you save someone. I was really hoping that the game's story would be something like Madoka Magica in that it would totally subvert my expectations….but that doesn't really happen. The story's ok……but I wouldn't exactly recommend this game for the story.

Overall, Rabi-Ribi is a fantastic Metroidvania, better than Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night but worse than Hollow Knight. I enjoyed the time spent playing this game throughout my playthrough, as there was never a dull moment thanks to the constant boss fights and maps full of items to find.

130806654.review:
Huge fan of both metroidvania and bullet hell games, and this one takes both and melds them amazingly well. It's hard to combine what I like about the game into something cohesive, so I'll just throw out what I enjoyed about it.
+ Boss fights. There are so many attack patterns in this game with tons of variation, and while some get pretty crazy, they all feel fair and are, most importantly, fun to "solve" and get through. This was the meat of the game for me, and my favorite part of the game. Trying to squeeze in the highest damage chain you can while weaving through bullets is great fun. Combat is tight and the game gives you plenty of control, and you'll need it as you get further into the game and dive into higher difficulties.
+ Music. The BGM is fantastic with plenty of bangers. I find myself going to the OST periodically just to jam or reminisce to some tracks.
+ Non-linear exploration. After the prologue, you're more or less tossed into the wild, and while the game marks the location of bosses in case you get lost or stuck, more often than not, you'll be going through the game in a completely different order just from wandering around. The game does a good job of making you feel free and there are plenty of upgrades littered everywhere to make exploring feel rewarding.
+ The aesthetic. The game has a tone and artstyle that knows exactly what it is. It mostly doesn't take itself seriously and everything is done in good fun. It gets silly at times, but after exploring the world, experiencing the bullet patterns, and reading through the art book, you can tell the developers made a game that they wanted to make and put plenty lot of love and care into it. It's very soulful.

130465489.review:
Just like many who played this game, I had no expectations other than "cute bunny girl, I'm sold" when I bought the game. I played it a little, very little, didn't see anything too absurd about it, then didn't touch it for a few years (even because my laptop at the time died and the replacement couldn't handle games whatsoever). When I finally got to have a device that could run Steam games again, I decided to check through my library and saw Rabi-Ribi again. I went "why not" and tried it. That time, I stuck with it. It didn't take much longer for me to actually get to the meat of the game.
Good God was I impressed positively. I'll give you a TL;DR immediately: to me, Rabi-Ribi is one of the best games I've played of all times, stat. Am I exaggerating? Possibly. However, that's how impressed it left me.

Is it rather ecchi? Yep. Is it hard? Some fights took me so goddamn long, some I've had to retort to third-party tools to get through the first time around (and some end-game content, or DLC content, is so tough I've never beat it fair yet, despite how much I've tried and strived already, but I'm far from very good at this type of games). With all that in mind, you know what makes me LOVE this desperately even when so tough? It's a game made with love. You can see the passion of everyone that worked on it, from the art, to the gameplay, to the worldbuilding, to the story, to the music.
It's funny that a game that made me go "Haha, that's Reisen from Touhou" ended up taking a place almost as big as Touhou with the incredible story and worldbuilding when being such a small project compared to many other games.

I'm certainly one to enjoy the cutesy artstyle and the kind of story it tells truly appeals to me, but I wholeheartedly think there'd be something for everyone in Rabi-Ribi. Unfortunately, it's rather challenging at times, so much so I doubt everyone could complete it with ease. Nevertheless, it's worth a shot because this is truly a hidden gem. Everything is so carefully crafted that it's bound to tug at your heartstrings.

The quality of every part of the game is superb. It's not some triple A game that redefines the gaming world, nor does it want to be. They made the absolute best they could with this without going overboard; and within their limits, they made something unique and that can definitely "redefine" indie games. There are a few titles that truly manage to make you feel incredibly satisfied with your time with them and Rabi-Ribi is one of those. It being a relatively small game (in terms of the production scale) is one of its strengths, because it uses what it can to the fullest and makes perfect use of the medium.

The story is what shocked me the most. The game might've looked childish at first glance, but I've played Klonoa on PS1 back in the day so I knew well not to judge a book from its cover; but to say I was stunned by where things went would be an understatement. Again, it's not something revolutionary, but the way everything was crafted is so exquisite, so well thought... it truly stole my heart. It even was rather mature in the way things unfolded in places. Yes, there's comedy, there's fluff, but it knows when to hit hard, too, and doesn't shy away from it.

The gameplay is also incredibly fun and addictive. I always find myself craving to replay some of Rabi-Ribi's bossfights. As I said, I'm far from good at bullet hell games, despite my love for Touhou (and Rabi-Ribi, of course), so I am suck against some of the bosses; but there are a few that truly entertain me to no end. When things remain simple, chaining attacks, learning patterns, and exploiting some of the more complex tricks feels so exciting to pull off, though watching more expert players challenge the toughest bosses on the hardest difficulties is insanely great, making you wish to eventually get to that point.
There are definitely some parts I think went too hard and some bits that require you to truly master the game to get through without struggling too much (especially on a first playthrough), but the more insane bits are either extremely late into the story, or in the DLCs.

I wish I could give a better review and go into details as to why I liked something or didn't, but this is what I'm capable of writing down. All in all, I recommend this game to anybody. If someone's skeptical and not sure they like the genres the game dabbles in, they can wait for a discount and get the base game then, play and then decide if they like it and wanna invest in DLCs or not. They cut the price off fairly often, and it turns very cheap, so I'd keep an eye on it. Worst case scenario, you tried at the very least! But I assure you that if you can put up with the game and see what it's to offer, you'll understand why it's such a precious treasure.

What a surprise this was!

The game is a high quality but very standard metroidvania, ticks all the boxes:
Exploration focus, interconnected world, collectables, skills to progress to new areas, the usual.

The main difference is the bossfight design:
Rabi-Ribi bossfights are bullethell in a platformer, quite challenging and frustrating at some points.
But after persevering, it is very satisfying to overcome this challenge.
Make sure to watch a video or two before buying.

Other things to note:
Personally I like the characters designs, but it may very well be a turnoff at first glance for some people.
Graphics are great for this style.
The music is outstanding.
The story and events are mostly nonsensical and cute.
Flexible badge and upgrade system.

I have gripes with two things:
The minor one is that the map is broken into pieces and we are unable to see this world in one big picture.
The major one is the endgame platforming sections, both in the postgame and in the DLC, these are infuriating, and feel very out of place, luckily you can bruteforce them...

Review was written after Post-game and DLC chapters 9&10 completion on normal difficulty.

127709015.review:
Best metroidvania ever (in my opinion), best combination of exploring, fighting and replayability, and all of them are very well done, if you don't like the character images when talking, there is a mod in the workshop to remove them, and the outfit of the protagonist and the fairy can be changed (and there are mods that also change them).

All the bossfights feel unique and fun, as all the bosses have different and thematic attacks that you have to dodge to be able to attack them (the bossfights are bullet hell, meaning that dodging is the primary objective). For example, one boss is a girl (Cocoa) who makes bombs (and wastes all her money doing so, so she lives in the streets and ask another character (Rumi) for food), so most of her attacks are her gadgets homing into you, shooting projectiles or throwing a bunch of bombs into the ground that you have to time your jumps to their explosions, while she's in a corner taking cover. While another (Aruraune) will summon vines from below you while you try to dodge other attacks. To compensate this, you have a lot of tools that you find around exploring, every bit of exploring you do feels rewarding, as most of the upgrades you find are very impactful (double jump, wall jump, slide, slideattack, bombs, MEGA bombs, extra types of magic that all of them have different properties and special attacks, flying attack, badges that you can equip up to a maximum to personalize your build, etc).

The game has very good music for all the bosses, that adapt to the fight (start slow and gets faster as the intensity of the fight increases)

The difficulty of the game increases as you get more used to the tools you have, at the start you might just chain some hammer strikes, then later you will learn that Erina (the bunny) and Ribbon (the fairy) operate completely independent from one another, so they can attack at the same time (example, Ribbon can shoot and charge her magic while Erina is hitting the boss, making sure that some magic attacks will hit). Then you will fit in the extra tools you found, like start your combo with the Bunny Strike (slide in + hammer to make Erina jump with the hammer to deal massive damage), mixing in moves that will make the boss go up to continue into aerial combos. By the end of the game, you will do complex combos to maximize the damage you do to the boss in the windows you have to retaliate, using the amulet you have (makes you invulnerable and deals damage to all enemies, has charges and long cooldown) to reset your combo and continue pummeling the boss.

You have a lot of options to where to go, unlike others metroidvanias often cheat (where they lock you out of a major part of the game until you get one specific upgrade in a very linear style), you actually can go to almost anywhere on the map if you find the way, most areas have multiple entrances, so you can actually choose what bosses to fight first (as completing the game requires a fraction of all the bosses, but the postgame boss requires that you defeat all bosses). You can even complete the whole game and postgame without any upgrade or item, it even gives you multiple achievements (beating the game and beating the postgame with 0% items collected).

As difficulty goes, you have multiple difficulties you choose at the start which affects the difficulty scaling of the enemies (damage and health) and various properties of your tools (you can carry more healing items for example), but most importantly modifies the speed and attack patterns of the bosses (most attack get faster and have more complex patterns to dodge).

For last, replayability, you can play the game the normal way, as any metroidvania, complete it with no items, which is very hard even in casual difficulty (the game even classifies it as LOW ITEM% difficulty, with + for each difficulty above casual) where you have to learn the patterns of all the bosses because no items even means no hammer, only Ribbon can attack, you can play new game+ which increases the strength of the enemies and lets you collect even more items, you can increase the difficulty and make the bossfights a lot funnier and harder. You have bossrush to fight all the bosses in one go, and you can play with Cocoa through the whole game and bossrush (you need the Digital Artbook dlc), and she has different movement capabilities and attacks, as she prefers staying away from the enemies while using her magic infused special bombs, which she carries an amount of each type and creates more as the fights go on (one even makes a safefield where you cannot take damage for a while, another is a fking nuclear warhead that actually will let you at 1 hp), and likes verticality more (she can do some crazy skips with her pogo). You can even speedrun this game in speedrun mode, because the game is incredible speedrun-friendly (instant resets, skips everything with a button or auto-skips them in speedrun-mode).

All in all, this is a hidden gem. Thanks for reading my TED-talk

All in all a fun game!
In all honesty, when I first started the game, I was more confused than anything else.
I mean, I was a bunny girl for absolutely no real reason!
Then as the game goes on, you get to see the truth about everything.
The controls are a little confusing at first, but they are easy to adapt to and easy to use.
Be sure to connect a controller, or you might fumble a few times!
The boss battles are the main highlight of the game (Besides charming characters), and they live up to the name of "Boss Battle".
Each battle basically has you on your toes the entire time, until you learn how to fight back!
The game can also be played in two different modes, with one progressing based on the amount of items you get (Standard) and the other progressing based on your story progress (Alternative).
I tried Standard first, and then kept going after that!
Long story short, the game lives up to its title as a bullet hell metroidvania, and manages to charm you with its colorful cast of characters.
Highly recommended!

124136846.review:
A close friend of mine recommended this to me when we were in middle school, about six years ago now.
I looked at him like he was insane. I basically said, "yeah, nah, that's a little too on the nose for me, man. It's a game with a scantily clad bunny girl as the player character." (That doesn't bother me so much now, as I have since become a weeb. But if it does bother you, you can change her outfit to a normal dress in-game.)
I'm not sure why I didn't take his word for it, because he never steered me wrong and he still hasn't to this very day.
This game is amazing. The variety of environments, abilities, items, characters, and especially music are really special. Combat is challenging and rewarding. Boss fights are varied and unique. They're all bullet hell kind of fights, but the patterns and types of projectiles vary greatly throughout the game. The characters are all silly and/or lovable, which is very important for a game with this kind of aesthetic, I suppose. Every single environment is beautiful and well-designed. The game rewards you well for backtracking and using new abilities (we don't have the Metroid problem of "oh great, yet another missile expansion..." because there are lots of different types of upgrades). I could keep going, but in short, everything about this just feels right. I have to say, I am surprised. I was expecting a good game, but I got an excellent game.
I've played quite a few Metroidvanias now, and this one is close to the top of the list. I still haven't finished it. I probably will soon. Even then, the clear replay value here means that I won't ever really have to stop playing it if I don't want to. 
Do yourself a favor and play this game, even if the aesthetic turns you off. It's just really fun.

Genuinely one of the best metroidvanias I've ever had the pleasure to play. The combo mechanics are an incredibly deep addition and make styling on bosses fun and engaging at all times. 118936779.review:
So here's the thing. Nobody goes to Hooters for the hot wings. And this game wears its, ahem, fanservice on its sleeves. But listen to me. I'm a gay man. It's not just that I think the idea of skimpily-clad teenage girls is in questionable taste, it's that it doesn't appeal to me at all. There are not enough Y chromosomes in this game to hold my interest. All that's left in Rabi-Ribi for me are the bullet hell bosses, the metroidvania exploration, and (I can't believe I'm about to write this) the story. And, I swear on me mum, these are some damn good hotwings.

The bosses are incredible. Most bullet hells give you five-ish boss fights you're supposed to grind until you have them memorized backwards and forwards and can execute them perfectly. Rabi-Ribi has dozens. Like, literally 50+. And every single one of them is bursting with creative patterns, unique theming, and inventive mechanics that require as much puzzle-solving as lightning-fast reflexes. The first phase of the final boss is a great example. Some of her bullets can damage you only when you're on the ground, some can only damage you when you're jumping, and they overlap in ways that force you to jump constantly. You have to frantically plan ahead to dodge when you're not going to be hit by the bullets that turn on the moment your feet leave the ground. That's an especially strong example, but every fight has something that creative going on.

The metroidvania exploration is also a joy. The map is set up so that you go to each area in the game multiple times, and each time you can explore a little bit further. But more than that, you can also do a little bit of sequence-breaking. You simply take a wrong turn on purpose, follow it the end, already have what you need to get past all the obstacles, and bam! You straight-up run into bosses and advance parts of the story a little earlier than the standard route, and the story has alternate dialog to account for it. Just as frequently, you'll run into an obstacle you can't get past yet. But when this happens, the game gives you plenty of tasty permanent upgrades for your trouble. And then when the game sends you back, you'll breeze through the parts you've already seen only to get your teeth kicked in the moment you get to the new content. It's glorious. It's so meticulously planned, even with all the freedom you're given to go off the beaten path.

And the story is actually pretty neat! It's definitely an excuse for anime girl fanservice, I won't pretend it's anything more than that. But what I honestly appreciate about it is that the vast majority of conflict comes from genuine, good-faith misunderstandings between well-meaning characters. Most stories have severe conflict that comes from dangerously evil demagogues who are willfully cruel or from deeply flawed main characters who struggle not to let their worst sides get the better of them. Rabi-Ribi doesn't bother with all that. It's just a bunch of girls who sometimes talk past each other, but when they get it out of their systems and calm down, they all just... discuss their problems. Like reasonable people. Again, it's not deep or philosophically compelling or of any serious literary merit. But gosh darn it, there's something refreshing about it all.

There's no getting around it, the amount of fanservice in this game is pretty tasteless. And the fact that the characters aren't clearly at least 18 years old makes it decidedly problematic. But even so, there's an actually brilliant bullet hell married to a joyfully explorable metroidvania to be played. And the story's willingness to be nothing more than an excuse for anime girls gives it a sincere happiness that can't help but make me smile. Take it from someone too gay to be impressed by the moe lolis: You really, honestly, actually can get this for the gameplay.

118782825.review:
This one is tough, enjoyable, and cute all in the same package, but it's also not a good metroidvania for beginners; expect this one to kick your butt.  The main challenge is all the bullet hell mechanics, though fortunately, you also get the appropriate tiny hitbox as well.  The game can be tough, but it's also fair minus a couple complaints, mainly the lack of an option to add your own map markers for pickups you may need to return to and a couple segments where falling through the floor will send you to a one-way fall very far away without warning (not a glitch); the latter can be mitigated by that oh-so-handy autosave slot.  

If you want a challenge and are okay with lots of flashing lights bent on killing you, this game is a good one.

[b]This game is an absolute banger.[/b]
It's absurd how fun this game gets. Somehow the game gets even more fun every playthrough and the more you learn little tricks and tips. The highs of this game is REALLY high, but it doesn't come with no lows of course. It's just that the high points of this game are so high you keep on forgetting the flaws. 

[u]Pros:[/u]
- Bossfights are GODLIKE. Definitely amongst some of the most fun bossfights I've ever had in videogames.
-- > They're both unfair and fair at the same time, but they're 100% fun through and through.
-- > Very rarely do I think "How did I not dodge that, that's unfair!" It happens but really rarely.
--- > (Though there are times where I think "How do i even dodge this at the first place...")
- Banger musics. [spoiler]Look up Mischievous Masquerade.[/spoiler]
- Movements feels really solid and fast
- Exploring feels nice. I could get lost for 20 minutes and not realize I got lost. And still had fun.
- Some secrets are super rewarding to discover yourself.
- The amount of variety a run can have from others is amazing. They put a whole lot of thought to give secret access for people who lack certain upgrades.
- Cute anime girls lol

[u]Cons:[/u] (Almost all are nitpicks but still)
- Number 1 complaint is lack of information.... for... everything.
- > Ribbon's magic types are not so well described, in particular the BOOST. It's not described anywhere on what each different magic boosts do despite them being really impactful. 
- > eg: [spoiler] Nobody ever told me hammer roll makes you invul to spikes ? ? ? [/spoiler] 
- > Moves/Items has little descriptions about the damage they do etc.
-- > Sure you have sandbags, but the sandbag in Starting Forest is sorta forgettable (and should've been in town tbh, it's not really near any teleport sites) and the sandbag in [spoiler]Plurkwood[/spoiler] doesn't record damage number. It's hard to tell whether the new skill you get is even worth remembering.
- Status Effect icons are REALLY nondescriptive. Even the name is a bit weird sometimes. [spoiler] Like Frozen and Cursed may not do things you first expected them to do [/spoiler] 
- NPCs are a pain to talk to when they're clumped up.
- Town is so big and useless. Town members could be stationed on certain buildings but instead they roam randomly and you gotta check the entire town to find the 1 NPC you want to check on, only for you to misremember which buffs they even give at the first place.
-- > [spoiler] Also why don't Syaro just offer us the Strange Box right after we beat her?? I've seen very plenty people not knowing about Strange Box cause they don't care about buffs and assumes Syaro also gives buffs. [/spoiler] 
- Map could be way better. Lots of details could be added. 
-- > Having some kind of map note / pin system would be very helpful as well. There are very often times where I see an unreachable item and think "Oh I'll get that later once I have the upgrade for it" and did not remember about where it is anymore afterwards.
- Getting healing is a bit weird, especially how pricey a healing item is. Feels like you're discouraged to buy it, and yet they're key items to have in every fight for most casual players that doesn't like to suffer as much.
- Some bullet gimmicks are extremely unintuitive. In particular, [spoiler] the "shoot the bullets back with blue/red" kind of patterns and Pandora's "jump to disable bullet" gimmick. [/spoiler]  [spoiler] Rumi makes it obvious since that's her entire gimmick, but Pandora's was really not that obvious at all. [/spoiler] 
- And finally...... some of these platforming sections are pretty absurd on your first time play.............

Yes I wrote a lot more about cons than pros but honestly most of these are nitpicks. Everytime the game gives one bad point, it makes up for it with 10 other good points. Overall extremely super fun fun game.
If you're still unsure, at least pick it up on discount then. Absolutely worthed.

116288641.review: Ok, mom, firstly, you need to understand that this isn't porn, all right? It's called "hentai". Yes, that's a Japanese phrase, I'm learning Japanese from these videos. Before I get to the part about learning Japanese, though, let me first comment on the cultural implications of hentai. After the second world war, which Japan lost after the nuclear bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the entire country underwent a period of self-reflection and soul-searching. They wanted to understand how events led to the rest of the world responding with such devastating atomic attacks. This led to a strong antipathy towards war-mongering and international aggression. You may have heard about how the Japanese constitution doesn't allow the country to have an active military. Same idea. A lot of post-war Japanese culture is a reflection of such attitudes. For example, the Godzilla movies are not just about giant monsters fighting each other. They're about the horrors of unbridled atomic technology (Godzilla's always depicted as being powered by or healed by nuclear power), and how such a terrifying force can never be allowed to be unleashed on humanity again. On a similar note, Japanese animation enjoyed a resurgence of popularity after the war, due to the populace choosing to turn towards the comforting images of their youth. Japanese kids, much like kids in our country, like to watch cartoons. As a result, psychologically speaking, cartoons represent a reminder of a simpler and more innocent age. This upsurge in popularity resulted in animated images pervading almost all of Japanese culture: from movies, to television, to advertising, to music videos, and so on and so forth. And because animated images were so widely accepted throughout Japan, they were used for almost every type of source material, or to tell any type of story. Animation was no longer the sole domain of children. You got animated movies that told very mature stories, like Ghost in the Machine or Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind. Sometimes you get stories that involve very mature topics, like war, or murder, or rape, or torture. The Japanese have generally become quite accustomed seeing depictions of such things in their animations. So yeah, that's why I was watching this movie. It's an epic tale about a space crew exploring a distant planet (the crew's all female, because Japan's very into gender equality), and they run into a hostile alien, with a bunch of tentacles... and... well... I don't want to spoil the story for you, but let's just say the crew eventually figure out how to get along with the alien. It's a story about bridging cultural gaps and finding common ground. Seriously, it's worth watching. Ok, next, you remember how I talked about knowing Japanese words and phrases now? It's because these movies are subtitled in English, so I can learn Japanese while watching them. I mean, I know words like yamete, and iie, and iigu, and lots of others. Much better than just knowing konichiwa, isn't it? I mean, I'm developing such an interest in hentai that I might just major in Japanese when I'm in college. Who knows, I might be the one writing the subtitles in the future. Oh, and one last thing, you should know that hentai's considered pretty mainstream in Japan now, and it's also quite common in the western world too now. Everyone's watching it. I mean, if I don't watch it, I'll be seen as some sort of freak at school. You don't want your son to be some kind of pariah because he doesn't watch hentai, do you?

My favorite game in years. Bracing bosses belie a leisurely approach to exploration, secret-hunting, and women's literature. 

The tone here is pitch-perfect post-meta-- it doesn't particularly "mean anything" that Erina has Amy Rose's hammer or looks like a Touhou, nor do the explicit invocations of Gochiusa or Splatoon or anything else. It's a dreaming amalgam painted in the same hypermedia typically leveraged toward pure, penitent unending wakefulness, cloaking a payload of depleted unreality. As such, it attains all criteria for the highest contemporary art: more radical than difficult, and too good-natured to make a fuss about it. I could go on and on. 5/5. So looking forward to next adventure.

110982732.review:
Bunny.

This game is sweet!! Combining metroidvania gameplay with bullet heck elements might seem like a weird combination at first, but Rabi-Ribi made it work super well! (And do not worry! While this game CAN be challenging, it's not as daunting as Touhou can be!)
First off, it combines many of the former genre's strongest points: Movement is fun, exploration is very rewarding, there's lots of stuff to find... it's all here! But Rabi-Ribi goes a step further and introduces two things that are honestly not as present in other games of it's kind: 
First off, it has excellent boss battles - and lots of them - that reward both offensive and defensive strategies
And second, to my surprise, even though there IS some sort of story progression that you should follow, you can totally tackle many of the game's areas in whichever order you want, and even go to areas a bit earlier than you're meant to to grab some upgrades ahead of time - just like Super Metroid! I did not see this approach to game design in many Metroidvanias I've played, so seeing this here made me very happy and excited ^_^
On top of all this, Rabi Ribi also features an excellent soundtrack! No wonder it got an orchestral soundtrack DLC five years after its release ^_^ And while I do think the game looks a bit too simple in certain areas, it still got a very cute artstyle with vibrant colors that suits the game very well! The CG cutscenes are also drawn pretty well, though I wish some scenes had less suggestive poses in them - but don't worry, it's not nearly as bad as in Neptunia, to cite one example ._.

If I had one flaw to point out with Rabi-Ribi, it's that I personally found the story to be somewhat hard to follow. Though I do find the story itself to be pretty cute, and sometimes interesting, it's not told very well, and the English localization can be a bit shaky at times to be honest.

But at the end fo the day, Rabi-Ribi is just a ton of FUN! Along with Touhou Luna Nights, it's definitely one of my fave Metroidvanias ever <3

I don't think I can do justice to this game in words, but I'll try.

I play tons of metroidvanias. I play a little bit of everything, but that's probably the genre I play the most. This is without a doubt my favorite one.

When I first played it, it seemed like a normal metroidvania, one where you go here, you get this upgrade, that lets you go somewhere else... And that was fine, I already loved it when it was just that. Cute characters, mesmerizing music that made the levels feel like these weird, cool, mysterious and otherworldly places. It had this enchanting vibe that I can't quite explain, but I was fascinated by what may look to someone else like just a cheaply made game. Then there's the bullet hell boss fights with incredible music. A meaty postgame with a fantastic true final boss that wraps everything up perfectly...

But then I took a look at the achievement list, and it blew my mind. The things you can actually do in this game! The way you can break sequence, all the different ways you can play this game, the seemingly essential upgrades that aren't essential at all! I mastered the secret techniques and found another whole dimension to the game. I haven't played it in a long time now and I haven't done all of the things that I would like to do in this game yet, but I haven't stopped loving it for a single second. It's a game that I'll always keep in my heart and I know I'll keep revisiting it over and over again. I'm patiently looking forward to the next game in this style by this creator.

107342177.review:
Let's be honest here: The game's a hard sell on its art alone. You have really look past the obvious fanservice and lewd designs of the characters to get anything at all out of this game -- but when you do, hot diggity.

There's a sense of 'newness', of exploration, an excited feeling I get when I play games that show me things I've never seen before, or take me to places I've never been. I'm old; games like Imperishable Night or Castlevania: SOTN or Super Metroid or Tomba!/Tombi! were my bread and butter during my college years. I loved them for that feeling that I got when I was playing them, that every stage or screen or room or area I visited would show me something new, or have something new for me to discover or solve or defeat. Rabi-Ribi is one of the few Steam Metroidvanias that's managed to light that fire in me again, and I really appreciate it for it.

The world of Rabi-Ribi is open and expansive, it's built with the idea of discovery and exploration and challenge at the forefront, and it really leans on the player to fill out the space that it's carved for itself in that niche of bullet hell and Metroidvania that emerged around 2015-2016. The game has so many different ways to solve puzzles, and it even encourages you to break it -- impossible platforming, opening secret walls, using unintuitive techniques to pass obstacles, the game not only allows you to do it, it rewards you for it. The developers recognize that sequence breaking is not only possible, it's expected of its players. Heck, I accidentally sequence-broke the entire final stages of the game my very first time through because I was that curious about if I could make a seemingly impossible jump with the abilities I had. My second time through, I decided to see how far I could get without picking up a single power-up. Turns out, pretty much the whole game.

This is what they want you to do -- to explore, to think and try new things and break the game in your own unique way. For that kind of experience and encouragement, I can overlook some dicey character art.

106556769.review:
Probably the best metroidvania to ever exist.

On the surface, Rabi Ribi seems to be a metroidvania with bullet hell. Ok, plenty of 2D games do that and usually they're kinda awful, so what's so special about Rabi Ribi? Well, what sets Rabi RIbi apart is that it adopts a lot of shmup game design principles too, which complement the bullet patterns to make the game very fun.

For example, Original mode uses a scaling difficulty system (or rank in shmup terminology), so that the bosses become stronger as you become stronger. This way, you won't get completely overwhelmed even if you don't find a bunch of items. Bullet patterns tend to be aimed or static, rather than being a completely random mess, which makes it actually reasonable to learn how to dodge them. Bosses are also designed such that they use certain patterns at certain HP %. This makes the bosses more predictable, so it is easier to adapt to and learn how to beat them. There's also the tiny hitbox, which is an essential feature for any game that wants to use bullet hell patterns (although I do wish that it was always displayed).

But even if you ignore the shmup elements, Rabi RIbi is a fantastic metroidvania in terms of the mechanics and world design. The game is very non-linear, and you can progress through the game in pretty much whatever way you want. The aforementioned scaling difficulty complements this really well, so even if you go to a "late-game" area very early on, you won't encounter a difficulty spike. None of the areas are gated by items either, so you won't be forced to turn back just because you're missing an item. This makes Rabi RIbi TRULY non-linear. There are also a lot of hidden mechanics which enable the game to be so non-linear, adding a lot of technical depth to the game. It reminds me a bit of Super Metroid's hidden mechanics and movement quirks.

The combat system is also really excellent. You have a huge arsenal of attacks. Bosses can be stunned by attacking them, which allows you to set the pace of the fight, instead of forcing you to play defensively and focus on reacting to the boss. In fact, if you know how to optimise your DPS, you can beat the boss before she can even do anything. There's also a combo system that rewards you for playing better, instead of having a system that punishes you severely if you make a mistake. The combat is easily the most technical part of the game, and it's very fun to learn and master it.

There are also a bunch of difficulty options. If you want to focus on collecting items and trying different routes instead of the combat, you can play Casual and Novice. If you want to enjoy the full potential of the combat system, there is Bunny Extinction and NG+ loops. As such, ANYONE will be able to enjoy playing this game. Between the non-linear world design and the highly sophisticated combat, the game has tons of replay value, and I can see myself playing it for several hundred hours more.

There are still a lot of good things to say about Rabi Ribi. It is honestly a masterpiece that transcends the standards of metroidvanias. In fact, I doubt I'll ever see a better metroidvania in my lifetime. I know the character portraits may be a big turn off, but you'll be missing out on a lot! Plus, you'll mostly be seeing the silly and adorable pixel art sprites anyway.

Rabi Ribi is totally worth getting at full price.

103600869.review:
Let's be fair. The Art is cute, the story is actually funny, and the main character is a bunny with a hammer. Very few other titles try to make a game where the highlight could be placed on the hammer as the one and only weapon. Plus, we got the fairy companion, which is far more welcoming than most other fairy tag-along characters in other titles (this fairy is also your ranged attack option). It is a title that's quite inspired by many other IPs that also exist on Steam, if you know where to look, as well as a title that promotes real nonlinear exploration where any path taken only has "soft barriers" of traversal that you can overcome with some core mechanical knowledge. Rabi-Ribi does not require certain mastery to pull off many feats, and the difficulty is very dynamic (you can even skip on 99.9% of the power-ups, and the game is still just as beatable, just harder). That said, there are paths that show up to those that break away from the normal loop and can impress even those that replay the game once or twice more, as well as those that would love to speedrun this game to beat certain times.

Now, by the time of this review being published, my time shows as 3.9 hours, but I have played this game on the other platforms, such as the Vita and Switch, and I had my hundreds of hours clocked on those. On top of the DLC that adds even more to the game's already beefy base content, this game has plenty to enjoy, explore, and revisit every other day. The Steam workshop has other stuff you could use, too. Though, the mod support isn't as active as with other games, I wish the community here was as active. It's pretty much Metroidvania+Touhou in a good sort of way, with some aesthetics similar to 100% OJ and the like. Even the serious player should give it a try, despite what some may think of it at an uninformed glance. I, at least, would recommend buying it full price too, but there will be some times that it might be on sale. In those cases, go for the bundles!

103200290.review:
Rabi-ribi is a bullet hell Metroidvania with anime girls. 

TL;DR, I recommend this only if you REALLY like bullet hell stuff. Other than that, there's no reason to play this

Some notes:

- Played at Hard Difficulty for Base Game, then Casual for Post-Game + DLC
- Played on PS4 Controller

[h1]Good[/h1]

[b]Mostly Fun Boss Fight[/b]

Rabi Ribi at its core is a bullet hell game. While there are some small enemies here and there, it's shine with its bosses. Bosses are incredibly challenging and have so many movesets it's crazy.

[b]Support for Sequence Breaking[/b]

For people that don't know what Sequence Breaking is, it's basically where you go to an area that normally is locked until some requirement on the story is fulfilled. In this game, not only it's supported, it encourages the player to sequence break. There is some hidden technique (that you can google) that can make players go to a certain level that should've been inaccessible until either the story progresses or the player already gets a certain item. This makes exploration really fun

[b]Extensive Way of Game Mode Modifier[/b]

Aside from the sequence-breaking stuff. Rabi Ribi also has many ways for you to play that are feasible. Aside from the usual Boss Rush, You can try no melee, 0% item (not picking any item on the playthrough, even the melee attack!). There's also two types of game mode (One where bosses scale with your story progress, and one where it's not). And for the masochists' type, there's a hidden difficulty on the DLC that is harder than the most difficult DLC, that the dev said that it's not untested (Still doesn't deter players to try it though lol). Shortly, it's great for replayability.

[b]Soundtrack[/b]

The OST for this game is so damn great. I honestly can't think of any bad track. It's mostly electronic stuff but man they do it well. There's also some variation like calm music and stuff. My favorite is the last song that played on the last DLC Boss, it's just perfect.


[h1]Neutral[/h1]

[b]Character Art[/b]

Character Art is drawn in anime style, which is fine. What is not fine though is mostly the character is drawn in skimpy clothes. Nothing too major, but not comfortable when your family sees you playing this lol.

[b]Environment Art[/b]

The environment art is basic, nothing special really. Just kinda disappointed because one of the joys of playing Metroidvania is to explore the world. In Rabi Ribi though, there's no interesting landmark, really.

Bad:

[b]Story[/b]

I usually don't get annoyed on the story for this kind of game, but because the start of the game is kinda interesting, it disappoints me.[spoiler] MINOR SPOILER, STOP READING HERE IF YOU DON'T LIKE IT Thing is, it sets in a fantasy world at the start, but then gives a hint that not really, it's still connected in our reality. The problem is, it never tried to explain how that works, and when it does, it is sloppily explained. [/spoiler] Coupled with some awkward translation (It's a Taiwan game btw), it just makes it confusing to follow the story.

[b]Spammy Attack Controls[/b]

You have two ways of attacking, Melee and Ranged. And because of how the game is designed, the best way to get max DPS of your attack is to spam the living hell when you had the chance. Normally it's ok but...

[b]Long Bosses Battle[/b]

The bosses battle is long, like extremely long. And there's not much breathing room for the battle, so you're always on your edge until you can remember the bosses attack really well. Also of note that bosses are designed to have many phases that you cannot skip. So if let's say you're good for 80% of the game, but have trouble on some of the last parts, then die. There's no other way to play again the 80% part of the game again before you can start learning the last part again. Don't forget the bosses HAVE SO MANY ATTACK, so you need to do it well, No shortcut here. Coupled with the way the attack is designed (see the previous point, spammy), it's just damn exhausting.

[b]Later Game stuff Difficulty Spike[/b]

Here's where I think the game falls apart. While the start and the middle stuff is good, the Later stuff is just too much. Platforming becomes harder, Bosses become much longer, Evade window becoming more smaller. It really is just too much for me.

[h1]Is it fun?[/h1]

It's fun for most of the parts, endgame stuff though, it's just way too much for me.

[h1]Recommend?[/h1]

If you like a challenging game, then highly recommend it for you. Just note that it needs a lot of dedication to enjoy the best of what the game has to offer.

If you were attracted to the anime style only, then don't. There are better games for this.

[h1]Closing thoughts[/h1]

It's a challenging game, but don't be fooled with the art style, it's not for everyone. If you're new to bullet hell stuff, be prepared to learn much about how it works.
