102791988.review:
A must-have for bunny lovers.

Bosses' patterns are visually appealing and, together with a variety of moves available, offer different approaches, some of which require some thought put to find them (which doesn't mean you'll get past the higher difficulties using just your brain and no skills). The progression that includes acquisition and improvement of moves, allowing you to reach new places, feels quite smooth too. Cute visuals, as well as cool music, provide a enjoyable ambient throughout all the diverse zones.

Another big selling point is the all-female cast, which has plenty of lovely characters and features a bunnygirl (!!!) as the protagonist. Even though story is barely more than an excuse to show the girls interacting, it's a worthy one for sure. If you insist on skipping the dialogues, you can do so automatically by playing on "speed run" mode.

The game can be made fit your playstyle. From explorers to rushers, every type of player will find a configuration and/or self-restriction that suits them. "Casual" difficulty will welcome newcomers to the genre and people who simply don't come to test their skills, while "bunny extinction" and higher will pose the challenge expected from bullet hells. Given that there are various ways to play it, the replayability is high. Particularly, those that aim for 100% achievements are in for a long ride.

If you buy it, make sure of visiting the Evernight Peak to admire the architectural splendor of the pillars there.

102692472.review:
Rabi-Ribi is a bullet-hell metroidvania done masterfully.
The controls are extremely tight and responsive, and Erina has a wide range of movement options that help with both dodging and increasing your damage output.

As a metroidvania it does its job fine, exploration is quick and fun, the game never enforces heavy backtracking due to a teleporter system, and sequence breaks are available to reach areas early using hidden techniques which make further playthrough's a blast.

However Rabi-Ribi shines when it comes down to the boss fights. Each boss has unique patterns, and in some cases unique mechanics, I wouldn't call a single one forgettable. The bosses all scale with either your items or the story's progression, and manage to keep you at the perfect level of difficulty for the time, you should and will struggle at times, often scraping a fight by with a climactic finish once all your resources are drained. 

Post-game content is where the game just blew me away, with some of the most intense fights I've ever played. 
The SP bosses are well above the paygrade of anything that comes before them, with crazy patterns that took me many tries to get down enough to even survive to see the next phases. If you watched these fights as someone who hasn't played the game the patterns will seem impossible, but the more you play the more you'll understand how to move Erina, when to use your invincibility amulets, when to abuse super carrot iframes, when to use the quick drop for positioning and more, and when you're giving it everything you've got against a boss that requires exactly that, it's a feeling most games can't even hope to achieve.

I love this game whole-heartedly but it's not perfect.
Namely the story isn't anything special, it's not bad but it's something I just skip through now because it's just not that important to anything.

Of course there's also the reason I struggle to get anyone else into it.. The art style and fanservice will shoo some people away who would otherwise try the game, and while I don't mind it myself I do understand the distain. All I will say is that it's not a major part of the game, just skip the cutscenes if you must but play this damn game.

Buy Rabi-Ribi. <3

At first I liked a game that finally forced me to buckle up and really try a boss a bunch of times until I figured them out, or just go to a different area because a boss was too much for me, but there is a limit I can take.

I don't know why the devs think the fun part of their game is creating gigantic numbers of moves as much as possible. The earlier bosses, even the final boss of the "main game" are kinda reasonable, with a well defined moveset they cycle through and really tough bullet patterns (as this is a bullet hell game) that you gotta learn with practice.

But I just am done with this last boss, and it is after I have taken every possible item and power up and buff to prepare for them. This boss literally uses each move once, and goes through all their moves one by one. And each move is COMPLETELY different and not intuitive at all. Every time you want to figure out how to avoid a move or deal with it, you have ONE CHANCE to see it per boss attempt, and who knows in what part of the fight it is. If it's near the end, you have to repeat the last 5 minutes every time of going through the first X moves to get to that last one. It's absolutely ridiculous and really the MOST unfun artificial difficulty boss design I've ever seen in any game.

Leaving out the main part you'll be spending your time on, the bosses, other stuff that's really to dislike about the game is that the dialogue and "characters" and story are all 100% worthless. They add nothing to the game and read like really badly translated hentai dialogue. 

The visuals are generic and not very inspiring. The map design is really awful, going for the order of ecclesia kind of "individual map sub areas that are not connected properly" instead of one giant clearly visible interconnected map. And largely because of this and poor UI design, the teleport screen (and navigation in general) will infuriate you every time you have to deal with it. 

The mechanics of the game go from acceptable (double jump, shooting) to extremely clunky and unfun to use (wall jump, bomb) to downright dangerous, that screw up your movement and kill you. The air dash and wall jump notably are probably among the worst implemented in any platformer I've played.

The one big positive I can give the game is that whoever made the music did an absolutely fantastic job. That's really what got me through a lot of the game before I just quit.

100414100.review:
You ever play that shooting game about the girl with ungodly amounts of destructive power, who fights monsters with her fairy companion that doubles as a powerful weapon? No, this isn't Cotton, this isn't an STG, and you don't play as a cute witch; this is Rabi-RIbi: one of the world's two only bullet hell metroidvania bunnygirl simulators! (Bunny Must Die is the other one but Rabi Ribi doubles down on the bullet hell elements.)

Rabi-Ribi takes place in a formerly peaceful world where magicians and kemonomimi girls co-exist. However, with the appearance of the only True Bunny getting isekai'd onto the island (Erina, the player), strange things start happening; people go missing, disturbances happen across the island, and an unusual group of bunny fetishists are on the hunt for your fluffy hide! It's up to Erina to recover the town's villagers that have gone berserk due to the strange "bunny lover" phenomenon and figure out a way to get back home.

The gameplay is unique and combines action RPG metroidvania elements with those of a shooting game. You run around the map on the lookout for items to power your character up and enhance exploration while also shooting and whacking enemies that fire their own barrages of bullets at your (thankfully small) hitbox. Bosses themselves can be tackled in a nonlinear order, and have attacks structured in a way not unlike the Touhou Project's Spell Card system. It's not all just dodging and blasting, however; there is a special learning curve to the game's combat. Learning how to manage DPS on the enemy, combining melee with the right balance of constant charge attacks, and using all sorts of defensive abilities that you attain over the course of the game to avoid damage is key to getting a good grade in boss battles, giving the game a sort of character action-like feel. On top of this are the game's many badges with numerous equip-able buffs and methods of customization, allowing players to create their own builds for any given moment.

Don't expect the game to be over once you beat the apparent final boss, either; once the credits roll, the post game awaits! Even more devious challenges await in this final encounter that even I have yet to clear! After all's said and done, there's still plenty of replayability for those who want to speedrun the game. With an adjustable difficulty system, features geared for optional speedrunning, and workshop support, Rabi-Ribi has more to see beyond the initial playthrough!

Overall, the (slightly) suggestive nature of the game's character designs may turn off some people, but those who choose to don their bunnysuit and walk the path of the mallet will see the true joy in playing this unique adventure platformer!

96415370.review:
Speaking as someone who's beaten the hardest difficulty and done both 100% and 0% games, this is easily one of the greatest games I've ever played. The anime aesthetics and fanservice-y themes can be off-putting at times, and the story is kind of an excuse plot at best, but you'd still be doing yourself a massive disservice if you skip on it. Rabi-Ribi really just has everything you could want from a Metroidvania in a non-linear, bullet hell, bunny-shaped package, and its cartoonish exterior hides an incredible amount of depth and difficulty:
[*] A cheery aesthetic and a huge map to explore, which gradually opens up new areas as you get new power-ups; fast travel makes exploration easier.
[*] An in-depth and varied, yet responsive and easy to understand combat/movement system that combines melee fighting with simultaneous ranged magic, along with a huge variety of tools and secret techs to amplify your power.
[*] Tons and tons of secrets that encourage creativity and exploration.
[*] Frequent save points and healing when saving/defeating enemies makes for less punishing exploration and deaths.
[*] A wide range of difficulty settings for players of all skill levels, ranging from Casual to the gruelling Bunny Extinction. On anything Normal and below, the game will also offer assists if you're struggling.
[*] On the standard difficulty, all enemies and hazards will scale their stats depending on how far you've gotten and how many items you have, which lowers the incentive to grind and look for powerups. For those who like the grind, there's an alternative mode that fixes enemy levels based only on story progression, meaning you'll want every last item. If anything, money grinding is also generally pretty lenient from what I've found.
[*] Incredibly well designed non-linearity that not only supports sequence breaking, but outright encourages it. There's an insane amount of developer foresight in the sense that no matter what you do, how you do it, and when you do it, there's probably going to be a built-in feature that'll help you out. You can very easily beat the game on low% or even 0% item runs thanks to this, along with a variety of hidden movement techs and secrets that allow access to virtually any point of the map at any time given you know about them. Even if you aren't necessarily sequence breaking, the game is incredibly lenient with how you do things and what order you do them in, with very little railroading outside of a quest system that you don't even have to listen to most of the time.
[*] An absolute banger of a soundtrack that'll get stuck in your head forever
[*] etc.

The levels are primarily exploration-based and don't have too many significant challenges until near the end, but the meat of the game is the myriad of memorable characters and their INSANELY well-done bullet hell boss fights. Even on lower difficulties, they can be quite challenging, but they somehow remain fair even on Bunny Extinction. To elaborate:

[*] The fights are designed to last just long enough to feel like a tough, hard-fought battle without dragging out, complete with many of them starting to take increased damage if the game sees you're struggling to damage them. On the flip side, it's virtually impossible to instakill or cheese them to death, which means you'll almost always experience the full fight.
[*] Even on higher difficulties, there are virtually no one-shots and bosses don't do enough damage to make taking any hits fatal, which means that you can afford to make mistakes as long as you learn from them. The learning curve with the fights is incredibly good in the sense that you can feel tangible improvement every time you dodge an attack or even die. Dodge Master achievements are a different story, but...well, those are optional achievements. But in a nutshell, the combination of the difficulty and the very tangible learning curve just makes them some of the most enjoyable battles I've ever had in a game, period.
[*] The attack patterns wielded by the bosses are insanely creative and stunningly beautiful, while also being memorable enough that you can recognize their user just by their bullet patterns/gimmicks. They're also designed to look overwhelming at first, but every attack has multiple viable ways to dodge it (especially when factoring in your various movement tools), which makes you feel really good when you find them. And when in doubt, the game gives you multiple ways to get limited invincibility frames, which opens up a lot more ways to avoid attacks.
[*] Bosses in this game have gigantic movepools that ensure they usually won't repeat over one fight, making sure you don't get bored. The sequence of attacks they use are generally somewhat fixed (entirely fixed for some of the endgame bosses) which let you predict them, but are still random enough that you'll need to actively react to them in order to win.
[*] Virtually every attack in the game (with the possible exception of contact damage) is designed to be as fair as possible. There are no infinite crowd-control chains, few cheap shots, and serious debuffs are used sparingly. Basically, you'll almost never feel helpless, and when you die to something, you very, very rarely feel like it was out of your control. 
[*] There's a combo system that rewards you with increased damage output if you can keep the boss under pressure and keep damaging them, rewarding an active playstyle as opposed to hiding from the boss, helped by the fact that if you play in this active way, there are very few periods of idleness in the battles. Not only do you have ranged attacks for this, for bosses that use bullet hell to attack, they're surprisingly generous with how many openings for melee combat they give you.
[*] etc.

If you've sat through all of this, and you enjoy Metroidvanias/bullet hells/platformers/all of the above, then I'm not sure what you're waiting for, go play the game or something

Simply speaking, the gameplay is fun and exiting.

94364298.review:
A fusion of metroidvania and bullet hell. The metroidvania aspects play out as you would expect, exploring the various levels as much as you can with your current equipment to earn more and progress further. Traversal based abilities are fairly standard, but an interesting addition to this is "hidden" techniques and alternate uses for some skills that can be used to reach certain areas before you have the proper item, if you know how to use them. Exploring is also how you find additional items to boost your character's stats or give her new abilities, which is essential to surviving as the difficulty ramps up. Save point and warp point placement is pretty generous and likely to keep you from wasting too much time when revisiting places. Exploring the world is pretty fun overall.

In terms of combat, regular fodder enemies may have attacks with elaborate patterns for you to dodge, go down easily enough in most cases, can do a lot of damage as you get through the game. They're good targets for whatever combat abilities you may gain and an occasionally decent challenge during your journey. The bosses are where things really heat up and the bullet hell aspects start to show, with epic musical scores serving as the backdrop for the intense fights against the game's various bosses and their myriad of awe inspiring attacks. They definitely bring forth a significant challenge, but the game also comes with generous difficulty options and assists to help you make your way through.

 Other notable aspects, it has a cute and colourful artstyle, nice music all around, mostly naked characters you kinda get used to, and a pretty weird but kinda interesting plot.

It's great fun overall, strongly recommend it to fans of metroidvania and bullet hell games.

93757245.review:
I really liked this game!! It's not the best ever, but it gave me a lot of what I want. It's a rare Metroidvania that ISN'T extremely linear and vaguely lets you wander around where you want to go, similar to Hollow Knight. Obviously, you're not going to get the outstanding quality of Hollow Knight here and you really shouldn't expect it, but if you want a nice exploration platformer, this is the game for it.

I, personally, also really like that this game is just filled with 99% girls and women. If you're looking at this and thinking "But is it ACTUALLY gay tho?" It IS actually VERY gay. There's only girls and the girls also love each other and WILL get canon crushes on each other, and I just think that's good and something that I really like. 

It's also fairly sexy in the designs/art, so take that with what you will, but I liked it a lot and I feel it handled it a lot better than other games might. Like, yeah, everyone is sexy and dressed weird and they know it, but you don't get the "we grope you scene hee hee!!" that you get in more mainstream games. If that makes sense. Hard to put into words. It also helps that, again, it's very gay. There IS one scene where random nameless dudes are perving out on the main character, but it is fairly minor, and the main characters beat the crap out of them and say how much they hate them.

The music is also really good most of the time! You won't get your mind blown by every level, but more than half of the big songs are pretty dang good in my opinion. 

The gameplay itself is pretty good too. It's, again, not the most polished and not the most responsive, but it's certainly a Good Enough in my opinion, and the constant upgrades keep you looking for more and make it feel exciting when you do get one. There is a LOT to explore and find, too. You'll just be CONSTANTLY finding things in almost every nook and cranny and I love that kind of thing.

The Bosses are your standard bullet hell types, but each boss tries its very hardest to be as unique as it can in that regard, so I respect it a lot. Most bosses have ways for you to constantly keep moving and attacking and don't feel as repetitive as most platformer bosses can feel. Example being: dodge attacks. Wait for boss to be in a "vulnerable" state. Attack. Repeat. In Rabi-Ribi, you can just keep attacking through just about most things. Sometimes, it WILL feel like the bosses are HP sponges though, especially in post-game content.

The story and writing are.... okay. I can't say I am in love with the characters or world, but I do also genuinely really like them. I wonder if this is due to the translation or just the writing in general? It feels all very dry and extremely literal at times. The plot itself is lighthearted mostly though and the world is full of all sorts of characters that don't have time to get enough attention. I think there's potential in all these things, though, and the player will probably be able to enjoy it still.

Overall, I think this will be one of my favorite games I played this year. Whoever created this, clearly just made something they really wanted. Sexy/cute girls who love other girls and they go on adventures through a colorful and weird world. Really enjoyed it for that! It goes on sale pretty often for a good price too, so I think this is an easy recommend. It's not the best game in the world by a longshot, but its got a lot of heart and charm and that's something to enjoy

93209992.review:
IF you like Metroidvania games…
IF you like ANIME…
IF you like bullet-hell type shooters…

THEN buy this game. The story is fantasically non-sensical, but it’s fairly self-aware of it. The control is silky smooth, and the exploration is fun and satisfying as you would expect of the genre. The game controls great, with enough enemies on-screen to make traversal a fair trial. The artwork leans towards the fanservice side, so it might not be to everyone’s tastes. The enemies range from the cute and ridiculous, to also fairly fanservice-y. Each of the main story beats is accompanied by a bit of nice anime art, and meeting each of the bosses starts and ends with a bit of goofy repartee. 

Overall, the combat is reminiscent of a late-era Mega Man game, but with a lot more emphasis on enemies filling the screen with colorful bullets. You start off with a melee attack, but quickly gain a semi-automated ranged attack, which can be slightly customized to fit how you want to fight. Some of the enemies are static, and just seem to shoot whether or not you’re nearby. The more dangerous enemies aggressively hunt you down while you’re on-screen, hoping to put you in a bad spot between their shots and the suppressing fire of the stationary enemies. Early on, each one of these encounters is pretty harrowing; some of the enemy deployments can take you down pretty quickly. Once you get enough powerups, though, you may find yourself just running through screens of enemies. However, all of the bosses remain perfectly challenging the whole way. The bosses in particular play out like a bullet hell shooter, with tons of tiny shots filling the filling screen in dizzying patterns, daring you find your way through them. The game also rates you on your performance during these battles, inspiring you to fight elegantly and not just tank shots while mashing on the melee button.

As you play the game, more areas open up, and DLC expands on some of these areas with higher degrees of difficulty. Some of the areas can be a bit of a trek to get to, but most areas have several teleporters to get you where you want to go quickly.

Overall, if you like 2D exploratory platformers, bullet hell shooters, and/or cute anime girls, this game is recommended. You’re bound to get your money’s worth.

91982713.review:
Don't let the aesthetic fool you, this is actually NOT weeb trash. 

Hidden behind the admittedly worrisome exterior is a hardcore, will beat you when your pants are down, melee-based bullet-hell metroidvania. Yes. That is what this is.

Essentially if you picture any normal Metroid style world layout, that is what you get here. Gaining new powers and attacks that let you traverse the world to new locations you haven't been. However, unlike many of it's more... confidently dressed peers, Rabi-Ribi has possibly the most boss fights and sequence breakable areas that I've personally seen. Seriously, it feels like there's a boss fight every 15 minutes... and there might be. So having said that...

Good god... The combat starts slow but by a couple hours in you got legit combos at your disposal, and so do your enemies. The normal non-boss fodder range from squishy pushovers to literally more annoying then Lucifer, but then you get to the later bosses and realize that you might not even get to see the credits. It is very much a bullet "hell" game at times, but in a good way. 

There's a light style system where as long as you vary your attacks enough the gauge will fill. You have a number of melee attacks and moves to pull off as well as a pew-pew pellet shot that takes different forms depending on which laser type you have equipped. The higher the style meter the more damage you do. Get hit and it goes down. So not taking damage is incentivised not only through the usual fear of death but also your damage output taking a tank. 

Oh, and them sequence breaks. Yea on first playthrough you might be following the normal path, but on repeats? Really, even on the same ng cycle, later down the line you might accidentally hit some buttons together and- what what that? You found a secret move? So now you learned the alternate wall jump technique before you were even supposed to have wall jump and can go virtually wherever you want. In other games you'd be told "nah ah, you stop that right there you silly billy!" Not here. You find a place your not supposed to be? Explore to your hearts content. 

Is it clear this isn't just some silly rabbit game yet? The whole point of this review is pretty much just so there's another "THIS AIN'T YOUR TYPICAL WEEB CASUL GAME LOOOOOOO-" post on here so maybe someone else will actually pick this up.

Look.
Here me out.
It's a very good metroidvania.
You have to believe me... It's actually one of the best depending on your preference.

If you like action games, Metroid, and don't mind some shmup-style-bullet-hell-teeth-grinding difficulty (the good kind) then pick this up and just pretend the game doesn't have what might be the most unfortunate aesthetic to hinder mass market appeal I've ever seen. 

Oh... and the story is like.. real bad.
But that's okay cause that gameplay be like y e e t.

91294050.review:
Originally, I played this game back in 2016. I recently came back to it, and it ticks a lot of boxes that I enjoy. Just unabashedly: A+got-bunny-girls. It's got the usual Metroidvania hooks that are really enjoyable. The combat is fun, but can be tough. It combines simple beat'em up combos with bullet-hell mechanics...I'm not a big fan of bullet-hell games, and as such, I find the combat quite difficult.
Some parts of the combat don't feel as tight as they should be either. Because they use a stamina meter to limit your combo, chaining attacks together (especially during the early game) feels really unsatisfying. And being able to link between different attack types isn't very smooth either. For example, going from a hammer attack to throwing a bomb is not fluid at all. You also can't have Ribbon (your fairy) shoot while you are attacking.
The story on the other hand....really reminds me of the kind of fan-fic-level anime-obsessed stuff I would write as a teenager. It falls back on to every anime trope in existence, the entire cast of only females is dumber than a sack of rocks, cringe-inducing and forced "will-they/won't-they" tropes, and an overall mixed tone that isn't well balanced and seems to have an identity crisis between wanting to just be a light-hearted game about girls obsessed with bunnies or trying to tell a story that pulls at the heartstrings. I am certain if I played this game back when I was in high school, I would have really digged this story, but honestly...it's just pure tripe. Game play is good though.

87264163.review: It's a fun Metroidvania with a bullet hell twist. The story is pretty unremarkable, but thankfully cutscenes / dialog are skippable if you really don't care to pay attention to that. Also, there is a surprising amount of depth to just how non-linear you can play the game, and an absolutely ridiculous amount of achievements to chase if that's your thing.

87129544.review:
Rabi-Ribi is a very good, mechanically tight exploration platformer (metroidvania). It also has bullet-hell aspects to the boss fights and some really challenging sections, but the game never gets to crazy, and it has plenty of options that let you tune the difficulty. Rabi-ribi is also just really pleasant to play, with very cheery music and colorful, pastel graphics.

Aside from the polish, the thing that sets Rabi-Ribi apart is that it's sort of open-world, even moreso than most metroidvanias. It seems designed so that you can "sequence-break" and go places early, but also acknowledges that you did something special. It's really neat, like it was made knowing people would find ways to break it. This really speaks to the overall quality of the game. Highly recommend!

86908588.review:
I cannot honestly recommend this game to anyone. I literally cannot recall skipping dialogues in any games in the last decade and that game made me do it.

The exploration was dull at best (to the point I managed to get), the battle ideas and patterns were good about 50% of the times but even when they worked the little amount of randomness there was felt overwhelming. Controls were vey unintuitive for the most part. It also expects you to commit for your attack too much. Nothing is cancellable and there are some animatons that a few SECONDS long. There were a lot of cases where I would do a certain attack, the boss would be able to telegraph the attack, does it and hit it with me with some time to spare before I am able to move. Pretty much no boss felt exciting to beat regardless of if it took 1 or 10 tries.

I cannot recommend the game to anyone aside from the people that are up for playing challenging games just for the sake of challenge as it is currently the hardest metroidvania I played (and I played about 45-50 by now. It's an easier genre overall). And even then you will be better off choosing another game on random IMO.

86325588.review:
Not Reccomended
617.7 hours on record

This is one of my favourite games. 

Okay but seriously, this game is fucking amazing. Looking past all the fanservice and also Cicini because God why did they do that to her design, this is quite possibly one of the best games I've ever played, with amazing exploration, level design, and combat. It's so fun to play, so easy to get into, and when you finally learn all the stuff you can do, using it to break the games in ways you think wouldn't be intended but then actually are... It just makes you feel like a fucking god. A bunny girl god with a fairy semi god. 

So, let me break down each aspect of the game:

Story: 7/10
This is definitely a mixed bag for a lot of people but... I actually like the story of this game, its fun, charming, and hey, it has canon lesbians so that's a plus. But the real best parts of the story for me come from everything to do with Noah and the past of Rabi Rabi. I really like how they told it, and Chapter 10 is such a good chapter in the game with how it concluded the story in a great way. 

Music: 9/10
Not every song is amazing, but when they're amazing, holy SHIT they're good. Speicher Galerie was such a good final area theme, matching how brutal the Library was if you didn't know how to get through it by mastering the mechanics you had at your disposal. 

Characters: 8/10
Pretty good, honestly. There's a few I don't care for, but some of them are really good! Irisu definitely is the one who while she isn't bad, you might not like her, and she needed slightly more time since her arc in the last chapter felt ever so slightly rushed but not enough to make me dislike her. I still like her, she's cool.

Gameplay: 11/10
This game is fun. Insanely fun. I have spent so much time playing this game and there is definitely a reason for that. It's just so insanely fun, and the design is so well put together. Like. Wow
There's so much shit to do in this game that it's kinda insane to complete it all. 

Difficulty: As easy or as hard as you want it to be

There are an insane amount of difficulty choices thanks to both the selection of 5 different game modes and 6 different difficulties (9 if you have the Artbook DLC). I used to play on Novice, which is imo a better starting point than Casual. But now I'm able to finish this game and some of the superbosses on BEX.

Overall: 10/10

This game has some flaws, but I just love it too much to let those drag it down for me. Please, if you can, play this game. It's absolutely worth it.

Ahora que ya he acabado el juego puedo decir que es una joya oculta que está muy infravalorada en esté género. Vas a tener una cantidad enorme de horas sacando los objetos, explorando el mapa y sobretodo tratando de conseguir la mayoria de logros que no son nada sencillos. De por si el juego no es fácil, si es tú primera vez obviamente requiere mucho del ensayo y error ya que los jefes no son nada fáciles aunque todo depende de que dificultad elijas.

El diseño de personajes es muy estilo anime y no, por más que parezca que parece un juego de la letra H no lo es. Aunque internet posiblemente ya haya actuado el mismo día que este juego salio....

En fin, en cuanto a la historia al principio no parecerá la gran cosa pero luego más adelante vas averiguando todo el lore que tiene detrás con el tema de la magia y demás, muy al estilo touhou. Cada personaje tiene su carisma e incluso ver las interacciones que tienen cada uno es gustoso de ver.

El diseño de los niveles esta bien logrado, es decir, cada parte del mapa que es totalmente grande (no por algo hay un logro de conectar 777 salas del mapa) conecta de buena manera cada sector y eso está genial.

Recomendable, es un juego con harto carisma y dificultad. Si encuentras que hay mucho texto por la trama tampoco hay problema, puedes saltar todas las escenas para ya preocuparte en los jefes, aunque igual hay modo speedrun.

85649133.review:
I'm quite a big fan of Metroidvanias, and I'm pretty sure this will always be one of my favourites. It was also my gateway into the Bullet Hell genre, so that's definitely a plus as well! If both of these interest you then this is basically a must have!

Pretty much every aspect of this game is on a masterful level. Erina and Ribbon control really well and the many upgrades feel great to obtain and use. The enemies and bosses are very fun to fight, with the bosses being plentiful with a massive array of interesting attacks. The world is huge and offers tons of areas to discover and explore, each with various events occurring in them. There's a bunch of extra areas with plenty more content if all that somehow isn't enough. I could go on, but I think this generally wraps up how good the gameplay is. It ticks off all the boxes in game design and area design and excels in many of them.

Yes, the game is extremely challenging...by default. If you're not confident in taking on tough games, no worries, for there are 2 easy modes made for casual players! If you're worried about being too good, no worries, for there are 3 harder difficulty options excluding the 2 unused options beyond that. Bosses can also have their durability and strength adjusted to be based on area progress or item progress, depending on whether or not you intend to gather all the upgrades. If you change your mind at any point, Skullo can easily change the difficulty for you!

As for everything else? Narrative is surprisingly great. It keeps itself simple for the most part, which is expected for the theme of the game. Without giving spoilers, parts of the game can and will take darker and much more serious turns, somehow without going overboard with it. Overall the setting is cute and fun, exactly as it should be! The darker elements are welcomed and really add a lot.

Music is phenomenal. I've often gone back to the music when not playing and my words can't do it justice! Each song, both overworld and battle, captures the scene extremely well and adds so much more to the already great gameplay! The music even makes very good use of leitmotifs, along with varying itself during gameplay.

Visually the game may not be perfect or spectacular in all regards, but it still looks really nice and keeps a joyous and consistent art style. Each area feels distinct from one another and enemy attacks are spectacular to look at!

There's tons of content in this game. I haven't put over 120hrs into a Metroidvania title before this one! If the huge array on content somehow isn't enough for you (much like how it wasn't for me) there's a bunch of DLC which all add a lot more to the game!

I don't say this often, but this game gets a 10/10 from me. It really is a treat to play! Don't pass on this one if you're into this sort of game. Even if you're not very familiar with Metroidvanias or Bullet Hells, this'll likely be a good entry point!

85568014.review:
While at first skeptical due to the amount of fanservice on display when people around me shared screenshots of the game, I eventually caved in upon hearing that the game is a Metroidvania. Turns out, it was one of the best decisions I could've ever made.

While Rabi-Ribi may not be a masterpiece, it does so many things right that it's easy to forgive it its faults. The map is well designed, giving you plenty to explore and get lost in, maybe not to the extent of some of its brethren (Axiom Verge and Hollow Knight are two games that immediately come to mind) but it's still fun to navigate around, in large parts due to its movement. Furthermore, this movement highlights one of this game's greatest strength, which is sequence breaking.

GemaYue has largely embraced the speedrunning and sequence breaking community with open arms, providing both a speedrun mode and also not removing any bugs unless they actually caused major problems with the game as a whole, even going so far as including an option to revert the way Hammer Rolls work since speedrunners were using them for zips and the subsequent update broke them. Sequence breaking is further encouraged by means of achievements, incentivizing players to think outside of the box and outright break out of it, something that the map, perhaps both accidentaly yet also quite likely intentionally accomodates. 

That's not to say the game is spotless though. While most bosses are quite fair (within the realm of bullet hell shooters) and well designed, there are several frustrating encounters that, while not impossible, knocked the experience down a bit for me. The other large problem this game has is with its pacing, particularly towards the end, as the finale of the game feels like it largely overstays its welcome and the game should have ended two chapters ago. 

These downsides have not been enough to make me not enjoy the game though. Rabi-Ribi is one of the best Metroidvanias you can play right now, and it manages to keep me playing it to this very day, both thanks to its updates and main game, as well as the ability for people to make and share their own levels. If you're looking for a fun time in this genre and don't mind coping with a lot of bullets on screen, this game is definitely for you.

85567435.review: Although the anime style may want to make you turn away, there's merit in looking past that. This game is excellent in both the metroidvania AND bullet-hell genres, and honestly has an insane amount of replayability. Plenty of items to collect, movement is varied and you always feel very in control, there's a lot of bosses and they all feel surprisingly unique, the challenge level can go incredibly high if you want it to... for me, it's honestly nearly a perfect game: even the flaws it might have actually help make it more fun. I can't recommend this enough.

I tried to play this game, but the skimpiness of the outfits and the dialogue treating them like children actually made me feel sick. The gameplay might be good later on (I wouldn't know), but if you look at the artwork and think "this kinda grosses me out", steer clear - it doesn't get better in-game.

Nearly all characters wear revealing outfits, with the most revealing outfit going to Ribbon, the very childlike fairy sidekick. She is nearly naked. Several characters speak in third-person first-person (e.g. "Ribbon is lost!") and constantly refer to their "masters". A character found early on is described as peeping on Ribbon in the shower. The main protagonist, who wears a Playboy-esque outfit, is repeatedly emphasized as being a regular pet bunny (with a pet bunny's understanding of the world) given a human form. It goes on.

Factors like these gave me a deep feeling of discomfort that I couldn't shake. It seems like the game assumes its target audience is into these characters, and wants to provide fanservice to them. Based on the mods on the Steam Workshop, they'd be correct - a large chunk of them are nude mods and alternative, skimpier outfits. The game seems to seek to appeal to people who're sexually interested in characters that have an underage appearance and childlike-level intelligence.
I wasn't kidding when I said I felt sick to my stomach earlier.

I do realize I have a shallow take on this game. "The game's characters and themes are repulsive!" isn't a very deep level of critique for any game, and I somewhat feel like a puritan for disliking the game for this reason. I think anyone with a similar perspective as I do would appreciate a review like this pointing out how appearances don't deceive.
I wish someone warned me before I started playing, so I'm warning you. If you read this and don't care/don't see why what I described would be disturbing or uncomfortable, you'll probably enjoy Rabi-Ribi. Consider it recommended to you. Otherwise, avoid this game.

81527215.review:
Boss-fight centered 2D action game with heavy shoot'em'up elements. Mechanically solid, has an absurd amount of content and well designed boss attack patterns. Challenging game that controls very well.

Player characters control similar to Megaman games (eg. Megaman Zero) where you have a ranged charge shot and a variety of melee combos & movement options. Combat and movement control is surprisingly varied with hidden techniques the player might find throughout multiple playthroughs.

Dialogue, art and story(?) can be super cringey but unless that really bugs you I think it's worth ignoring and skipping cutscenes etc.

Rabi-Ribi strives on pushing the player with increasingly more difficult boss fights. There are a huge variety of game modes, superbosses and optional challenges (even for meta-level stuff like speedrunning the game or 0% runs). 
Hardcore 2D action fans who enjoy boss fights can get a lot of bang for their buck for all that, others not so much. If you end up enjoying the game there's definitely no lack of content.

Later boss fights take long to finish which can be frustrating if you get stuck. But they have a much larger pool of attacks / unique situations compared to most games so it's more a case of challenge rather than a repetitive/boring fight with a long healthbar.

Exploration/world aspect and platforming levels aren't that notable compared to other metroidvanias. But combat design and boss fights are a major strong point.
I think the post-game "Is The Order a DLC?" makes the rest more interesting with focused and challenging platforming instead of fluff but that may not be for everyone either.

Personally found the soundtrack good all-around too.

[Played through Main game + Order DLC on Hard (standard, no buffs)]

81377712.review: In the early 2000s a gargantuan custom campaign by the name of Visions of the future was created for Starcraft Brood war. It was an anime based campaign and it remains to this day the largest and most detailed custom campaign ever created, by far, with exactly 150 maps, 6 mods, tons of secrets, and more. Rabi-ribi is to the Metroidvania genre as Visions of the Future is to Starcraft. At first impression this game seems to be nothing more than weeaboo bait in a mediocre game but it doesn't take long before you discover you're playing in one of the largest most content-full metroidvanias ever created. This is recommended for any fan of metroidvanias as well as any fan of touhou. At 50 hours of gameplay, this is also one of the few games on steam that are underpriced. Make sure you buy the "is the order a DLC?" DLC as it basically holds the final conclusion to the plot. Indeed, this game is second only to Hollow knight in its size. with Bloodstained: Ritual of the night being the only other game that comes close to being as massive as this one.

76830292.review:
I don't think it would be possible for me to overstate how much I like this game. I played it back when it first came out in 2016, so this thumbs up is far overdue.

Rabi-Ribi blends familiar metroidvania gameplay with the bullet-hell/danmaku genre. This combination plays out brilliantly, as each new method you gain for exploring and traversing the world (double jump, air dash, ground slide, etc) translates into the boss fights as new techniques you can (and must) use to avoid increasingly complex patterns of bullets. The gameplay rapidly evolves with each new ability you gain, and the difficulty demands you learn to make the most of each tool you are given. The game becomes very challenging very quickly (especially if you are as bad at bullet hells as I am), but it's precisely the difficulty- the split second reactions to slide under a stream of bullets, or air dash against the wall to stay suspended in an opening while lasers fill the screen- that makes the boss fights so rewarding.

Though the game is very difficult, you do have some options to give yourself an advantage. You can carry a small number of healing items, bought from the (cute) shopkeeper in the hub of the game. You can also find upgrades to health, stamina, attack damage, etc out in the world, in addition to badges that offer various effects- such as applying poison to your attacks, or increasing the number of i-frames you are given after being hit.

And I'd be remiss not to mention the soundtrack. This is easily one of my favorite game soundtracks. Each area of the game is accompanied by a track that fits it perfectly. The early game sounds upbeat and fun, while toward the end of the game, there are songs that are impactful and even emotional.

I could (as my friends know very well) go on a great deal longer than this. I love this game. The boss fights of no other game give me quite the same feeling as Rabi-Ribi. They are intense and satisfying but not quite in the same way something like souls is. If I could put it into words, I would.

Rabi-Ribi delivers one of the most unique spins on the metroidvania genre. The boss fights are amazing, the world is full of hidden upgrades to uncover, and the soundtrack is absolutely incredible. If anything you have read has piqued your interest, I implore you to give this game a try.

74352654.review:
7/10

Rabi-Ribi (Rabbit-Ribbon, the characters you control) is a fun metroidvania platformer with bullet-hell-style boss fights and a Japanese-style chibi panache. This is actually one of the largest (overall) metroidvanias I've played. 

The story is rather confusing (what with anthropomorphic bunnies, cats, elementals, and whatnot), seems to be a love story about the bunny-girls, Erina and Erisu. The story has that distinct anime weirdness to it, so you may (or may not) care about such things, but if you're into it, it's a cute story I'm told. I thought it was super strange how everyone in the game world is just super-casual about animals suddenly turning into people; it's like it was a regular thing for them and they couldn't be bothered to be shocked. Whatever.

Weird anime story aside, the gameplay is where this game shines bright. The levels are well designed, fun, somewhat challenging, and unique. The controls are responsive and the level progression gates are pretty creative.

The "boss" fights take that platforming goodness and throw it to the wind in exchange for some bullet-hell gameplay. It's not the kind where if you get hit, you die; it CAN be that if you really want it to be, but if you put the game on "casual" difficulty, you can tank all of the battles just fine without dying. I mean, on the final battle, you MIGHT have to eat some health items if you get hit by everything.

The thing annoyed me most was that the bosses have scripted damage-caps that artificially lengthen the duration of the battle. I get that the devs wanted to show off that bullet-hell dazzle, but I found it to be ridiculous and a poor design choice. Why didn't they just make the bosses health scale with your current DPS instead of making them stop taking damage until a certain time has elapsed?

Overall, Rabi-Ribi is a rather enjoyable metroidvania/BH/VN hybrid, and it's totally worth a playthrough if you pick it up on sale. If you're into the anime waifu scene, then this might be just what you need, but if you aren't, then it's just a pretty decent metroidvania with some weird design choices shoehorned into it.

This Metroidvania is amazing!
Controls in this game are rock solid, basically perfect, very enjoyable if you use an actual SNES controller *(However, requires joy2key or similar software to assign buttons if using certain USB SNES controllers).
There is a lot of freedom to explore the game quite early on, being able to go to most area's with in the first chapters of the game.
The battle system's bullet hell platformer style is a very entertaining take on the metroidvania genre, and makes boss battles all memorable and challenging for the most hardcore, with easier settings for the less initiated and more casual.
The story may be a little too "anime niche" for some people, but I think most would find it to be a cute story, it's certainly not difficult to follow and works well with the games play style and aesthetics.
The music in this game is all very fitting, and just downright amazing. After playing this game for 3 years I just cannot get these catchy tunes out of my head, listening to them frequently.
Most importantly, Bunnies.. So much Bun power in this game. Who doesn't like bunnies and bun girls?
This has been my most cherished game in my steam library since receiving it.
This game and it's DLC is, in my opinion, all been well worth the price!

73334666.review:
Easily the best Metroidvania to date, by leaps, bounds, and at least a couple of hops.

From the Publisher that also brought you... uh... *checks list* nope, not those games, hold on.
Can I get a do-over?
From the Publisher that also brought you M.A.S.S Builder, Mahou ARMS, and-uh, you know--the Sakura games and Nekopara-comes the best Metroidvania. Period. You can take all the issue with the 'horny on main' aesthetic you want, but the fact of the matter is if you're looking for any kind of definitive Metroidvania experience, from exploration to music to combat to overall presentation, you will not find a better one and it's been four years since its initial release. It even has DLC, for MORE CONTENT. Everything you could ever want.

The overall mechanics are incredibly solid, as they need to be from any game in the bullet hell genre alone, let alone this one, and they allow for so much discovery. Literally. The sheer amount of map that's available to explore with hidden items and areas and power ups and easter eggs is staggering, and there's bits hidden EVERYWHERE. But it's all accessible. Everything about the controls makes sense and just generally feel good. The game takes a bit of a hit whenever it decides specifically to not use its own mechanics in homage to other games which came before and likely inspired it. You don't need to play those games though, you have Rabi-Ribi, and Rabi-Ribi is so much better.

The music. The MUSIC. THE MUSIC! THE SOUNDSCAPE! If only every developer could afford this much time to what and how their game sounds. The score is just so good though. It fits the scenes and varying atmospheres of the game perfectly and still manages to be catchy all on its own. The sounds are satisfying and, almost as importantly, give weight, depth, and feeling to what's being done on screen. This is something that even high budget studios seem to miss quite often, but the developers of Rabi-Ribi seem to have an understanding of the importance of music and sound and the potential impact it can have. It's not always the most noticable thing, but it's part of what separates good games from great games, and great games from games like Rabi-Ribi.

It even has a good story. NOBODY BELIEVES IN PANTS AND THEY STILL WROTE A GOOD STORY! I know that's a bit of a non-sequitur, but honestly I don't want to say anything about the story because this is all very improvised and I don't know how to reference things without spoiling, and the story is good enough to not spoil. I dunno about the DLC storylines, but the main one is great. Don't like it? Find the other endings, nerd.

As for replay value, yeah, Rabi-Ribi's got that too. Varying modes of difficulty, vast amounts of exploration, mechanics to explore and master, a level and upgrade system that you could throw out the window if you're a masochist or something but if you do want to do things passively YOU CAN! Figure it out. Rabi-Ribi is about exploration and discovery at its core, and honestly the developers incorporate that theme into every aspect of the game. It's beautiful.

Play Rabi-Ribi.

72764489.review:
Is it for hentai-lovers, japanese video game culture fanatics, or medtroidvania followers?

I'm actually still not sure after going through the main game, but I come in the last category at least. Rabi-Ribi's core gameplay is fun. It's just like others in the genre--upgrades, exploration and boss fights. Though I recommend it for that, when sets it apart is very niche in my opinion.

The graphics and sound during normal gameplay are great. The upgrades and combat are decently interesting.

Less appealing to me is the scantily clad all female minors cast that is shown during all dialogue, which is at least a quarter of the game (but you can skip, thank Christ). On that note, nor am I interested in "cute" conversations or anime expression figures seen during loading screens or displaying character health. 

Fighting itself is fun, but you need to be prepared for what that is in this game before buying. Exploration has some harsh spikes and easy fights. Nearly EVERY boss fight is a repetitive, but different variation of, a bullet hell where you must cycle through attacking and dodging. This is additionally forced by your most powerful tools having diminishing returns in short time spans. The game also scales everything to you, so if you don't find secrets and upgrade stuff you're in for a challenge.

That being said this game gets attention for a reason, mostly because of the girls, but there is some fun metroidvania moments in there I assure you!

72396520.review:
[b]The best game I've ever played.[/b]
Very fun gameplay, a lot of cute things, a fairly big free-roamable world with a lot of secrets and things to find, many things to do even after you finished the game... And all made mostly by a single person.

This game is about a bunny named Erina who somehow got transformed into human and wants to find their master and then starting to uncover mysteries that Rabi-Rabi island has. A simple task turns into a big adventure with a lot of memorable moments... And all this in format of a mix between bullet hell and metroidvania, with some tough platforming sections here and there. If you want to get into bullet hell games or platformers, playing this could be one of the stepping stones into those two genres in a way... Since it gives you understanding of concepts those games are based around.

The game offers a wide variety of difficulty settings that can accommodate to each type of player. Starting from a difficulty that anyone can clear implying they try (literally anyone i mean), to difficulty that only the very few can do... Which seems impossible at first sight and is called such in the game as well.

Also this game is the only one I played that has speedrun mode - a mode that skips all the story stuff and shows in-game timer with item/map% shown as well. Due to the world being open, there are very many ways to build yourself a speedrun route for this game. There are many factors that can impact your route choice, but for some of the main categories there is a couple of really bad tricks that can kill your run in the middle / end if you want a very optimized route...

This game is perfect for people that enjoy challenges of many kinds, be that simply obtaining all achievements, beating the game fast, with various handicaps, or even beating the game with all items being randomized. (I don't suggest randomizer to anyone who has not memorized every single item location though)

And for people who want to enjoy the game casually there is a lot of cuteness, glorious OST and a lot of fun to have...

I tried to be brief with this review and also didn't have my thoughts organized enough, but in short: buy this game if you like any of the following:
1. Challenges
2. Cute things
3. Bunnies
4. Metroidvanias


Also I [b]REALLY[/b] suggest anyone buying this game to at least buy "Is the Order a DLC", this DLC expands the game story, makes it much more interesting and adds new mechanics to the game. For people that want more challenge they can buy Before Next Adventure as well.
10/10 in all categories. Don't even need to list the categories. (S+)

Note: My achievements were reset and all my timestamps are different from actual ones. Due to it happening due to a certain accident, the developer decided to add a new launch option for me to be able to reset and still stay at #14 (#1, because 13 people were hackers) in achievement leaderboard as I was the first person to obtain every achievement after cocoa DLC was released.
The new launch option is -noachiupload, it prevents uploading achievement score to leaderboard so I can reset achievements without affecting the board.
Actual time of completion is about 250 hours.
All valid achievement timestamps are here: https://truesteamachievements.com/game/RabiRibi/achievements?gamerid=46228

72220752.review:
What's more unsatisfiable than gamers who finished The Last of Us Part 2 or more unquenchable than the desire for Ubisoft to make another open-world game? If you thought, "a weeb's craving for anything anime," you are correct. And diving down the 'rabbit hole' of anime, here we have Rabi-Ribi, a bullet-hell Metroidvania where you play as Anime Girl the Rabbit, Erina. She is a rabbit who became a human — a human who looks like she ran out of a lewd maid cafe while still on duty. And it's up to our bunny girl to find her owner and discover the secrets of why bunnies have disappeared from the world. If you read this sentence and are thinking to yourself, "What...?" Don't worry, there's more. During your journey, you will meet new friends, who will immediately try to kill you upon encounter. If you successfully survive annihilation, your new, now non-hostile friend will agree to help you open a portal to a different dimension. It's an outside world full of dangerous degenerates and perverts similar to the ones who play this game. It's in these two worlds where you'll uncover the mysteries of Rabi-Ribi Island. 

If the story doesn't arouse you, that's okay. There's also — thrilling gameplay. If you're unsure as to whether or not this bullet-hell platformer is for you, fear not. Our female protagonist comes: well-equipped, and by that, I mean she wields the mighty Piko Hammer, a weapon so powerful it could even match the iconic Mega-Buster. Alongside you flies your trusty fairy helper, Ribbon, who decided that wearing nothing but a ribbon cut into two pieces, would protect her from harsh environments such as freezing icy summits and blazing volcanic caverns. She has the ability to cast magic spells that not only assist enemy bosses in giving you epileptic seizures, but also deal massive damage to them as well. It's a win-win situation.

The gameplay loop is simple. Run about the map, find a boss, die to the boss about 10+ times, receive a "pity-buff" to beat the boss, and then repeat. I should also add that there are tons of secrets to discover, upgrades and combos to unlock, as well as those sweet, honeyed CGs players will be anticipating. While you won't find any of that juicy NSFW material most of you are looking for, Rabi-Ribi does not fail to greet players with much bunny fanservice, as it will become apparent that every character in this game looks like they just got bouncing back from Comiket. In other words, hopeful anticipants won't be disappointed.

In summary, this game gets a lot of things right. Top-notch gameplay, eargasmic music, pleasing visuals, and an expected incomprehensible anime-style plot. Let's get serious for a moment; we all know why you want this game. Don't try to hide yourself with the usual "for the great gameplay!"  phrase. If you want to play as a lewd anime bunny girl roaming about beating every living thing to death and then getting pimp-slamped herself to death, you've come to the right place. No shame in calling it what it is, fellow degenerate. Welcome to Rabi-Ribi~


(Warning: This review is a bit different from my normal ones as it contains excessive sarcasm)

71152338.review:
Throughout 2019 I played several Metroidvania games, including Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night, both Guacamelees, Touhou Luna Nights, and, er, some of Hollow Knight... and Rabi-Ribi was my personal favourite. 

Simply put, it had by far my favourite boss fights. (I played on Hard with Alternative scaling.) Bosses have tons of elaborate attack patterns that often fill the screen with bullets/lasers/etc, which look incredibly daunting and panic-inducing, and thus feel so satisfying when you learn how to best avoid them. Many bosses I've died to over and over, but when you lose to a boss, you can continue right in front of the boss, keeping all the consumables and buffs you had from before the attempt. And you can even skip the dialog/cutscenes quickly and thus be back in the action in a matter of seconds.

It's like a bullet hell, but also has RPGish elements in that you don't die in one hit, can adjust what 'gear' you're wearing to customize your playstyle somewhat and if certain stats might be more useful for a certain fight, and things like that. 

And the exploration's great too, with a ton of freedom in where you want to go, yet it provides some suggestions so that you never feel lost wondering if you're making any progress.

70582761.review:
8/10

Rabi-Ribi is an incredibly cute but also deceptively hard bullet hell metroidvania game.

You play as Erina, a bunny who suddenly finds herself turned into a human-bunny hybrid and in a strange place, then sets out to find her master again. The game is a metroidvania through and through - certain areas can't be reached at first, but as the game progresses, you find new items that allow you to reach new areas. There is no leveling system - instead, all character upgrading is done by finding items on the way that increase the character's stats, acquiring badges that grant certain bonuses and buying upgrades at the shop. Despite the lack of a leveling system, there are still plenty of upgrades available.

The game's main difference from "traditional" metroidvania games is the bullet hell element. The beginning of the game is quite easy, but very soon bosses, even the early ones, release attacks that require precise movements in order to be avoided.

The game feels, looks, sounds and plays great. The art for each character (shown during dialogue scenes) is very well done and the pixelated graphics are cute and well done. It also helps that the game has great sound design and an amazing soundtrack.

The story is also quite interesting - it gets a bit convoluted as the game progresses and reveals more of the plot, but it works for the most part and shows a story that is a lot deeper than first expected. Character dialogue is also well done for the most part, including some very good translations. Not once during the game did I feel like there was something missing or misplaced in the dialogue because of translation issues.

Combat works quite well. Between all the different attacks that are unlocked as the game progresses, magic attacks for ranged combat, boost attacks and the combo system, there is plenty of variety in combat. More so considering the variety of enemies as well.

I think the only issue I had with the game was with some of the levels from the DLCs, which rely more on platforming than combat - which is okay in theory, but not great in practice. Certain areas from these levels are near impossible to get through without taking damage, which was also one of the reasons why I had to reduce the difficulty from Novice to Casual (since even on Novice the game can be pretty hard and I'm also not going to pretend I'm some kind of bullet hell master).

The only other thing I could think of besides that is the map system, which is kinda confusing and doesn't really explain to you what each icon means. Sometimes it also doesn't show when an area has a connection to another area.

I think that if they balanced the difficulty a little and improved certain things on the game, a possible sequel (if there ever is one) could be even better than this one.

Easy recommendation, even at full price - just be warned that this isn't an easy game.

70361176.review:
If you get over the fact that it looks like a cheap bootleg hentai game, you'd discover an amazing, non-linear metroidvania with creative boss fights.

In my opinion, what makes this game truly unique among others is its progression and boss battles. They resemble bullet hell games, although the patterns are predictable enough to make it feel fair. Plus, you can progress on whichever way you want, avoid certain bosses until you feel like tackling them, find collectibles and upgrades if you want to focus on that before facing bosses, level up and customize the player character to your style.

It isn't a purely hardcore game, although it can be on higher difficulties. Having many difficulty modes makes it accessible to anyone, regardless of your playstyle or skill. And if you struggle with a particular boss fight, you can always buy consumables that make it much more manageable. So I think anyone who enjoys action platformers can get into this game without feeling like you're bashing your head against the wall repeatedly.

I loved this game and can't wait for a sequel or spiritual successor.

69873888.review:
This is a "bullet hell" game with a Metroidvania design.

If you like difficult bullet hell games where you're dodging a thunderstorm of bullets non-stop for 20 minutes at a time during a boss battle, Rabi-Ribi will be amazing. If you like Metroidvania games, you might want to pass. The main mode of this game actually discourages MV-style exploration. It's more focused on dodging while chipping away at enemies.

Pros:
- Cute MV-style world
- The BG music for each area is awesome
- Awesome bullet-hell boss battles
- Excellent freedom of choice (all items are optional) and backtracking
- Offers many difficulty levels and you can switch between them; normal mode is quite forgiving

Cons:
- The story is absolute nonsense and extremely-weak
- The characters are too psychotic to be cute
- Collecting items is a double-edged sword that levels up enemies
- Certain bosses sequences are really long
- Post-game content is insanely difficult

69640384.review:
[h2]Rabi-Ribi[/h2]
[i]Jumping around and smashing everything with a mallet never looked so cute![/i]

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
Rabi-Ribi is a Metroidvania Platformer with Bullet Hell style combat everywhere, all wrapped up in a cute little 2D Pixelart graphic. The game consist roughly of 20% story dialogue (VN style), 40% running around looking for more secrets, items, bosses or whatever and 40% awesome boss fights. (Only counts for the Story Mode)

As expected with Metroidvanias, except for certain parts locked by game or story progression the world is open and you as the player have the complete freedom of choice on what to do when. The story progresses on a certain number of bosses beaten, not specific bosses beaten in order, and you can decide where to go and what items to pick up everywhere. (You even get an achievement for beating the game without ever picking up your melee weapon.)

In terms of combat, next to the constant bullet-hell-dodging-struggle you face not only with bosses but literally every tiny minion you encounter plenty of throughout the world, you have several different combat abilities. Many melee attack moves as well as several kinds of ranged magic attacks, each having a different attack pattern, charged attack and special skill. All of them are unlocked and upgraded by picking up specific items in the world or buying other specific boosts in the town shop.

More advanced attack moves are also usable and at some point even needed to clear harder platformer puzzles, which is one of the most common ways how new areas are locked until you find the needed buff somewhere else.

The boss battles are long, challenging (there are several difficulties to choose from - per (only for some) boss and playthrough), epic and feature enough uniqueness in every last one of them to never get boring.

Finally, alongside the special items you aquire throughout your journey, there are "badges" to collect as well. Each one of them giving different passive buffs, but only a (larger with game progression) limited number of them can be active at a time, limited by a point-cost-system.

[hr]
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2554689030[/url]

[hr]
[h3]Content & Runtime[/h3]
With over 20 unique bosses to fight, of which many have more than a single unique bossfight, scattered over 9 (+ town) unique areas with several progress locked sub-areas, dozens of items and badges to find/upgrade, several story chapters including an "After Game" and "After-After Game", as well as NG+ mechanics, several difficulties to challenge, an additional speedrun and boss rush gamemode - plenty of content is given considering the small and cute appearance of this game.

Depending on how much motivation you have to challenge chasing the over 200 Achievements, ranging from simple game progress to literally breaking the game, and how much of a challenge clearing the game itself is for you, multiple dozens of hours of gametime can be guaranteed.

And besides the already good enough gameplay challenging all the awesome boss fights, the game also delivers a story that's worth mentioning - and enjoying of course. Even though the story only really gets serious towards the end and in the DLCs, under the cute and lighthearted mask lies something that, after finishing it, I would even call "emotional". Both the main story's ending as well as the true ending in the DLCs building up on that leave a certain impact after clearing, different from the usual "I finally cleared that awesome boss fight" feeling.

To enjoy everything the game and story offer to its fullest, the "bunnybox" gives a CG gallery to look at all the story related CG artworks again, as well as a music box where you can listen to all the over 60 OSTs, all the ingame sound effects and even modify the play speed/pitch as it would be affected by certain ingame effects (all if you saw/heared it ingame once before).

[hr]
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2559059588[/url]

[hr]
[h3]The DLCs[/h3]
They do actually add content.
Of course the soundtrack and artbook are completely optional while the "real" content DLCs are highly suggested.

They do add new sub areas, new items, new bosses, new challenges, new story chapters, new everything - basicly expanding the base game in a way DLCs should. None of them are necessary, though if you enjoy the base game they are certainly worth considering.

On a side note, even the Artbook is recommendable - it does not only consist of concept artwork and lots of developer commentary, it even features a look at content back when it was in development and some scrapped gameplay ideas, which are fully playable there though.
On top of that it delivers the sprite viewer - a mode where you can enjoy and pose all the character (VN story) sprites in the game.

Who enjoyed the game and wants a fair bit more of it will certainly not be disappointed.
Overall, getting the complete bundle is a good idea when you are confident you'll like the game.

[hr]
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2554689112[/url]

[hr]
[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
Is this game worth it?
Certainly. It looks cute and isn't that expensive (even the complete bundle during a sale is almost nothing compared to all the content) and offers lots and lots to play with. It is a cute little timefiller for whenever you want to kill a few hours, though keeping you occupied for quite some time in total. The difficulty is highly adjustable so that both beginners and veterans will have their fair share of fun.

Getting the bundle in the next sale is recommended, unless you are too unsure if the base game is something for you in the first place - during the 2h refund-gametime you have you can make yourself a crystal clear picture of what awaits you.

68922048.review:
Rabi Ribi is a hidden gem, its incredibly well designed and one of the best Metroidvanias out there, even rivaling the likes of Hollow Knight and Ori. It comes more closer to a true non-linear Metroidvania than any other, with an overwhelming amount of exploration, freedom, Super Metroid-like hidden techniques, and sequence breaking, with a large number of achievements for fighting bosses "earlier than intended". The overworld is beautiful, with an extremely fitting soundtrack of ~60 OSTs.

As a Bullet Hell, there are no shortage of bosses that carry a progression scaling to keep them difficult and brutal, and definitely felt very challenging even in the "normal" difficulty. It takes off the kiddie gloves very quickly, and pushed me to be better, and with constant memorization I eventually reached all the no-hit boss achievements.

The main story can come off as a hit-or-miss, but the dialogue is fairly quirky and sometimes comical and self-aware (Achievement: "Talking to everyone is unnecessary!"). I really enjoyed meeting the bosses which have a lot of flavorful personality, in spite of attacking for the silliest of reasons.

In spite of the art, the characters actually present themselves as cute. While most characters tend to show skin, the game actually has next-to-no fan service: there are no jiggle physics, the amount of clothing ripped in defeat CGs being extremely tiny and minimal holes, no "bathing scene", absolutely nothing to stimulate the male gaze. I honestly don't understand the dislike for the art, when successful game series like Shantae present themselves as more risque with blatant fan-service.

Overall, a phenomenal and definitely must-play game, which doesn't have thousands of overwhelming reviews for no reason.

68859616.review:
Incredibly well designed and fun fun fun. So far I've only cleared the easiest setting, and there's still so much more to do. This is a game for people seeking a bullet hell challenge to go with their side scrolling and exploring. And there is a ton to explore and secrets everywhere.

I never ran into a point where I was so frustrated that I had to take a break, but some of the boss fights push you. I didn't run into many issues with the platforming and while the game 'punishes' you when you miss a jump, the level design is such that it doesn't delay you much. It's also an easy game to pick up and put down, as there are save points everywhere.

Finally, I have never played a 'Metroidvania' that allows you this much freedom. They give some loose objectives to move the story forward, but you are in full control of how the story plays out, and many of the achievements are tied to this experimentation, making this game near infinitely replayable if you want to try and get all of the 212 achievements (with the DLC). 

By the time I "beat" the game, I had only discovered 69% (nice) of the map and only 68% (almost nice) of items, so I'll be at this for awhile.

I'll finish by saying that while the artwork is certainly suggestive, I found letting my wife know that the game is actually well worth playing to get me past that hurdle (not that she honestly cares that much for my silly hobby). I don't tend to go for games with artwork this style, mostly because it's not what I look for. This is just slightly more racy than the Shantae games, which are also well worth your time, but not nearly as robust as this was.

Highly Recommended. A

68347187.review:
This is a good game.

Important: If you are new to action platforming games, this is not a good place to start.

At the time of writing - the achievement for beating this game entirely (including post-game) on normal has a lower completion rate globally than Sekiro's defeat all bosses achievement (another game infamous for starting a difficulty controversy on the internet). That's how hard it is simply to beat the game on normal. 

There are skill-walls in the game also when it comes to platforming. Even if you have all items and are pretty much maxed out in the game and don't have problem in fights, but you can't time a jump into air dash (correctly in a tight 0.2 second window) into a triple wall jump, you simply can't get to the next room. And you need to in order to progress the story. That's how brutal this game this.

The bullet hell action is another story. There's very little "aeroplane-style" bullet hell sequences where you dodge like you would a traditional vertical/horizontal scrolling shooter. Most of the game involves navigating bullet hell via platforming. Controlling jump height by length of button press, air dashing, sliding, dropping etc is key. If all of this sounds good, you're going to like this game.

Even tougher than the gameplay is the fact that the cutesy art style and suggestive CG makes this a really tough game to be walked in on. It's like being walked in on when playing Dead or Alive. No one will believe you're playing it for the game. But you know better, you person of culture.
