65823123.review:
This game really took me by surprise and completely blew my expectations of the water. It's one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played and it's probably my new favorite indie game. At this time with just under 50 hours I've completed all of the primary game content and bosses of the base game and DLC content with a modest completion percentage, minus a couple of the special bosses, but I won't be stopping anytime soon. The game is packed with content and you'll definitely be able to get your money's worth, particularly if you're the completionist type. There's a ton of achievements to hunt down as well as challenge modes: different boss rushes and a speedrun mode. The game even has workshop, something I would never typically expect from a game like this. 
Really, I like just about every element of the game. The music, the characters, the story, but above everything else is the gameplay. The standard metroidvania level exploration is great, the platforming sections were neat and fun. The bosses are what stand out to me most though. They're all unique and super fun. The way you get a glimpse into different characters through their attacks is wonderful and the magnitude of some of the battles at times left me in awe. There's times where I was left feeling like some particular attacks weren't exactly fair; not everything is perfectly intuitive for sure, but all in all I think it just comes down to learning the trick to some of the difficult attacks, which is fine. There's a healthy difficulty to the boss fights, and that's a good thing. They feel like proper bosses, something I find a lot of games drop the ball on. I've seen a couple people complain about the length of the boss fights, but I only consider that a plus, and a big one at that, which further contributes to them actually feeling like proper bosses and that ultimately only means more fun gameplay. 
I'd totally expected a completely generic, superficial story not prior knowing much about the game, but on the contrary even the story managed to draw me in. Honestly some of the character dialogue isn't exactly deep, and as such many of the supporting character personalities fall under simple stereotypical anime character archetypes but nevertheless the bits of lighthearted dialogue among characters in between the proper story segments is nice and makes the game a relaxing, comfy play.  
It's not a game that's for everybody; some won't be able to get on board with the game's mix of genres. Even if it's not your typical go-to, I highly recommend giving the game a try as you too might be pleasantly surprised.
Update: Having now spent some 170+ hours playing the game to obtain 100% achievements I actually consider Rabi-Ribi a very strong contender for being my favorite game all-time. Without question it's the sort of game I could and do intend to play again and again even still.

Gameplay feels clunky early on with the inability to perform moves in every direction as you only get those attacks later on as power ups and having to search for those power ups is a pain in the ass. There is no detector or anything so you have to throw bombs everywhere in hopes it blows up a secret passage and even then you may end up needing another power up to get it anyway. Thus you end up backtracking a billion times.

The game also is rather unfair, most of the time you get hit, it is because the projectiles fill up the already small rooms leaving you with no space to evade. The answer is to either run away or stay behind cover and wait 20 sec till your laser kills them through the wall both of which feel really lame. Bosses are also an issue as most of them end up in trial and error. They usually telegraph the attack beginning but then you still don´t know how the attack will spread and in which direction it will end leaving you in situations where you are unable to avoid damage. Atleast the saves are fair and often so you won´t have to redo much and in case of bosses you start right before them again. But that doesn´t mean bosses are hard, especially later when you get a certain item you can abuse invincibilty frames and do tremendous damge at the same time making them a cake-walk.

All in all it isn´t bad but I rather play a better metroidvania as this game is way too overrated due to its cute aesthetic.

64588928.review:
Game hard. Game good.

I thought that I was signing up for a cakewalk with cute yuri moments, but unbeknownst to me I was actually selling my soul to the bullet hell devil. This game is punishing, confusing, ridiculously time-consuming, and yet all the same it manages to be cutesy, it manages to keep you playing and encourages you to take on even harder challenges, it manages to keep you looking for more of the hundreds of secret items scattered around the map, all of which are completely unnecessary to beat the game. This, in particular, is what astonishes me about the game, and keeps me coming back to it: it is made to be played wrong. One of the achievements is given for finding and defeating one of the endgame characters before you find anyone else, one of them is rewarded for fighting and beating the final boss without even picking up the most basic weapon, and one of them is for breaking the game sequence to the point that it is impossible to achieve 100% completion. I have had so much fun going back into the game and trying to break it, learning all of the secret tech, and trying to complete the incredibly over-sized map. This game is a lot of fun, and in the end, we got that VIVA YURI moment.

61369768.review:
I know what you're doing. You're looking at the art of this game, the costumes of the main characters, and the bad "cutesy" dialogue in the screenshots. You're thinking "wow this otaku-bait blows" without even watching the trailer all the way through. But hang on, I promise to god this game is good.  Please bear with me a few seconds.

I thought the same thing too, until I gameshared it off somebody close to me for an hour or more. What looked like a barebones excuse for fanservice with some popular clickbait genres attached ended up being one of the best metroidvanias I've ever played. Playing the game on "Hard: Alternative" difficulty is a great challenge with tons of bullet hell goodness, and I never feel like the game is cheating me- I can beat any boss if I grind the patterns enough and learn how to dodge them. The way you deal damage is unique and interesting too, with a combo system that increases your overall DPS if you switch weapons a lot and lay in tons of attacks without getting hit or stopping for too long. Each weapon has it's own use too, and while some are certainly better than others there is definitely a reason to use each one. 

As for the exploration aspect, the best comparison I can make for this game is "An Untitled Story" if you've ever played that. After the short prologue, you can basically go wherever you want and do whatever you want. I'm currently on chapter 2 and instead of doing the main story i'm going around and beating the crap out of hordes of optional bosses and adding them to my town. Each boss you beat also is able to buff you in various ways for a small bit of cash and gives you an overall increase in stats! And on top of this all, there are a near uncountable amount of secrets and collectables to find in each area. But don't fear the powercreep: every boss you beat "levels up" other bosses you haven't defeated yet, so the game is constantly engaging and doesn't get easy if you accidentally sequence break or explore too much.

The only main negative I have with this game is that there are a few invisible walls in the world. You can explore a staggering amount of places right from the getgo, but occasionally you'll run into a place where Rabi or Ribbon will go "Oh no, this looks too scary... let's turn around" and it feels cheap/stupid. Gating progression via a powerup would have been easily a good substitute, even if it allowed for sequence breaking. Being told I can't explore somewhere when I have freedom to go almost anywhere else just breaks my immersion and enjoyment.

But yeah seriously, get this game. I promise you it's good, just stick with it past the prologue.

57665006.review:
A great game in essentially everything but writing. Essentially, Rabi Ribi is a metroidvania-style exploratory action-platformer game, punctuated by in-depth and challenging boss fights, flavored with anime-style, cute, and at times sexy visuals. When playing a game like this, you aren't playing for the writing, so I'd recommend just skimming the dialogue and not thinking about it too critically, because it takes twice as long as it needs to explain everything it wants to. Long story short, you play as Erina, a rabbit owned by a woman named Rumi, and you've been magically turned into a bunnygirl. You meet a fairy named Ribbon who becomes your companion, and you reunite with Rumi. Between an explanation and information presented in the prologue, you discover that Rumi's sister, Miru, is off missing in a strange world. In order to get her back, you need to go around and recruit (have boss fights with) magic-users on the island the game takes place on, who will power up an artifact that teleports you to the strange world where Miru is, so that you can get her back. That is the main plot, and it's all right conceptually; it's just blandly and at times confusingly written.

Now, moving past that, every other aspect of this game is a true gem. The music ranges from light, spunky, and energetic, to serious, intense, and climactic, but I would at few points say it borders on "generic." The visuals are, again, very cute. The pixel art is extremely easy to read, and all the particle effects (and there are a lot of them, especially in the boss fights) will never leave you guessing as to where is safe and where is dangerous, but it pulls that off while looking pretty, too. The CGs (full-screen drawn art) is very competently drawn, and conveys a genuine style, not like a Western artist trying to *copy* an anime art style -- this is the real deal. These CGs are pretty cute, sexy, and generally pretty fun. I wouldn't say they go particularly far into fanservice, but maybe I'm a bit desensitized, so your mileage may vary if you dislike cute-sexy fanservice for some reason. The movement in this game is tight, and you have an impressive amount of control of your character at any given point. Your movement options are vast, courtesy of double-jumps, wall-jumps, aerial dashes, speedy ground-rolls, slides, slide-kicks, rising-tackles, divekicks, and more. It's a pleasure to play, and danmaku (bullet hell) fans will feel at home with a tiny hitbox much smaller than the pixel art itself that can bob and weave through flashy and hard-to-dodge patterns of attacks. Performance-wise, the game runs like a dream, too, and has great controller support, especially with how Steam handles controller input these days.

Besides the writing, I suppose the only criticism I could see reasonably levied against the game is that the RPG mechanics on offer are either lacking or missing entirely. Basically, you have an experience system for your hammer attacks, your fairy companion, and a carrot-bomb tool similar to Metroid morph ball bombs, and the experience you gain in these areas maxes out within twenty minutes of starting the game, making your attacks start slow and incomplete and climb up to full speed and full extensiveness within that time. In other words, the experience system is purely there as a tutorial, to get you used to Erina's moveset. I'm not saying this is a bad thing, either, just that there are people out there who go into this expecting the steady forward march of level-ups constantly improving the player's capabilities. Rabi-Ribi largely confines powerups to going out and exploring the world instead, with Erina combing the environment with her exploration tools and discovering a myriad of permanent buffs, badges, and tools to use, with a comparatively small number of similar items that can be bought from an in-game shop using a currency you absorb from defeating enemies. In short, it's far closer to Metroid than Castlevania on the metroidvania scale. Just thought that needed clearing up.

Beyond that, though, the game is a dream. Play on Hard for a real casual-filtering experience. I would say that's the "intended" difficulty for most people willing to challenge themselves. It's an extremely well-made game that rewards you appropriately for all the hard work you put in to beat it, and if you're one of those people who stubbornly believes cutesy anime games are all fluff and no substance, you owe it to yourself to prove yourself wrong in the best possible way with this game. Just stick with it for at least five hours, and don't be a baby about the stupidly silly writing, and you'll be good.

55620610.review:
I don't think I've ever seen a game try so hard to back itself into a niche and scare off potential players, but Rabi-Ribi is a solid game if you can get through all the weirdness. It really delivers well on its promise of being a metroidvania/bullet hell crossover, with the former being the format of the bulk of the game, and the latter used for boss fights. But the devs added some pretty strong Alienate the Audience dials, and turned Furry up to 5, Weeb up to 7, Cutesypoo up to 8, Girl on Girl (Romance) to 7 while leaving Girl on Girl (Action) at 0, Fanservice to 3, and both Achievement (Quantity) and Achievement (Completion Impossibility) up to 11. These individually may attract some players, but it's definitely an odd combination that, in whole or in part, will make a lot of potential buyers walk (or refund). I personally appreciate some of those points, and am not bothered by the rest, but do make sure you know what you're getting here. [B]You're playing as a literal bunny girl in an anime fairyland filled only with other animal girls who all have secret, unrequited crushes on each other and all the drama that goes along with that, in a game with hundreds of achievements, the majority of which only the most skilled and dedicated players can possibly earn.[/b] If any part of that sentence turns you off, best to move along.

Still here? Lucky you, because as mentioned this is a truly solid gameplay experience, and I really enjoyed it. On the metroidvania side you have a lot of freedom to explore as you will, which in turn means there will be a lot of wandering around, backtracking, and stumbling into boss fights you won't be ready for (though they all have save points right before, so this doesn't feel unfair); and the mechanics are unique enough to stand out, with both melee and (eventually) a choice of several ranged attacks and specials that hit the genre must-haves while adding a few unique features as well. Only the very beginning is linear, and there's very little hand holding, so you'll need to keep track of every obstacle you couldn't clear, and then cross-reference it against each new upgrade you find that may let you finally pass it. And I'll admit there's a couple of things I never did figure out how to reach, but nothing that prevented me from completing both the game and the post-game.

On the bullet hell side, the boss fights are insane, with a lot of complex, layered bullet patterns combined with aimed attacks. I can definitely see this being appropriately challenging for skilled bullet hell masters, but I just as definitely am not one. Fortunately, they added enough level-up health and healing item mechanics that players like me can facetank a lot of bullets before dying. Honestly, it feels like a lot of boss attacks are undodgeable, and come more frequently than the cooldown of your one move that gives immunity frames, but there must be a way, as at least a few people earn the "defeat boss X without taking damage" achievements. And the challenge level is really well done - on both the "normal end" boss and the "post-game end" boss I was able to defeat them without deliberate grinding, but did so only after clearing all the game areas accessible before the fight (so "natural grinding"?), taking multiple attempts, and finishing with less than 10% health and no more potions. But difficulty is adjustable, so you can find your own appropriate challenge level.

[Oh, and Protip - the game doesn't tell you this until literally the final stage of the final post-game end boss fight, but Erina's hitbox is tiny, possibly as small as a single pixel, and located in her chest. Meaning she can take bullets to her massive head or her legs without damage. This is critical to know when trying to dodge some of the bullet patterns that have gaps smaller than Erina herself.]

So if you want a non-linear metroidvania with fair but challenging boss fights and a robust post-game (even without DLC), Rabi-Ribi will deliver - so long as you're not too uptight to enjoy it!

54677112.review:
I can see why this game is highly regarded, and why a lot of people that buy it would enjoy it, but honestly I wouldn't recommend it. It has a lot of excellent things going for it, but I just intensely disagree with some of the core gameplay elements, and they resulted in it being more unfun than fun by the end. 

The main things that hurt it, to me, are the terrible scaling mechanics, and the insanely overlong boss fights. These kind of go hand in hand. The scaling is, I imagine, due to the open-ended emphasis of their exploration. However, it ultimately feels punishing - no matter which mode I selected, and no matter how much I scavenged up every possible power up, it never actually affected the fights because the fights all boil down to "dodge this bosses' 4-5 attacks for 10-15 minutes while chipping away at an immense health bar". The earlier fights are actually more fun, but the farther in the game you get the worse it becomes. 

To me, the overscaling makes it feel less like a metroidvania and more like an action-platformer that should have just had the RPG elements stripped out to simplify it. Since the stat powerups are largely meaningless, why have them at all? The ability powerups are (mostly) all fine and fun, and the level design is mostly great, albeit largely pointless because the exploring just gives you powerups which don't do anything. Even the actual boss fights are all well designed, they just start to overstay their welcome starting from hour 3 or 4. I kept playing because I kept expecting it to get back to where the fights were fun but it never did. 

There's a pretty fine line between 2D action games that fall into the side I like vs. the side I don't, despite the "metroidvania" trappings here it falls on the side I dislike, closer to games like Ghouls N' Goblins or the like. I'd recommend Touhou Luna Nights over this if you wanted a metroidvania-ish bullet-hell-boss-fight game, as it does basically ignore stat development entirely and focus just on keeping things streamlined, and is better for it. Rabi-Ribi isn't a bad game, but I think it's falls short from good due to the confused design. Somewhere in the 6/10 area, it's obviously higher if you really like long-ass repetitive boss fights (which some people do).

Note: I know the stat boosts don't actually do "nothing", but the game is designed to make it feel that way. I had checked a map to make sure I had every possible stat boost when I still had about 6 boss fights to go, and they all were just more of a grind and made you feel weaker than the very first handful of boss fights, which is the opposite of what you should feel when you spend hours digging around for upgrades and buffs. The payoff for getting through those last fights just was never there, the game never got fun again, and the story was so minimal at that point it would have been more fun to read the wiki.

54276149.review:
Been a while since I last played it but this is seriously my favorite platformer of all time, so I should leave a positive review :)

10/10 as a platformer, boss-fighting game. The best of it's kind. Accessible to casual gamers and hardcore platformers such as myself. 

Metroidvania aspect is okay, but not amazing. I came for the metroidvania and stayed for the boss fighting. 

If you hate all things anime, still give the game a shot. Just get over it and see the gem for the game that it is. Truely non-linear metroidvania game unlike most steam games tagged as metroidvania nowadays.

You have a small hitbox. Always a plus for platformer games.

If you love boss fights I would also HIGHLY RECOMMEND the DLCs, especially the recent one. All the bosses introduces in the newest DLC makes the last boss before the release of this DLC look like tutorial bosses. They're that good. Irisu and Miru have the more fun design imo.

Boss design in general is very good in this game that I hope becomes a standard for all platformer games...but that will never happen. Each boss in this game has MANY attacks. A mixture of memorization and reflexes is needed to dodge them. But a first playthrough of the game you'll be very surprised at how many attacks each boss has. There's never a dull moment. Most attacks are dodgeable even if you've never seen it before.

The only thing that I didn't like was that I couldn't start on the hardest difficulty from the getgo. I'm sure you can get a save file to bypass that but what I did was go through Hell mode (after hard mode) and beat the first main last boss to unlock the next difficulty and move on right away. You could simply do that twice from hard mode to hell mode to unlock bunny extinction - the hardest non-DLC difficulty. I think there are DLC difficulties higher but mostly artificial difficulty introducing harder hitting bosses that's about it. For maximum difficulty you should avoid fighting as many bosses as you can in lower difficulties while you unlock the higher ones.

I would recommend everyone to play to at least hard mode, though even then, I think the game is too easy at that level. On that difficulty you can literally face tank bosses doing max dps and still win because you take so little damage and you have food options that restore life. To me, that's not playing the game but just button mashing. On higher difficulties such as bunny extinction, you are forced to dodge or die.

The achievements are also fun to do. There are stuff like no items that's possible to do. This was one of the few games I cared to collect all the achievements because of how much I liked the game. Although I did get a bit bored and didn't collect the last few I missed plus with the information that more would be released going for 100% achievements before that happens would be silly.

The developer is making a spiritual successor to this game that I expect to be as good as this game or better. The bar is set high after this game, but I have high hopes.

53824117.review:
[h1] Where do I begin? [/h1]

I hated this game back when the game was released and did not enjoy the game initially. I thought the difficulty was too high at times. I failed to understand that while the game is marketed to your face to be a painful misery bullet hell metroidvania, it is also marketed to be one of the most 2D platformer player choices one can possibly have as well.

Want the game to be easy? The story is god tier and there's so many good things in the story and let me just gush right now and say that by far ribbon is one of my favorite characters and duo sidekicks I think ever made. Rabi-Ribi has Shantae level's of good story telling with a overwhelming amount of lovable characters! This game is just almost, almost... a masterpiece and a blast to play from start to finish!

[h1] My honest complaints however stem from my experience of playing the game today. [/h1]

* Rabi-Ribi starts off with one of the most cardinal sins in gaming, a painful movement speed slog for a surprisingly long time before obtaining an actual movement speed buff if you factor the main progression, through exploits and intentional sequence breaks, there's faster hidden mechanics and upgrades to reduce the slog to a mere five to ten minutes.

* Some unlocks require you to beat the game multiple times, other's however are far too strict, such as 200% and bunny hell. If you follow a guide, it won't take too much trouble and most play-through are quicker with speed run mode.
* Speaking of this Speedrun mode, in order to unlock it [spoiler] you must complete the ENTIRE game, one fake credit's sequence later and you are required into a second half of brand new missions and locations before facing an extremely hard final, final bossfight, [/spoiler] only afterwards can you get it.

* Attempting to perform any low% in this game is flat out terrible. I cannot fathom why anyone would enjoy doing this. It is simply a masochist category nobody should ever want to try beyond the normal difficulty, and if you do, I'd encourage trying one of the unlockable game modifiers, one in particular speeding up a certain character.

[h1] And what about the rest, what are the positives? [/h1]

*This speedrun mode, I don't even consider it as such. If anything I'd call it a "cut all the bullshit out" mode,  [spoiler] in this mode it skips an entire introduction sequence that is the game's tutorial and pre-prologue. You are encouraged to play this mode specifically through unlocking higher difficulty's and game difficulty modifiers, with even two additional progression systems! The former letting you play through the game normally, each new boss get stronger very slowly as the game goes on... The latter, is a lot different, you are able to face any boss early on before tackling stronger bosses, this time you can fight a majority of the bosses early on to save the pain train for late game progression, as you'd expect, only the bosses that can be fought early on are a breeze but the moment you are on the main path to beating the game, it throws down bosses at their max difficulty at all times, [/spoiler] it encourages either exploration or simply you wishing to suffer as fast as possible.

*Endless replayability, an entire active player base, a dedicated easy to access sort of randomizers with steam workshop mods, and yes, steam workshop mods. 

* The story could make a person cry.

* Every single DLC is worth it.

You won't be disappointed if you enjoy light hearted visual novels, platformers, and the fact that this is a very long game that could take you days to complete. And if you wanted more than rabi ribi or just want to skip this game and the dlc, maybe even save some money, look no further than it's sequel called TEVI.

53419145.review:
I saw Rabi-Ribi in my recommended games a while ago and noticed it had 97% positive ratings. Seeing the user reviews and how positive they were, I decided to buy the game. The story wasn't the most engaging; but the gameplay was phenomenal. 
Rabi-Ribi is an asymmetrical bullet-hell metroidvania. Asymmetrical meaning you can explore the world, progress the story, or just do anything the game has to offer in any order you want. There is no linear path, and this allows 0% runs of the game; ignoring everything but the story itself and getting no upgrades or items. 
Even if the anime girls aren't too appealing to you, don't let it take you away from the fantastic gameplay this game has to offer. Tons of bosses to fight/recruit, items to find, abilities to acquire, and upgrades to buy. On top of the 6 difficulty levels, there are DLCs that add more quests and areas to explore. This is not an easy game, but it is a lot of fun to play.

53416155.review:
This game easily makes the list of my favorite games of all time. If you like difficult games, this game can fill that purpose. If you like to jump around and explore, well by golly, this game sure has that. The game is difficult (very much so, i have trouble on novice) and if you aren't into that, then you can set the difficulty lower and have a wonderful time! There's plenty here to explore: Caves, Mountains, Deserts, etc. You can do things in basically whatever order you want, so much so that if you do it right, you can beat the game without collecting any items, as weird as it sounds (that was a nightmare though). The Characters are all lovable and unique, the music is the most godly music to ever have blessed our puny mortal ears, and, with the recent workshop support, you can play levels made by other people, or run around as freakin' sonic the hedgehog. All in all a wonderful experiance and has lasted me for hours upon hours of pure fun.

TL;DR if you love great games and cute bunny girls, this game is for you! 

P.S.: Saya is best girl

Started out this game without too much previous experience in metroidvania/bullet hell, but I still finished it (though on an easier difficulty) and came up with pros and cons:

PROS:
- I noticed after finishing the game fully that even if you play on an easier difficulty the game still can be challenging at a handful of times and it's nearly impossible not to get better at the game

- The soundtrack was amazing and in my opinion some of the scores helped with comedic portions of the story

- The DLC was fun and short and added new bosses/special bosses

- The controls and movement in general took a bit to get used to but overall was very fluid

CONS:
- After finishing [spoiler]Windy Ravine[/spoiler] you can't go back to the area again [spoiler]unless you fight Irisu again[/spoiler]

- Throughout the story I had a very vague idea on what was going on and didn't really fully understand until the end

Overall, I found this game very enjoyable and would definitely recommend it for people trying to get into the genre, finding the items weren't very tedious, and each boss was very unique

51655284.review: Despite what my lack of hours would suggest, I absolutely love this game. The visuals are an amazing take on old, 8- or 16-bit style, the gameplay is smooth and feels good (even for someone who'd never played a bullet hell prior to this one), and, as just hinted at, combines multiple different genres; it's a platformer, bullet hell, and has some RPG-esque elements; imagine Touhou meets any of the Mario RPGs, except the enemy system is more akin to a New Super Mario Bros.: the enemies exist in the world itself, and boss battles happen in secluded or blocked off areas. It's a really nice system that works very well for the game. The dialogue is well-done, and the characters are very likeable. [b]And that isn't even mentioning the soundtrack.[/b] The music made by 3R2, Laozi, Triodust, MWT., and the Rabi-Ribi team fits PERFECTLY within their world, and they are all audible delights that compliment the visual style very well. I adamantly recommend this game. It's just great.

51398660.review:
I don't really have much to say because others already reviewed the game really well. So I'll try to summarize.

This game is a huge metroidvania with a ton of items to collect and a ton of bosses to fight. The objective of the game is to go around the island recruiting bosses by defeating them, if you want the best ending you need to recruit them all.
The game somehow managed to put bullet hell elements into the game really well, it's not uncommon for enemies to shoot simple bullet hell patterns at you and for bosses to use complex ones instead.
Bosses are really long. Most last about a minute, but the true final boss (DLC not included) is 15 minutes long with no checkpoints. (DLC bosses are actually either shorter or have checkpoints)
The game has "advanced techniques" which can let you beat the game without any items (Although in the second half of the game it becomes clear that 0% was an afterthought when designing that second half), or to get several items earlier than intended.
The game is VERY accessible, as it has 6 difficulties, from Casual that is easy enough to be anyone's first videogame ever to Bunny Extinction that will challenge even super skilled gamers.
My only complaint is the non-DLC true final boss. I already mentioned she's long and has no checkpoints, but she also has some really annoying and/or badly designed attacks that just made me wish it was over already. If you beat her, and want more after that, then please buy "Is the order a DLC?" for a MUCH better final impression.

Wow, and I thought I didn't have much to say.

51095867.review:
With selectable difficulties, plenty of unique bosses, loads of items to collect, secrets to discover, and sequences to break, this metroidvania/bullet hell game has something for any fan of the genre. 

There's plenty of achievements to get, most of which offer hints on new ways to play the game, like fighting a certain boss first, or beating the game without getting any items! If you're looking for a casual game to play, or a challenge, the difficulties will definetly suit almost any skill level. 

The game's soundtrack is really neat and the locales are varied, and two tracking percentages will tell you if there's more to explore: some of these hidden areas are really neat and really push the envelope, like two certain objects above a certain warp stone.

Boss battles mostly boil down to dodging bullet patterns and then moving in, but depending on your difficulty, this can be much easier said than done...or a cakewalk, if you want it to be. Some are more frustrating than others (I'm looking at you, #24!), but most of them end with a sense of accomplishment after defeating them.

Unfortunately, all games have their faults. The dialogue isn't the best, and the character's personalities are pretty generic. Standard enemies are also pretty lame, and certain parts of the game are just much more difficult than the rest of the areas. On the flip side of the hidden areas, some are just so out of the way, that I'm pretty sure you'll need a guide to find them. Oh, and some of the magic types you get just feel useless.

TL:DR PROS:
Selectable difficulties make the game easier or harder
Unique boss fights that rarely re-use mechanics or patterns
Fun combat and traversal
Collectable items ftw
Non-linear to the extreme
Music
Neat hidden secret areas 

TL:DR CONS:
Meh dialogue
Generic personalities
Lame standard enemies
Difficulty spikes, especially on harder difficulties

So yeah, if you like the sound of this game, give it a try. It's a game I've played three times over now, and it was still fun each run.
Side note: All of the characters in the game follow one simple rule...no pants.

50719374.review:
This is a Taiwanese metroidvania with bullet hell bosses and a visual novel like story, full of fanservice and clearly inspired by Touhou.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- The game world is almost as big as [url=store.steampowered.com/app/367520]Hollow Knight[/url] which is a rare feat in a metroidvania. There are over 20 different biomes each with their own bosses and often some kind of gimmicks, e.g. underwater movement, strong winds, low lighting, slippery ice etc. It's also very non-linear, you can pretty much go anywhere right from the start, the plot revolves around finding all the girls (basically beating them) and you can do this in any order.
- The combat/movement system is quite complex. You have a ranged attack that can be charged a la Mega Man and infused with a selection of elemental crystals and then you also have a melee attack that can be used to string combos. You can slide, dash and roll, double jump and wall jump. Moreover, you can set bombs and charge up powerful fullscreen attacks.
- The game doesn't waste your time with pointless backtracking. The protagonist moves very fast (and even more so after getting all the speed upgrades) and there are warp points basically everywhere. Revisiting prior areas for collectibles doesn't feel like a chore.
- Catchy soundtrack. Just listen to [url=youtube.com/watch?v=lFEsfCM_dXw]this[/url] or [url=youtube.com/watch?v=Nr84s_mxtNA]this[/url].

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- The story might be cute in the original Chinese, but the translation reads like bottom of the barrel anime schlock fansubbed by high school kids. Typos galore, characters constantly speaking in third person and calling each other "master", you'll be rolling your eyes quite a bit. Not to mention that the whole premise of a bunch of magical girls living on a magical tropical island with not a single dude in sight already takes some suspension of disbelief.
- Dodging bullet hell patterns during boss fights is a fun thing to do, but not for 15 minutes. The bosses are such health sponges it gets quite ridiculous especially towards the end of the game. There's one boss with 5 massive health bars that will take you quite a while to grind down. The game suggests you grind and stock up on consumables. Or drop the difficulty down to casual so you just sit through it in complete boredom. No middle ground.
- Bad difficulty curve. Most of the game is pretty easy to do on normal, but the later chapters (past the credits roll) do a crazy jump in difficulty. There's a long platforming section filled with lasers in every room that take off a good chunk of your health and require split second timing to dodge. Not to mention the massive HP creep on new bosses.
- While the VN segments are drawn well, the actual game is quite ugly. Very low effort pixel art. Backgrounds are badly stitched stock images with visible seams. Not to mention that 90% of enemies AND bosses are all variations of the same bunny girl sprite. It becomes an eyesore after a while.

Ultimately, the game felt quite hollow to me. It doesn't break any new ground and it's by no means terrible either. Just really mediocre. Kids like it because scantily clad anime girls and lots of stuff to grind? I don't know. It's an acceptable time waster if you have nothing to do, but I'd still suggest looking for your fix elsewhere. [url=store.steampowered.com/app/367520]Hollow Knight[/url], [url=store.steampowered.com/app/428550]Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight[/url], [url=store.steampowered.com/app/345820]Shantae and the Pirate's Curse[/url] and [url=store.steampowered.com/app/250760]Shovel Knight[/url] are all much better options.

49331258.review:
TLDR: I purchased this game based solely on my love for metroidvania type games, and all those glowing reviews. If you like the idea of chibi girls + a pinch of sadist Super Mario Maker levels then go for it. If you're more interested in something that's like Metroid or Symphony of the Night, then you're probably better off skipping Rabi-Ribi.

"Hey I drew a bunch of cute anime girls. Wanna make a game and put them in it?" 
"What's their personality like?" 
"Well, they're just... cute" 
"Works for me!"

Pros: 
Great Music
Challenging Boss Fights 
Nice Character Artwork

Cons:
Poor Sound Effects
Strange, Seemingly Pointless Storyline
Early Level Design vs Boss Fights = Mixed Signals
Repetitive Boss Design
Instant Death (final boss only)
Lack of Character Depth

Was there ever a point when you were playing a game with a boss fight that easily takes several minutes to do, and then there's several points where getting hit meant instant death? Well that's in this game. It's just the final boss, but it's nonetheless annoying. You can tell the devs put a lot of time into this game, but there's moments toward the end where you feel like they invited one of those guys that makes impossible Super Mario Maker levels to design some of the spike pit areas. I'm not joking. 

There's this amulet you get early on that allows you a brief moment of invulnerability when you use it. I didn't figure out how to use it until reaching the last level of the game. I pretty much had to figure it out, because the spikes here are almost as deadly as they are in Super Mario. That's another thing. The spikes seem to deal a consistent 60% damage to your health. In a game where you're finding extra health, having to heal up can make those extra health pickups feel like more of a punishment! Games with RPG elements should NOT include damage scaling! 

The thing that really bothers me about this game, is the artistic styling and level design will often make you think you're playing something simple like a Super Mario game. You know, something a little kid could play. Then you get to the bosses and the difficulty goes up significantly. Speaking of the boss fights, they're all very similar. You just dodge a lot of lasers and light balls, and then you hit the enemy with everything you have, and then you repeat. There's no real strategy involved. The most you're challenged to do is time your jumps carefully while dodging a bunch of lasers, stars, bombs, and lights. 

I also want to add that none of the characters are really memorable. I like the little fairy, and a lot of the character designs are pretty cute. Just don't ask me to tell you their names or what their personalities are like. Very few of them actually stand out. I could tell you there's an egyptian girl, 2 bear sisters, 2 cat sisters, 2 scientist sisters, 3 fairies, "master", a succubus, a water singer, a plant girl, and several others. They could have all just as easily been one character. Actually that might have worked out better because then there would actually be some character development. 

I don't mind losing to a boss several times simply because I'm not good enough, and get hit too many times to stay alive. I DO mind losing to a boss fight simply because they used instant death on me. It's not a mechanic I appreciate in any RPG or adventure game. There's a lot of players who love this type of gameplay, and kudos to them for wanting to deal with it. If you don't like boss fights with instant death powers then I suggest making a pass on this one. I mean, it WORKS in some games, but only those where the boss takes like 3 hits to kill. It just doesn't work in a game where  said boss has 100K+ hit points (I'm not kidding). With that said, you CAN do some research and find out how to avoid the instant death debuff (as Remin has noted in their reply to my review). But really, up until you get to the Library it's very likely that you won't do any research, look at the info in the menu, and possibly not even use the amulet. 

If you're still interested in giving it a try, I would suggest waiting until it's at least half off. $10 or less isn't bad. I have completed the game since my initial review, but due to the flaws mentioned I just can not recommend it at any price above $10. As it is I would go neutral (neither recommend nor condemn it), but that's not how Steam works.

49290257.review: Excellent bullet hell metroidvania. [b][i]Review copy provided by publisher[/i][/b]

Style can have a huge impact on a game, and it’s not even a matter of having a good one. Not everyone is going to agree on what styles are good, or even which style best matches a particular game. I doubt folks are going to agree on Rabi-Ribi’s style, for example, because not everyone is looking for a bunch of boobs in their face while they explore a sprawling metroidvania. But it turns out that for even the most disinclined players, it’ll be worth pushing past the spectacle to see just how deep this rabbit hole of gameplay and adventuring goes.

Erina is a bunny, like literally a fluffy, cotton-tailed rabbit, until she awakens in a mysterious world as a full-figured woman. Lost without her owner, she ventures forth into a land full of strange new sights (even for a transformed bunny girl). She meets tiny fairies, including a rambunctious one named Ribbon who joins her quest, as well as mad scientist girls, catgirls, immortal demigod girls, and weird bunny-obsessed girls who will try to magic you to death. Through all of this chaos your sights are on getting Erina and her owner back to the world they know, but it’s going to take a lot of friends and a lot of fighting, especially when the dark cracks around reality begin to show.

So obviously this game has a specific audience, if the busty animal girls and fairies that wear nothing but ribbons didn’t give it away. It’s not all mindless, mind you, as the dialogue is at times very playful with the art tropes and there are even some rather poignant creeper photographer enemies later in the game. But they’re still tropes, and unless you’re the target audience for it it’s not going to do anything for you or the story. By the same token, it’s not the point of the game, so if you’re okay with beating bikini-clad princesses down with a clueless Playboy bunny you should be able to enjoy the rest of the bright, charming presentation.

Beyond the boobs (if such a place even exists), Rabi-Ribi is quite the sprawling metroidvania. The first hour or so leads you around with gating, objective markers, and lots of cutscenes to get you properly introduced to the world and its inhabitants. Once you’re set up with your allies, the game proceeds in a chapter structure where you go out and find new friends to invite back to your burgeoning little town (by beating them up, obviously) until you have enough to open a portal to a boss or something more sinister. The story is shot through all of this, stopping you periodically for dialogues between Erina and Ribbon or interjections from your friends, and if you’re not in the mood for reading it can honestly get to be a bit much.

When you do have control of Erina, you have a good spread of powers and unique attacks to use. Her favored implement of destruction is the squeaky hammer, which she will unlock new moves and combos for as she uses it. That’s true of all her abilities and Ribbon’s attacks, they’ll level up and gain new capabilities through use. Erina’s hammer uses fast-charging stamina to swing so you’ll need to actually time your attacks, and Ribbon’s ranged magic costs MP which limits how much you can spam it. Most enemies aren’t very challenging though, leaving you plenty of time to explore the vast world and search for upgrades and secrets.

The bosses are where most of the challenge lies, and they’re a definite highlight of the game. Erina doesn’t have much luck making friends most of the time, so the other animal ladies you run into will want to throw down before buddying up. These fights are very much bullet hell showdowns, with all kinds of attack patterns and beams and gimmicks to deal with. Thematically they’re very much in line with the girl using them, like the scientist throwing vials of chemicals and blasting you with lasers and the Egyptian princess attacking with her staff and sliding walls. Erina’s hitbox is actually tiny and you’ll need to learn that to survive, because attacks can come pretty fast and dense as you whittle down their substantial health bars. They’re thrilling fights, though, enough so to be a major driver that keeps me moving through the game.

There’s a lot more to the game than that, which is what really sets it apart from other metroidvanias. The main adventure can take upwards of eight hours, with dozens of friends to haul back to town before buttoning up the plot. Town inhabitants also offer you temporary buffs and passive upgrades, and you earn a special ranking with each depending on your performance in the fight against them. You can buy stat and ability upgrades in town, and find others in the wild, and also unlock badges that can be equipped for additional bonuses like those in Hollow Knight (I know this came first, it’s just for reference). And if somehow you need even more bunny girls in your life, there are multiple gameplay modes and difficulties to explore, and a whole library of DLC.

Look, if you like platformers and anime girls, you’re all set here. The gameplay is solid and robust, and I’m not even going to make the adjoining joke about the characters. I can totally see the art style being a hangup for some, but there’s nothing objectionable in the game beyond appearances. The sound design is less exciting with pretty weak effects and that overly-peppy music you get in a lot of cutesy Japanese games. Aside from the presentation, though, you’ve got a metroidvania of impressive scope here. Rabi-Ribi is big on action and exploration, which should be enough no matter how you might feel about the style.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!

48584893.review:
Ah... how do you start a review for this game? I guess I'll just go with "yes."

I found this game from Christ-Centered Gamer. Long story involving match-3 games, don't wanna talk about it. It forced its way onto my wishlist, but I didn't end up buying it until the Winter Sale in 2018. I bought the Super UPRPRC Edition, which includes everything except the free Halloween DLC. (Would recommend, by the way; the Digital Artbook is much more than the PDF file I was expecting, the Original Soundtrack is just heavenly, and you really can't have the full experience without "Is the order a DLC?")

The instant I started up the game, I realized that I was getting much, much more than I paid for.

This game is the gift that keeps on giving. The description doesn't do anything in the game justice. This is one of [i]those games.[/i] You know the kind: one of those little indie games where you go in and realize that the developers poured their hearts and souls into every little detail. One where you wonder why all games can't be like this. One where you understand the passion and joy that the developers felt as they crafted a masterpiece.

The gameplay, of course, is the first point. Everything is fantastic, and the game feels amazing to control. It's a Metroidvania at heart: you go around, find some items, fight a boss, find more items, use those items to find even more items, find a new area, find more items, go back to the old area... it has a good amount of backtracking, but of course, the developers didn't make you suffer through all of it. There's the convenient Warp Stones to get you from area to area, and getting every single thing isn't a big deal in the standard mode. Half of the game is bullet hell, and the enemies and bosses all use pretty tough patterns. It's something that you can get down once you memorize it, so even if you don't have the upgrades, you can eventually pull it off. It's a very satisfying feeling.

The graphics are mostly pixel art, and it's very pastel-like. Colors are light, sprites are cute, and everything about the game just has that happy tone to it. The environments are all very unique and detailed, and it's fun to even just walk around and look at enemies, backgrounds, Erina and Ribbon, and everything else. Portraits have a more traditional style, and they're all very nice. They look fairly anime-like, but with a certain unique touch that makes them recognizable if you know the game.

The music is really great. It always fits its environment pretty well, whether it's a peaceful forest, a tense fight, or an unknown location. Buying the Original Soundtrack gives you access to all the files, as well as a fully unlocked sound test. I've spent a long, long time just listening to the music, and it made a lot of the harder parts of the game more enjoyable and less annoying.

The plot is a good mix of casual humor and serious development. It's a bit confusing, but it has a few twists that really keep the story moving and make you want to find out what happens next. It may not be the greatest story, but it really works well for the game, and I, for one, adore it. It really made me feel emotion, and that's a plus in my book.

There is honestly too much to the game to cover in a review. There's New Game +, multiple difficulties, fantastic characters, speedrun mode, a multitude of achievements (many of which are based around sequence breaking), minigames, special abilities for Erina and Ribbon, the DLC content, [spoiler]how much I love Irisu and Noah in particular,[/spoiler] and way more. It just never ends. I've only cleared my first playthrough at the time of writing this, and I'm working on 100% clearing it before moving on to New Game + and possibly higher difficulties. Even though I've beaten it before, I just want to keep playing, because I know the developers of this game loved it just as much as I do.

I bought this game for anime bunny girls, and I got a masterpiece I'll never forget or get tired of.

47903503.review:
Okay, let me explain ONE aspect of this game properly: the (boss) fighting. Rabi Ribi has the deepest and most balanced and simply best fighting compared to any game I know. Bosses aren't all about dodging attacks, but also executing your own attacks and using situational moves well.

The following may look overly complex, but all these moves are gained gradually when progressing through the game, so you have time to practice each of them and add them to your fighting bit by bit. It's just really deep, varied and satisfying fighting with pretty much infinite skill cap (which is why the game has so many additional ridiculously hard difficulties).

Basic balance of a boss fight: You have basic hammer combo that stuns the boss if you catch it in it (some bosses jump around like crazy). However, after a combo, the boss gets into a hyperarmor mode where they take less damage and won't be stunned for a few seconds. You CAN keep attacking if you have stamina or other available moves, but you have to watch out for the boss attacks, so bruteforcing is not usually effective. When the boss has around 25% health left, they go in a longer hyperarmor mode and unleash their more difficult "spellcard" attacks, you can either survive through them and/or do damage while dodging the moves to kill them before it ends. Boss moves usually consist of bullet hell patterns, simple but quick attacks that you need to react quickly (sometimes in a specific way), and some bosses jump around in tricky ways, doing melee damage if they hit you, and being difficult to catch in a combo.

You have a charged magic attack (hold to charge and release to shoot), which you can use at range while dodging boss attacks (later you also get a melee projectile attack which you can use simultaneously for quite good DPS, though it gets difficult). You can also use it simultaneously while melee comboing. With magic you also have different projectile types, though the biggest differences between magic wands lies in its boost magic attack that can provide for example extra AoE damage over time, give attack and armor buff for a duration. Boost magic attack has long cooldown (charges by magic attack hits).

Then you have 2 powerful extra attacks with a cooldown to add between basic melee combos situationally: 1. Super Carrot: You have to channel for about a second without taking damage (risky), after which you do a powerful AoE blast, which also grants invincibility for tiny duration, but you take more damage if interrupted. Also does damage upwards, to be used when a boss is floating above you. Very rewarding if you can anticipate a difficult bullet wave or find a spot in easier one and IMO adds a lot of depth to the fights. 2. Bunny Strike, which is simply a powerful dashing attack. Seeing all the situations where you can utilize these attacks is key to dealing more damage.

Then you have Bunny Amulet, which is kind of like a bomb in a bullet hell game (invincibility), though quite brief and doesn't clear bullets. It does a little bit of AoE damage and resets the cooldowns of Super Carrot and Bunny Strike, though it should basically never be wasted as a damage source.

Other moves: You get a sideways air dash (useful in some patterns or moving quickly), and a ground slide for dodging bullets around your height. Double jump (basic stuff). Quick downward descent for some fast zigzag dodging. Wall jump (mostly for exploring). You have a upwards and downwards hammer attacks that you can do some extra damage as a follow-up for basic hammer combo if you have extra stamina.

Here's a video of one of my favourite mid-game bosses (on Hell difficulty), the player here seems to have many late-game abilities, but the bosses scale accordingly. No super carrot usage here, since this boss is so fast (it's slower on lower difficulties). You could even watch it at half speed to better see what's happening: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D_Ao98Awv

watch?v=D_Ao98AwvUQ (if not working)

47837451.review:
I'm absolutely in love with this game. I've had this on my wishlist for a pretty long time and I've always eyed on it whenever big sales cropped up. At long last, Christmas 2018 and this game was gifted to me by a friend! And lemme tell you, that time was worth it.

There's so many things I want to talk about with this game, but I'll start from the most fundamental part - the gameplay. It's just fantastic. It's a metroidvania platformer mixed with a bullethell game. And it's so good at being just a great game. The controls are super good - they are responsive, accurate and satisfying in every sense of the word. While at the start of the game you may be limited in terms of movement options, by the time you hit the late-game - you'll basically be going anywhere you want, whenever you want. It's that kind of gratifying feeling that makes exploration in a game like this really fun. Thanks to this, backtracking to previously completed stages never feels like a necessity or a drag because the game properly rewards you with new areas to explore alongside with new items to gain, new enemies to fight and even new characters to discover. It's never over until the game says it's over. And even then it's probably still not over.

On top of the solid controls, the combat is also very satisfying. While invincibility frames & slight knockback can be a minor annoyance, nothing in this game felt cheap. The game gives you a fair chance but also requires some degree of precision to dodge if you don't want to constantly lose health. Although this being heavily inspired by bullethell shooters, especially during boss battles, visibility can sometimes be a problem, as stuff tends to blend in with the background or with each other even and it may feel like you get hit by something you didn't see. But if you do pay attention while the boss is attacking then it's absolutely not a problem.

The story is a bit weird. Overall I did like it, but I didn't like the inconsistencies between the main game and the post game. I'm not gonna spoil anything here, but you may notice narrative inconsistencies from time to time. Besides that, the story doesn't try too hard to take itself seriously and that's for the better - you're a bunny girl running around with a fairy and a giant hammer. If this game tried to be ridiculously serious with its narrative then I'd find that pretty jarring for a game of this nature. Aside from that though, there were a few nitpicky quirks with the story, such as a couple of spelling mistakes that made themselves pretty obvious. While I never really outright laughed at this game's comedy, it never bored me and always kept me engaged, which is a good thing since that means it doesn't get very repetitive. Although some of the achievements in this game definitely are funny, I liked the sense of humor of the achievements, especially some of the references.

The soundtrack is just on another level for me. Well done by all the composers of the soundtrack, especially 3R2 with amazing tracks such as cyberspace.exe, Get On With It, Bounce Bounce and more. I also really liked songs like the Volcanic Caverns theme and Exotic Laboratory theme. But as stated - every song in the game is just incredible. It's rare for me to say that I didn't dislike any of the songs. I'll probably end up buying the game's soundtrack on Steam for listening outside of the game.

Although one thing I will mention about the game that I feel is a bit of a negative is that the boss battles can feel a bit repetitive. Almost always you'll be placed in a wide open area with the boss you're fighting and it's really just a case of "dodge, attack, wait, repeat". Not a lot of the bosses in the game felt like they really challenged your skill otherwise. I do understand why they designed it like this - so speedrunning the game didn't feel like certain items were crucial in order to progress but because of that, the final result ended up with some repetitive boss battles. The best battle in the game was the main game's final boss because it was the closest thing in the game that ended up being even a little bit mechanically challenging for the player. A close second would be the boss battle in Natural Aquarium due to the higher jump that you get from being underwater, allowing for some flashy combos to be made.

There is still an entire OCEAN of content I haven't covered - badges, the item shop & how simple its integration is, new game+, speedrun mode, boss rush, etc. but that should be a testament to just how much stuff there is in the game. Overall it's a really solid metroidvania bullethell platformer. If you're at all on-the-fence about this game, just get it. It's absolutely worth it and I loved every second of it. In fact, I'll probably give this game repeat visits just to see how much stuff I missed.

46438729.review:
It's pretty hard to make an innovative bullet-hell game. You usually get top-down shooters. Some games add rpg elements and turn out pretty awesome but this is the first game that imo succeeds in merging bullet-hell with a platformer. Now, there have been attempts of doing this before but usually the movement (momentum, gravity, ...) either limit the bullet pattern complexity or the difficulty balance.

Not this game. The way the character hitbox differentiates between getting hit by a bullet or by an enemy attack directly along with slower movement while charging make for a really great control scheme that allowed the devs to make some really awesome battles with complex patterns without skimping on anything.

Aside the very fun gameplay you get a plethora of difficulty settings (and they can be difficult), an amazing open world castlevania style, tons of easter eggs and achievements to obtain and even (more or less intended?) sequence breaks and secret challenge modes. A few items offer gameplay customization and there's also a story or something. 

Also the music. It slows down when underwater. In real time. There's so many small touches that make for such a great experience. Best game.

45537249.review:
At the time of the Kickstarter, the developer created Rabi-Ribi because there was no game where the bunny girl was the hero. This simple yet funny reason is the background behind the birth of Rabi-Ribi, which has overwhelmingly positive reviews in its current Steam evaluation.

Rabi-Ribi is a 2D Action Platformer / Bullet Hell Game developed by CreSpirit & GemaYue and published by Sekai Project. The main character Erina was originally a rabbit, but suddenly became a female human in a bunny costume. At the same time, mysterious problems arose in the village of Rabi-Ribi. In addition, Erina's master Miru is also missing. The main storyline of this game is to venture out to find your master. In this adventure you will also meet another playable character named Ribbon who is a fairy.

The main feature of this game is that it's a 2D side-scrolling / RPG shooting game based on the Metroidvania playstyle. In addition, some of Rabi-Ribi's gameplay seems to be inspired by the Touhou Project games. Despite this, the originality of Rabi-Ribi itself is always fully present. 

In this game you can get stronger by using game money that you receive from defeating your enemies. Since there are some grinding elements, players can enjoy this game without getting bored. Moreover, through its unique combat system and numerous boss battles, players will become more immersed in the game.

This game is a user-friendly game that considers the player above all else. A variety of difficulty levels are available and the tutorial allows players to learn the game easily. But it is ultimately a game that will be difficult to master. And even though the game was released in 2016, it's still a great game with new content updates. So if you haven't played Rabi-Ribi yet, you're definitely missing out. It's a game that will be well worth your time.

If you're anything like me, you saw this game and you thought something like, "Oh great, it's bad enough when my friends catch me playing Nights of Azure, I don't need another game like this."  

What you thought was wrong.  You DO need this game.

This game is an absolute blast, one of the greatest Metroidvanias/platformers I've ever played.  Just about every aspect of this game (most notably, to my mind, the music, which is just phenomenal) is brilliantly, lovingly done.  

There's a longstanding tradition of using absurdly drawn female characters in video games (and in lots of other places) to appeal to dudes like me, and I wish we could hurry up and get past it already - it's the 21st century, and while it's a simple fact of life that sex sells, we can and should hold ourselves to a better standard when it comes to this stuff.  That said, I don't think all that should stop you from enjoying this game.  

9/10

43367581.review:
A game of many flaws that still has seduced most of us. Why is that? Is it because weebs™ like this? Not really, take a look at the reviews and they'll all say the same thing, terrible story, amazing gameplay. And i can attest to that. The gameplay completely overshadows all the honest mistakes.

Let's start with the pros.

The art is pleasant to look at, the character design is cute (it's one of those girl-only game), and the CG and pixel art both fit into the game. There's a few risqué scenes but nothing that goes too far, and overall the fanservice, while present, is scarce and not a bother. It won't be thrown in your face every minutes if you can bear with it. If you are into that, which is fine, then it'll further enhance the experience for you.

The music is pleasant and catchy, perhaps a bit lacking in variety, but not to a bothersome extent. Overall the game goes for an uplifting, upbeat and innocent artistic direction, you'll notice it fast. (Which makes the parts where the game takes itself seriously with the story all the more painful rather than engaging, the story would be better and more fitting if it stayed on a silly tone all the way through)

Now let's go over the best parts. The map is quite big, there is many shortcuts, intersections, and the metroidvania elements are good enough to be praised, though i wish the game had a better pace for the abilities that you get pretty much either in the same place at short intervals, or in completely random places you might visit too early or too late.

The game can be 100% non linear, and you're able to break most if not all the sequences of the game through hidden means, which is probably a plus for speedrunners. There is many achievements tailored for every kind of players and routes. If you take the intended path, the beggining will have a bit too many dialogues, and will restrict your freedom until you reach the town, but after this, you're on your own. You won't be lost however, as the game gives you a clear indication of where to go to progress the main quest.

There is a good ammount of upgrades you can find so if you enjoy RPG elements, this can be pretty satisfying, although you're in no way forced to go through with it to beat the game

Last but not least, the boss fights. This is where the game shines. This is where you hit gold. Where you can clearly see the devs designed this to be amazing. You'll be able to take down bosses through many means, ranged attacks, a melee combo, strong magic attacks, a few hidden tricks, fancy movement abilities that double down as damaging abilities, waiting for an opportunity to strike them or slowly chipping at their health while they throw at you every once in a while bullet hell patterns that are very fun to dodge. The game isn't spammy or overly speedy, it's methodical, and puts focus on smart dodging skills and positioning. There is a crazy variety in patterns, and new bosses are always interesting to try out and learn what they have in store for you. A few attacks may feel unfair, but you can always learn how to handle them consistently, and if you have trouble with some attacks, the game gives you an invincibility frame "spell" on a rather low cooldown. Every boss can be done no-hit, consistently, without the spell i previously mentioned, which is good design.

You can fine tune the difficulty to your liking, to have either an extremely casual experience, an average difficulty where you'll be challenged without frustration but nothing too easy, or crank it up to the max and get your buttocks whooped to the point where soulsborn styled games, old retro games, and other games with hardcore fighting challenges will look easy. Though you need to play through the game twice or so to unlock the last difficulty. The game also has a new game+ feature allowing you to keep your item progress while replaying through the game with everything hitting harder, having more health, being faster, and so on... up to a few hundreds of times. It's fair to say you have an infinite replayability as long as you enjoy fighting the bosses.

The content is huge, boss wise especially. And, at its core, the game is a glorified boss rush, if you're into that, chances are you won't regret buying it. I didn't. There is a quick reload feature and escape key will skip an entire set of dialogues if you don't want to bother with them, making coming back into a fight quite fast.

I'll also mention the controls felt tight and responsive, no issues here. Your hitbox is very generous, thus getting hit doesn't feel unfair. The game has a few bugs here and there, but most if not all of them won't break the game or pose a problem. You're a bit sluggish at the beggining but that's quickly solved. Overall playing Rabi-Ribi feels good. I can't put it into word, and feel like i'm underselling it.

And finally, the cons.

The story is just there at best, annoying at worst. It is confusing, aimless, and possibly one of the worst i've seen, much like the bland dialogue that is laughably bad. It's just generic trying-to-be-cute anime lines recycled over and over, which does nothing to add to the characters' personality or story and make you roll your eyes (eg: insert protagonist saying "Miss [animal or nickname]!" with the other girl correcting her "i'm not an X, i'm an Y, how dare you, let's fight"... times the ammount of characters in the game. That, or the other way around). It's just mindless small talk aswell as peptalk for the majority of the dialogues, and there's way too many of them.

Do your best to ignore it, the gameplay is worth the trouble, 100%. And if you somehow enjoy it, good for you!

I do have a critique for the overworld aswell. Although i did enjoy the secret hunting (this game has a loooot of it), the overworld felt bland and generic, at times becoming a chore to get through the enemies. The few platforming sections felt weird and overly punishing, although they aren't bad, they are thrown in out of nowhere at maximum difficulty, forcing you to adapt to the sudden jump in the difficulty curve and making use of advanced platforming technique you didn't get the time to practice. The hitboxes are a bit unforgiving, and the movement requires precision, but it's not technically flawed, at least. It's even clever for some parts, just not properly introduced.

Get this game if:

- You like extremely fun and satisfying boss fights with bullet hell elements, with quite a decent ammount of diversity in how to approach them.

- You like hidden secrets and achievement hunting.

- You like games that give you a decent ammount of freedom to explore and enjoy challenging yourself (You can disable upgrades you don't like)

- You like cute anime girls, yeah, the game has that, what can i say?

- You like a selection of difficulties that go from yawn inducing to harder than any game you've ever played

- A lot of potential replayability

- Speedrunner friendly

- Want the rewarding feeling of beating a difficult boss after many tries

DON'T get this game if:

- You expect a visual masterpiece or a narrative on par with the best novels, recounting amazing, engaging stories

- If you can't ignore the above even though you can essentially skip all of it in a second

This game is great, especially for a metroidvania and bullet hell fan like me. You can tell the dev isn't the most experienced programmer or novelist ever, but still made this with a lot of passion and hard work. They also communicate with their community. A purchase that was worth all the money i spent on it.

Sidenote: "Is the order a DLC?" DLC is ridiculously hard, adding some spammy bosses that will clog the screen with bullets, and some extreme platforming. Only buy it if you're up to the challenge.

"Artbook" DLC adds playable content, including two difficulties, some bosses, and few other things. The artbook itself is nice, though be aware there's an NSFW image in it.

43337221.review:
TL;DR This was not something I expected to like. I liked it [i] a lot. [/i]

[h1] The Story [/h1]
[i] 5/10 [/i]
The story is absolutely the worst part of the game, but in my opinion it wasn't absolutely horrible. It was difficult to follow at times and some events sorta happened out of nowhere, but it flowed nicely enough that I could manage it quite well up until Chapter 4/5, which is the end of the main game. 

The amount of characters that refer to themselves or each other by name instead of "you" or "I" is absolutely ridiculous. Originally, I thought this trait was exclusive to Ribbon, a small fairy that acts as Erina's (the protagonist) long-ranged assistant. It was cute until I realized characters like [spoiler]Noah[/spoiler] & Rumi did that as well. 

Then there's the whole "Master" thing. Ribbon refers to Erina as "Master" from time to time, Erina & [spoiler]Miru[/spoiler] refer to Rumi as "Master". It gets quite on my nerves, but I did have a chuckle when the game pointed their story flaws every so often.

[h1]The Controls[/h1]
[i] 8/10 [/i]
Albeit the quirky setup for performing actions, the controls are surprisingly easy to pick up. They're fast and always responsive, making the bullet hell experience flow that much better. The only issue here is the menus will sometimes activate Ribbon's Boost when backing out, and that gets quite aggravating when it's activated outside of a boss segment. There's also the chance of activating an ability with your hammer that you didn't want if you're a bit reckless with the controller, but that's usually harmless and only impacts people with gamepads.

[h1]The Metroidvania Gameplay[/h1]
[i]10/10[/i]
This is easily the most polished part of the game, which is why it's the only category I'm rating as perfect. Each area comes with its semi-unique assortments and variants of enemies, each with a learnable pattern to maneuver around. The world is littered with not only 5 potions that generously upgrade your statistics, but wands for Ribbon that give her unique attack styles, abilities that give Erina additional mobility, jewelry that upgrade already existing aspects, orbs that make already existing paths more traversable, and badges that allow you to customize Erina to your own strengths and weaknesses.

The paths you attempt to travel are rarely blocked by the plot past the prologue, allowing for almost entirely free exploration the entire time. The open world allows you to take on later bosses earlier if you know where they are, and even though some paths are meant to be blocked off until you get a new ability, you can utilize hidden moves that are always available and bypass the obstacles anyway. In fact, the non-linearity gets so ridiculous that you're able to beat the game without picking up the Piko Hammer, Erina's method of attack.

[h1]The Danmaku Gameplay[/h1]
[i]8/10[/i]
The bosses are obviously the main part of the game, and are [i] almost [/i] always a fun fight. Every single boss (and there are a [b] lot[/b] of them) has tons of unique attack patterns that will keep competitive players on the edge of their seat, and will provide tons of replayability for the more casual players. The bullet hell patterns are insane in later chapters and the reasons for executing said patterns even more so. Every boss is fun and has a signature set of moves that really make them memorable. Each equipped with a "spell card", these bosses are no joke. Sometimes, however, it's not a joke for the wrong reasons.

If you don't take the time to empty the world of items, bosses from Chapter 4 and onwards will prove to be absolutely ridiculous in terms of health, resulting in a messy endurance encounter. During the main game, however, this is completely avoidable if you don't rush. Taking time to collect items and balance your playtime in both genres the game provides you, bosses will provide the right amount of challenge. Of course, some players may not be happy about this, as even after items are collected a certain amount of perseverance is required to defeat the later encounters.

Even after the above paragraph, though, the bosses are still a beautiful feature in Rabi-Ribi and interested players should take the time to fight as many as possible.

[h1] The Music [/h1]
[i]9/10[/i]
Most of the tracks aren't that memorable, but all of them do their job amazingly. Especially when it comes to the snow & boss themes, the ambiance the audio creates is almost a necessary addition to the areas that vary in intensity to extreme extents. I don't really have much to say here, other than they're some [i] d a r n [/i] good tunes.

[h1]The DLC[/h1]
[i]9/10[/i]
The Artbook is just a wonderful addition to Rabi-Ribi. Yes, you get the art that you paid for - design concepts, commentary, etc - but you also get actual content along with it as a nice little extra for helping out a certain cat person. The missions are fun and unique, and the bonus unsused boss was a nice little addition. Haven't picked up the other DLC, but have heard very good things about it.

The ONLY issue I have with the DLC portion is that the wardrobe customization is [i] exclusive [/i] to DLC.

[h1]The Extras[/h1]
Not a large enough chunk of non-post-game extras to actually rate, but I appreciate there being a set of Boss Rush modes that spice up things just enough to be a fun, new challenge. 

[h1]The Final Rating[/h1]
Story: 5/10
Controls: 8/10
MetroidGP: 10/10
B.HellGP: 8/10
Music: 9/10
DLC: 9/10
[b]Final Rating: 9/10[/b]

I know this isn't an averaged amount, but the story isn't important to the point where it's necessary to deduct an additional point from the final rating. This is an absolutely amazing game, and I reccomend everyone looking for a new twist on a classic challenge to pick this game up.

Definitively recommended.
