42750134.review:
After a long string of Steam recommending me garbage visual novels just because I had played Tales of Berseria and Danganronpa, I had initially thought this game was another one. Out of curiosity, I took a look at the store page and was surprised to see a metriodvania with all the top reviews praising amazing gameplay rather than only talking about the cutesy asthetic. So, I bought it and was astounded by the fact that this is one of the best designed games I've ever come across, and a killer bullet hell game to boot. I'll just briefly talk about some of the aspects of it.

[b][u] Story [/u][/b]
The story is pretty meh overall, and is the game's weakest aspect. However, the game is aware of this and keeps any dialogue to a minimum, and usually tries to incorporate jokes rather than an attempt at dramatic dialogue. Character designs are... fanservicey to say the least, and characters themselves do not have much depth. However, the game's focus on gameplay allows the story issues to not have much prominence.

[b][u] Music [/u][/b]
Almost every track in the game is extremely strong and fitting for it's setting, with the majority of the game's best songs being held by the end game and post game areas and bosses. It was one aspect that caught me by surprise, as each and every area consistently had a strong theme to go with it. The soundtrack is definitely worth buying if you are interested in it.

[b][u] Gameplay [/u][/b]
This is the biggest strength of this game. The controls are tight and responsive, and enemies and bosses are well designed to bring new challenges and strategies at a constant pace. As well, the game has an extremely well designed and laid out map, with a multitude of secrets, optional bosses and areas, and optional challenges. Plenty of collectibles are available across the map as well.
This game also incorporated fresh ideas that, as a fan of metroidvania style games, I have barely ever seen outside of this title. Combat, combo, and boss fight mechanics are extremely well designed, keeping the game challenging no matter how many items you have found, but still easing the difficulty with the aquisition of more. And when i say "no matter how many," I mean that it is possible to complete a run of this game while obtaining anywhere from 0% of the items and upgrades available to 100% of them. That is only possible due to an extremely clever mechanic in the game, [spoiler] Hidden Tech [/spoiler]. I keep the name of this spoilered out since this mechanic is best discovered yourself, and the game will make sure to tell you in the form of an acheivement if you have found something.

Overall, this game is abolutely worth playing for anyone who likes bullet hells, metroidvanias, or just challenging games in general. The DLC is also very much worth purchasing, with the caveat that all of the game's hardest fights are contained in the DLC. With that in mind, perhaps play through the game first and only get the DLC if you find the difficulty to be manageable, as the DLC is sometimes crushingly hard in comparison, while still fair.

9.1/10

42144486.review:
I personally embrace the cutesy "moe anime" aesthetic, but even if the visuals are a turn-off to some Rabi-Ribi is nonetheless a masterful game underneath. The "bullet hell" boss fights and dual protagonist setup with both a melee (Erina) and ranged (Ribbon) character is a unique take on the usual Metroidvania formula. The dynamic difficulty and careful level design give players a lot of freedom to explore the map as they please, rarely being funneled to specific areas and ensuring the player is never under- OR overprepared for fights. Controls are tight and precise; Erina is insanely mobile at full power and yet never feels neither clunky nor unwieldy to move around. An item finder function exists, so 100% item collection (though not easter eggs...) is feasible even if playing blind.

The only weak point is the story, which mostly exists to fuel the gameplay and character interactions, but that's rarely a strong point for games in this genre and the individual characters are still pretty cute. Take or leave the visuals based on personal preference, mind the game doesn't particularly sexualize its characters despite their pandering designs, but the music is more universally praised ranging from appropriately thematic area tunes, upbeat boss music to energize the player, and epic ballads to set the mood for the biggest showdowns.

Rabi-Ribi is perhaps the best example of a "tough but fair" game I've ever played. The lowest difficulty is pitifully easy for anybody with working eyeballs and motor skills. It's great to accomodate total gaming newbies, youngsters, and anyone who just wants to solely concern themselves with the exploration aspects of the game and/or follow the story. Successive deaths will offer you a buff to make things easier; the only penalty for doing so is a bruised ego. Consumables are encouraged. Buffs can be purchased from acquired helper characters in town. And it's all totally optional, the player has full control of how challenging (or not) their experience is.

On the flip side, the game can be UTTERLY BRUTAL if you desire and it does so while remainingly entirely in the realm of fairness (with one exception, the very intentionally cheap and entirely optional "special" endgame boss trio). Upping the difficulty doesn't crank damage up to insane levels but makes boss attack patterns faster and more complex, challenging players to tighten their execution while still allowing them to make mistakes.

Seriously, kudos to the design team. Bosses actually modify their attacks based on items collected to ensure that nothing is ever undodgable just because you don't have a specific item. The map has a heck of a lot of alternate paths and secret passages to give players the freedom to explore with a wide variety of item loadouts, including the possibility to complete the game with no items at all! If you're an achievement hunter, some of the DLC ones have alternate unlock conditions based on whether or not you have the DLC (I think just the Artbook cheevos though).

There's the usual boss rush fare, a "speedrun" mode that automatically skips all cutscenes for your pure gameplaying pleasure, and a CG gallery for cutscenes viewed. Sound test is fun to screw around in because you can crank the speed on the music way up or down. Controls are fully remappable and gamepad support is good. Personally I'm not a fan of the way the comic and leaderboard (and in-game cheevo display) are implemented with the Steam overlay, but it's cool that they're accessible from inside the game.

And over two years since release, the developer is still showing this game a lot of love too! (Perhaps it helps that they recently released on Playstation Network and are preparing for the Switch release.) Just in the past couple months (as of writing this) they've added local multiplayer co-op out of nowhere, as an "April Fools" gift gone serious, and an additional tougher difficulty [i]beyond the two beta difficulties in the Artbook DLC that are already tougher than the highest release difficulty![/i] They are their own game's biggest fan and it really shows with how much care and support they continue to show it well after release.

This game is worth more than its asking price and worth every gamer's time.

42037507.review:
This game manages to surpass nearly all of my expectations of what a metroidvania should have (and also shouldn't, but they're trivial). 

Rabi-Ribi's plot is quite silly, to say the least. There is potential to the plot progress but it was wasted with typical anime-esque tropes and arguably cringy texts. Fanservice is next to none though (although I have to say there ARE some eye-gouging cutscenes you might want to fast-forward through; I didn't!). With that out of the way, the rest of this game is prefectly done, from the battling mechanics and world exploration to the IU and soundtrack. I must say that I bought this game expecting a metroidvania, not an anime RPG, so I'll comment accordingly.

This game is like a hybrid between a metroidvania (hollow knights, ori and the blind forest) and bullet hell (nuclear throne, enter the gungeon, touhou); you explore the world with random mobs, secret rooms, bosses, checkpoints and whatnot, while you also have to dodge crazy bullet curtains projected out. This part was well done. whatever you do the difficulty will be tailored accordingly, regardless of how many skill items you've collected (hell, there's an achievement of "completing a game with no items collected"!). Of course you could revert back to a story-related gameplay which encourages exploration. That said, Rabi-Ribi leaves a lot of free space for the player to do whatever he likes - non-linear they say. Although the bosses are vital to the plot, it's made so that you could fight anyone you'd like first and the plot will still make sense. Speaking of bosses, they contribute a huge part to this game's success. As said, fighting them involves in spamming attacks continuously (their HP is insanely high to encourage bullet-dodging) and ultilizing various techniques to dodge mentioned curtain of bullets. To make this trial-and-error process not dull, the pattern of the bullets are really original and once you lose, you know it's your fault, not the game's. The battles are far from being artificially hard (except for the unusually high HP, which again, is for bullet-dodging encouragement). There are 40+ bosses for you to fight with and 5 (or 6?) difficulty levels to engage in. There was a point when you have to fight like 15 of them, one by one without any checkpoints in between. God that was exhausting.

The soundtracks are pretty short but they do create a vibe and are pretty good. The music and the battle together makes for the satisfaction after you've won a long boss battle. Art's fine, anime standard art.

That said, I do think this game fits a larger niche than it's destined to at first with tight controls, engaging battles, various items and secrets that are not compulsory so you could do whatever you want, nice soundtracks, art and whatnot. Unexpectedly good game.

42030863.review: The aesthetic of this game put me off of it for a long while but in all actually it's... a pretty fine metroidvania, yeah. Wouldn't say it's the best I've played but it's pretty fun. It clearly focuses on exploration and combat more than platforming but it does the first two well enough that I don't really mind the lack of the third. And there's a loooot of boss fights here. And they're surprisingly diverse for mostly being against humanoid characters; just a lot of different bullet hell style fights, mostly. The game world is pretty big by itself with a lot to find, though sometimes hiding stuff in a lot of obtuse ways without giving you the tools to find it all (some of those easter eggs are just, what, whatever). And a few of the bosses aren't too great; too much time invincible being the primary reason. I dig how the strength of the enemies scales as you grow more powerful but there's still some natural curve to the difficulty as well. And I like how some important powerups are just... there. Playing through the game the first time and it is just perfect for me as it has both plenty of story elements like a visual novel, but also a lot of typical metroid/castlevania mapping and item hunting. I've had my issues with the publisher Sekai before, but I think with titles like Rabi-Ribi they probably hit exactly where they should be publishing games. High quality, anime games with a lot of enjoyable gameplay. I kind of hope they can bring in more of these, and perhaps avoid certain other genres that they seem to deliver much worse at.

For anyone looking to pick this game up, it has quite a lot of hours of fun into it. Especially if you are slowly looking for secrets all over the place like I do. My only real complaint in over 10 hours of playing is that the game kind of felt like it was encouraging you too much to go continue the main quest line after you reached those checkpoints, while I'd rather go search the areas as far as I can get. That part could probably have been designed better.

The rest is just a solid and fun anime game. Probably even better than some classics like Bunny must die and Cave Story.

Of course if you are one of those boring people, you should be aware that the game enjoys showering you with sprites that wear fetish clothing on the girls. The game is mostly for men I would say, even if there is no problems enjoying it if you aren't a hater of such content.

41594326.review:
TL;DR: You should really consider buying this game. It has tons of replayability (especially for those who love to set goals), and is a surprisingly difficult game. Don't let the anime art style turn you off. By the way, this game has no nudity in it. If someone says this game has any sexual content in it, they're wrong. That should please those of you who don't like nudity and sexual content in your games.

Onto the actual review.

Rabi-Ribi is a game about a bunny girl and a fairy. The plot of this game is very simple, with you needing to bring back someone who mysteriously teleported away. However, despite what you may believe, that's not what has kept me playing for as long as I have been. So, what makes this game so interesting?

This game is a metroidvania. I've never played a metroidvania game before, so when I went into this, I didn't know what to expect. I really don't regret diving into this. There always seemed like there was something more to do, and something more to collect. Even after finishing the game, it seemed like there was always something I'd either forgotten, or would suddenly find out.

Combat is also pretty interesting. You control Erina, and use Ribbon as your support. The only thing Erina can do is attack with the Piko Hammer. It sounds very simple, but when you have a ranged fairy along with that, combat can become very interesting. What would otherwise be mindless bashing now becomes constant comboing with melee and ranged attacks, while sometimes dealing with various attacks that get thrown your way.

Surprisingly enough, this game has a ton of replayability, especially if you go into this game setting goals. The first goal I had when I got this game was to get good enough to speedrun the game. One playthrough on hard turned into another playthrough on Hell, to another 10 or so playthroughs on Impossible. Each time I've played, I've found something new and interesting. I haven't even done all there is to do. I keep getting caught up in other stuff. I've yet to do a 0% run, and I've yet to get 100% of the map filled.

So, what makes this game so satisfying? One thing may have to do with the bullet hell. Some people played this game on Casual or a really low difficulty, and may have found the game to be "not too difficult". If you're one of those, try heading to a harder difficulty.

After all of what I just said, I think it's easy to know what I'm going to tell you.

41224978.review:
[h1]Overall[/h1]
Rabi-Ribi is a 2D exploration platformer and a bullet hell, much like games from the Touhou series. The world and its art-style are very cute, funny, while the gameplay is energetic and explosive. Jump, shoot, bash, mash, loot, bump, die and repeat - the pace of the game astonishes, even after late-game bosses.
The game honestly becomes quite difficult past a certain point in the story, forcing you to understand what you actually do. Rabi-Ribi makes you grow fond of its looks, its general cutesy atmosphere and its yet epic, somewhat difficult, boss battles. In addition, the post-first-playthrough game modes expand the game's lifespan and offer new, challenging ways to play.

[h1]Overall score - [b]9/10[/b][/h1]


[h1]Story[/h1]
Rabi-Ribi's world does not have much innovation to offer, nor is its storyline revolutionary or outstanding in any way. It tells the adventures of Erina the bunnygirl, a former actual bunny who doesn't know how or why she was transformed into a human, and Ribbon the fairy, a dweller of a forest who has never left her home. Both of them know nothing of the world in which they begin their adventure, and hardly anything about themselves even. But as the plot develops, the mystery thickens and the story gets more interesting. All in all, although the story may come as quite generic, it has its moments and is still enjoyable.


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Rabi-Ribi is all about exploring and fighting. The quest do not guide you as much as in present-day games: the places you want to go to and the order in which you visit them are entirely up to you. You generally do not have a precise objective in mind, stuff just [i]happens[/i]. Most of the time, you notice that you arrived to a quest location because a boss pops out of nowhere.
The exploration part can be ignored to a certain extent, but it isn't recommended for a first playthrough as it makes altercations even harder and reduces your number of available moves.

[b]♦ Exploration[/b]
Rabi-Ribi's world is rather vast. It is divided into several areas that you can all access at any point through the story. The maps are labyrinthine and brim with items, bonuses and power-ups to discover and pick up. Some are noticeable, most aren't. Illusionary walls, secret passages and hidden areas are scattered around the world. Their hold secret bonuses, but they also serve as shortcuts to get to bosses' fights more quickly. Surely enough, you will get paranoid and try to bomb every wall looking for a hidden passageway. 100%'ing inventory and bonus stats is not a simple task.

[b]♦ Fights[/b]
The fights are absolutely nuts. Most of any enemy's attacks consists in shooting bullets or lasers - still, who would have imagined that such a variety of patterns could be invented? Fighting trash mobs isn't that unsettling, although their damage might bewilder you at times. However, fighting bosses is on a completely different level. They spam the living sh*t out of you and throw so many projectiles at a time that you will not get out of the battle alive, yet more unscathed, if you do not choose your time to attack wisely. Every boss' attacks are unique and amazing. You need to dodge them cleverly in order to be in position to dodge the next attack. These duels are very challenging, but a hell lot of fun.

[b]♦ Items and collectibles[/b]
As I said, the map is filled with items and power-ups to pick. Items basically unlock new moves and enable to go to new places (higher, accessible only by sliding etc.). On the other hand, power-ups slightly boost your stats. There is a shop at which you can buy more of these power-ups and where items can be upgraded to improve their combat ability. Items are compulsory to grab to move on in the story, power-ups aren't. You can choose to unequip an item at any time. All this means that you can choose to pick up all the collectibles you find to become stronger, or you can choose not to pick up anything and deactive your items to push the challenge to its limit. But, in this case, the game will become extremely difficult.

[b]♦ Difficulty[/b]
All in all, Rabi-Ribi is pretty difficult. The game starts off quite easy regardless of the initial difficulty level you picked, but becomes harder over time. More precisely, there are several difficulty spikes past certain events in the story. You definitely take some time to adapt to later bosses and start dying frequently at some point. If you did not collect power-ups, the game gets so absurdly mad that I cannot begin to describe it. At any moment, you may choose to lower the difficulty, but you can never get it up again.


[h1]Aesthetics & Sound environment[/h1]
Rabi-Ribi's design suit the game very much. The retro-like graphics fits well with the cute atmosphere and each character's art style is very good.
However, the most gorgeous thing Rabi-Ribi has to offer is indisputably boss battles. Each boss has his own patterns and his own attacks, and you would not believe how many different missiles a skilled team is able to create. No boss resembles another, and the bullet hell they unleash looks like a ballet of forms and colours - which leaves a particular feeling of satisfaction to the fights. You will most probably take a few hits at the start of every battle, because you will be both surprised by the celerity of the attacks and amazed by how colourful they are. 
To top it off, each boss has its own music that fits its style of combat and attack. The musics are both cute and epic, and they fire you up as much as needed to fight decently. Each area's background music also sounds good, without being invasive. They are calm and often soothing, which makes for a better surprise when it surprisingly switches to an epic one because you have just unexpectedly encountered a boss!

41213702.review: Actually one of the best metroidvanias in the entire genre.

41139402.review:
I can't express my feelings for this game, it has a perfect mix of everything that overall, makes this one of my favourite games I have ever come across.
There are many features to a game that can be implemented to craft a perfect game and I think this game takes those elements and makes it into a price worthy platformer. 

For a start, and most importantly, the gameplay. On the surface, the controlls look very simple and the action also looks quite simple and basic which is true in the earlier parts of the game but, as the game progresses, the intensity of merging moves learnt throughout the game into dodging the bullet hell the bosses throw at you makes the game very challenging yet still viable to play. 
The thought processes of using slower but more rewarding melee moves or faster but less damaging projectiles, healing items and bombs turns this game from a simple bullet hell platformer into a much more complex yet still managable game to enjoy and play. 
The difficulty however, can be very challanging at the end-game which is understandable for it being th final boss. That is why the importance of difficulty settings is good for this game because it appeals to more than just skilled players but also the lesser experienced players too with an option to decrease the difficulty at any point which I think is vital. 
I would say the gameplay is split into three parts, discovering new parts of the map, finding skills and upgrades, and the boss fights. The map discovery sections are pretty self explanatory but is important and done well in this game because of the interactivity of the maps and the challenges it puts before you, rather than being levels you can simply fly through without any reward. This makes the lesser intense parts of the game still interesting and interactive which many other games seem to lack. Secondly, the finding of skills and upgrades. This part of the game is vital for many player for without them, you will find it very hard to pass though some of the later bosses. This follows the same formule as the map discovery sections because it doesn't send you though a hard tresure hunt without any rewards or purpose that feels stuck in but instead, makes it a high reward and fun journy to the final upgrade. Also, a small feature is the attention to the players level and the level of the enemies of the area. The upgrades you find in the area seem to correlate with the levels of the enemies which again is attention to the reward you get for finding these upgrades. Finally, and  the most fun part of the game is the boss battles that are present at the end of each "level" per say and aren't your usual boss battle. These boss battles focus primarily on you and the boss where you need to stratagise your attacks in an attempt to deal as much damage as you can and take the least damage possible until you defeat them. The attack patterns are very inventive and unique which means you rarely see any repeats which makes each new boss a new experience for the user. Another small feature is the use of the ranks in the boss battles that increases up to max depending on your performance throughout the battle. Rather than the rank simply being a title present in your records (,while still important because it drives the player to do even better to get max rank), it has a dual funciton of increasing the players attack by up to %40 at a time which rewards the player for doing well in the battle, usually do to the upgrades collected in the previous area. The final thing gameplay I feel is vital to mention is the continue buffs you are presented with when you die multiple times. Rather than getting to a level and repetitively dying over and over again and getting frustrated, the game gives you the option to have buffs that increase various stats and results in you staying alive long enough to pass the harder sections. This is just a potential helping hand to assist the user, just incase. 
These features is what makes the gameplay unique and different to your usual game which definetly seperates it from other games.

Gameplay aside, the story. While the story of the game is not the best out there, it is still enough to give the game a premise to work off and form a game around which it does very well. The game is basically split into two halves, the first half is the easier section, working on getting skills and upgrading stats to tackle the harder bosses in the game, and the second half is less focused on the working of skills and upgrades and rather focuses on the intensity and implementing these skills against more challanging bosses. 
The second half acts as a post-main game section that still works off the first half which is more for the experienced players to get a "second shot" at some more challanging gameplay while giving the lesser able players a place to stop and more or less, finish the game. 
This again gives you every oppotunity possible to play the game to your preference and skill level rather than a pre-set path and difficulty which would usually drive away most players.
The story itself is moderatly long giving the player lots to do and play for, taking me up to 30 hours just to do the non-dlc story with much more to offer with the dlc options given to you. This means that this game will last you longer than the usual game that can be finished in one sitting which shows that real thought has gone into making this game what is it. 

Now another important yet small feature that I think the creators of Rabi-Ribi have done well is the controlls. I played with a controller so I can't make any comments on the ease of the keybindings, but the controlls regardless are very simple and easy to grasp with the given option to change the bindings to more closely suit your preferences which makes you feel a lot less trapped with how the developers want you to play the game but rather how the player themselves wants to play the game.

Now finally, the last important part that feel meeds to be mentioned is the music. In some cases, the music can be the make or break feature of a game, the feature that livens up a battle and overall emphisises the tone of specific scenes. Rabi-Ribi seems to handle this quite well with an extensive range of boss music that really makes you feel part of the boss battles and I belive that some of the music included in the boss battles are some of the best boss music out there. It fires you up for the upcoming battle. There isn't much else to say about the catchy tunes in this game, it is one of the smallest features that have the greatest effect on the game. 

The only negative things about this game is the difficulty of some of the early game enemies. Sometimes they can be too hard to defeat and continue which is vital doesn't happen in the early sections of the game where the player needs to learn how to play the game but this was only present with a select few enemies and even then, it disappeared later on in the game. 
Another negative that may arise from some players is the duration of the boss battles. While I personally had no problem with this, some of the boss battles can be a bit lengthy such as the final battle for example which takes up to 30 minutes of constant playing and dodging to complete which can be viewed as quite ridiculous but can be seen, especially in my eyes as a higher reward when you finally come across defeating the boss. 

I would personally highly reccomend this game if you are up to a complex, cute and challenging bullet hell platformer and the price is worth what you get. I really enjoyed playing this game and I am up to playing it again in the near future.

40193661.review:
I'm... speechless...
This is actually the greatest game I have ever found on Steam, period.
Okay, that might sound cheesy, so let me backup my statement.

[h1] A tale of a bunny and a fairy... [/h1]
The story revolves around the bunny-turned-human Erina. To be honest, the [b] Story[/b] is probably the weakest aspect from this game. Then again, you probably weren't expecting a great story in the first place from a metriodvania. What we have here works, so it doesn't really warrant more than a minor complaint.

[h1] An adventure of improvement and growth.[/h1]
This game takes the form of a metroidvania. If you are unfamiliar of the term, it originates from two games that share the same gimmicks, Metriod (the series) and Castlevania (specifically, Symphony Of The Night). You start off without even having your two main weapons, leaving you defenseless and not very mobile with a simple jump. However, that lasts all of 10 seconds when you recieve your trusty Piko Hammer, and it all goes on from there. By the end of the journey, you'll be a high-flying, air-jumping, bash-rolling, uppercutting, hammer-flailing bunny with the power to unleash a massive beam from a carrot. Yes.

[h1] Wherever there's growth, comes challenge.[/h1]
If you play normally, the game'll treat you well. It respects your skill, but if you're struggling, it will offer help in the form of the Halo Boost, granting temporary perks that help with the fight. However, if you ask it to, the game can kick your ass so hard you'd probably only be able to hop for the rest of your life. The hardest difficulty, [b]Bunny Extinction[/b], is DETERMINED to make your species extinct by pelting you with an endless barrage of bullets. If you manage to brave the challenge, you'd be able to walk outside and dodge the goddamn rain.

[h1] But most importantly, it's all about the fun.[/h1]
Honestly, ever since I've got this game, I've been HOOKED. It's just so much goddamn fun, especially if you're a masochist like me. If you want the ultimate challenge, try for the Rabi-Ribi achievement. I haven't even managed to get ahold of that kind of skill after 150 hours of playtime. If you wanna push yourself even further beyond, the speedrunning community is fierce with competition. Can you score ahold of a world record in Speedrun Mode (that's included in the game, mind you).
Not the kind for fights? The game also functions as a perfectly functional platformer, complete with the ability to make custom scenarios to put our bunny/fairy duo through. Steam Workshop support available, too!

Backed by an absolutely phenomenal soundtrack by the likes of Triodust and 3R2, Lazoi, MWT, Waiting and more, with pretty pixel art and the cutest bunny/fairy duo you can find on Steam, incorporating Bullet Hell elements into a fully functional Metroidvania, jam packed with content and with endless replayability.
All in all, I can just say this:
[h1] If you haven't bought this game yet, you are MISSING OUT. BIG TIME.[/h1]

That is all. Enjoy!

EDIT: Improved wording.

40011047.review:
[h1]Do not be fooled by cuteness, lest you be beaten countless times[/h1]
Rabi-Ribi is a game that blends together metroidvania, bullet hell and platformer gameplay, and does it pretty frickin' well. On top of that, you get a ton of cuteness, rabbits and anime-esque goodness. But one of the things you must never forget is that this game is [i]very hard[/i]. Although, to be fair, you could play on casual difficulty.
Although there are many items scattered around the expansive map, on standard rules the bosses you encounter become stronger with you such that the advantage is not game-breaking. On another point, the bosses are probably the selling point of this game: with bullet-hell attacks that are always dodgeable (even the flippin' annoying ones), by the end quite challenging, and also always with an excuse to fight you (including atmospheric anomalies). Erina, the Playboy-esque bunny-turned-bunnygirl who wields a giant Piko hammer, has to deal with all this while trying to figure out what the heck happened. And her accomplice in the carnage is Ribbon, just another fairy who is [i]absolutely[/i] not food.
On the aesthetics of the game, the more peripheral aspects of this game are pretty good. The 16-bit artstyle used in gameplay flows well, and the areas all look great (even the endgame ethereal areas). Rabi-Rabi Island (and what I presume is Taipei) in this art style looks colourful and bright in most areas, and the endgame ethereal areas also give a sense that you're in a purely magical area. The antialiased drawn art is pretty good too. And the music is good enough to be listened to [i]outside[/i] the game. Respect to GemaYue, Saiste, Triodust and the others for all this.
However, although the story has some mystery to it, it is probably the weakest point of the game, as there are tropes to be found (Saya: "NOTICE ME SENPAI!" [i]not a direct quotation[/i]) but not too many. Perhaps GemaYue (the developer) just wanted to focus on gameplay, which is not a terrible idea. There is always the excuses to fight, and even Ribbon has had enough of it. But it's not terrible.
A neat point about this game is that if you ever find yourself having to 'git gud' you might just, with perserverance, 'git gud'. To exaggerate: Having difficulties on casual difficulty? Well, give it 300 hours and I guarantee you'll be doing 0% BEX runs without ever suffering damage. I was one who chose to start on hard difficulty, and with the effort (and lots of retries; godammit Nieve and Nixie, you're flippin' annoying!) I finally made it to the end of the DLC content (much harder than the base game). Who knows, maybe you'll have that skill too. I still have a long way to go myself. +1 to replayability.
Even if you find anime-esque things distasteful, I encourage you to challenge yourself to a game that could give Dark Souls a run for their money (maybe).
Oh and one other point: GemaYue is [b]Taiwanese[/b].
[h1]9/10[/h1]
[i]A great, challenging game, obsessed with bunnies, but nonetheless worthy of pro-gamers.[/i]

39590589.review:
Rabi-Ribi is a game with some really strong good points held back by some floundering bad points.  It's a good game and quite unique compared to what else is on the market, but your enjoyment of the game may be hampered by aspects of its presentation and whether or not that personally bothers you.  In Short: Great Gameplay but mediocre pixel art (and borderline hentai character design).

Rabi is a Metroidvania + Bullet Hell.  It has an insanely huge map with some of the best designed areas I have ever seen.  Several areas can be tackled in any order to progress the main story, while many movement abilities can be circumvented or worked around with clever platforming and creative routing.  It *is* possible to do several sequence breaks that sound impossible on your first playthrough: and most of them even have achievements associated with them.  Even on top of that, a huge amount of map/boss/areas are optional in the normal story.  The game has a pretty intense post-game with escalating platforming and boss fight challenges that will really test and engage you even on normal.

Speaking of boss fights and difficulties: this game can be challenging.  If you've never played bullet hells, you will struggle in some boss fights even on normal.  When it comes to the THREE higher difficulties than that, bonus bosses, DLC, NG+ looping, and challenge modes like speedrun and boss rush: you will quickly approach the limits of what you can handle.  But the game's patterns are really well-designed and the hit detection is excellent.  As hard as the game can seem, it's always your fault when you get hit.  To a seasoned shmup or fangame player, this game is not that hard as even the hardest patterns are pretty manageable and the extra difficulty mostly comes from boss stats.

The music is all-around solid but inconsistent.  There are some standout great songs, and some average ones, but nothing bad.  Some of the boss themes are super cutesy and others sound like they came out of a Castlevania final boss fight, but they're all catchy in their own way.  I liked it enough to buy the soundtrack edition.

The story is pretty generic and mostly forgettable, but it has likeable characters who just want to protect their home and their friends.  Some scenes are vapid hentai pandering, but if that's your cup of tea you'll see that as a pro and not a con.

The art... this is the part where the game suffers.  First off, the majority of the game is pretty low res pixel art.  This part is decidedly mediocre compared to the 60,000 other pixel art Metroidvanias on the market.  But it really is inconsistent with both the bullet hell patterns/FX and the high res hand drawn character portraits.  When the screen is overwhelmed with bullets it's always possible to see your character... but mostly for the unflattering reason that her sprite looks so much worse than everything else on the screen at that point.  As for the character art and character designs... this game is all women (and little girls) who are allergic to pants.  The playboy bunny costume has an in-universe justification, but there's nothing you could say to defend Ribbon or Miru's outfits.  If their cut-ins are on screen you better make sure your friends and family aren't watching, unless those people are into loli-bait.  Your only argument if they see it is "but it has good gameplay".  And y'know what?  It DOES have good gameplay, but it also has these character designs.

I enjoyed this game thoroughly and find the lategame platforming challenges and boss rushes truly exhilerating.  It's a good game wrapped up in the shell and trappings of a bad game.  Hopefully after reading this you know if you'll be able to enjoy it or not.  If I told you how I actually felt about Miru's artwork, the police would come banging on my door.  So instead I'm just gonna say: that kind of art had no place in this game.  In a different universe where this game had the art-style and character designs of Shantae, everyone would know and love Rabi-Ribi.

39449992.review:
Por juegos como Rabi-Ribi es que adoro esta industria, este Bullet-Hell ha hecho algo que yo creia imposible, tener una mecanica de gravedad, lo digo por que todos los juegos del genero eluden completamente la gravedad y por ese motivo me dio curiosidad. Que sorpresa más grata me llevé.

[h1] Historia y contenido [/h1]

Empecemos con el punto fuerte de este título: este juego tiene más contenido del que tu y yo vamos a querer jugar, mis respetos para aquellos que lo completan al 100% realmente es toda una hazaña. Pero voy a explicarme, despertamos en un lugar oscuro sin saber como llegamos alli ni donde estamos, al poco tiempo nuestra protagonista Erina se da cuenta de algo !Puede hablar¡ pero ¿Por qué? ella era un conejo, espera, tiene... ¿manos...? y... ¿Pies...? !Es una humana¡ escuchas un ruido y vas a perseguirlo, estabas dentro de una caja y pareces atrapada en un edificio; para no alargar el analisis, dire que estamos en un mundo donde existen hadas, magia y los conejos estan casi extintos, así que no es descabellado pensar que llegas a una isla con habitantes humanos con orejas de animales, tras volver a casa a encontrarte con tu "maestra" parece ser que su hermana menor esta perdida y para encontrarla hará falta un monton de magia así que tu mision sera buscar gente capaz de utilizar magia para ayudarte y a ello que vas, a darle de martillazos a todos para que te ayuden.
Todo bien hasta aqui, pero ¿dónde esta todo el contenido? Pues resulta que tras completar la historia principal aún queda [b] mucho [/b] por hacer, tenemos un segundo objetivo que no puedo contar por que es spoiler [strike] y no recuerdo cual era exactamente [/strike] pero si te puedo decir que es mas o menos equivalente a toda la historia principal, pero sabes que, aun no has visto nada, tras completar este segundo objetivo (yo tarde unas 40 horas hasta este punto) todavia te quedan montones de cosas para el 100%, claro que todo esto es opcional pero hay algunas cosas que si bien no vas a querer completar de primeras, lo vas a intentar y  no vas a parar hasta completarlas

[h1] Mecánicas [/h1]

Como habrás leido antes estamos hablando de un [i] bullet hell con gravedad [/i] y no solo eso, de mundo abierto, montones de items por encontrar, un ligerisimo toque de RPG, metroidvania, plataforma, 2D y un monton de bosses por derrotar. El juego realmente se basa en esto último, cada persona que quieras reclutar requerira que le encuentres pasando por un par de salas con enemigos bastante simples y que mueras unas cuantas veces en una pelea contra un boss, ya que saben usar magia es razonable pensar que te atacaran con muchos patrones de balas, ¿no...? parece facil pero ponlo en una dificultad alta y veras como los patrones pareceran inesquivables.
Al contrario que en todos los juegos del genero tu no tienes disparos para combatir al boss, o bueno quizas sí, pero son de un hada de quien te haces amiga al comienzo, tu tienes un martillo, una zanahoria y un par de habilidades mas, algunos combates son realmente tensos y dificiles así que tendrás que repetir hasta conseguirlo; este es uno de esos juego que te parecen imposibles al comienzo y al final de verdad son imposibles pero es increiblemente satisfactorio vencer.
Tambien tengo que hablar del mundo abierto, al ser en este formato eres libre de explorar todo lo que quieras mientras tus habilidades lo permitan, recordemos que tambien es metroidvania, asi que puedes buscar items para tener ventaja sobre los bosses donde te atoraste, a menos que estes en modo alternativo; me explico, al iniciar la partida puedes elegir entre 2 modos: estándar o alternativo, en estándar las stats del boss (vida y daño) se definen por tu progreso en la historia, de esta manera es posible obtener una ventaja, pero en alternativo las stats se definen por la cantidad de items que tienes, haciendo aun más dificil derrotar a un boss si no tienes alguna habilidad especial e incluso imposible obtener ventaja. Como recomendacion, si piensas jugarte el juego mas de una vez para conseguir logros, empieza por alternativo, me lo agradeceras

[h1] Más contenido [/h1]

¿Creias que eso era todo? aun habiendo completado todo lo que la historia te puede ofrecer quedan disponibles dos modos más y un par de DCL´s, uno de ellos gratuito que añade una zona nueva de plataformeo bastante dificil, el otro de ellos al momento de escribir esto no lo he jugado pero tiene pinta de añadir un par de capitulos más post-endgame y un par de bosses; en cuanto a los modos, ambos se desbloquean tras completar el juego principal, uno de ellos es bastante soso y [u] creo [/u] que solo es para conseguir logros [spoiler] speedrun [/spoiler] , pero el otro va a ser un veredadero dolor de cabeza o el mejor regalo que los desarrolladores te pudieron haber hecho: un Bossrush, por si uno solo no fuera suficiente ahi los tienes todos juntos, o bueno no exactamente todos. Existen 3 Bossrush uno de los bosses principales, otro con los Endgame y otro con los Post-Endgame, realmente una locura

[h1] Logros [/h1]

Me parece un poco absurdo hacer un apartado para esto pero creo que lo merece, los logros son en gran parte de donde viene mi exageracion por todo el contenido que tiene, te incitan demasiado a pasarte el juego al menos 4 veces y aun sabiendote las ubicaciones de los jefes, los patrones y demas no es un juego corto precisamente. Tambien estan los que van desde lo mas absurdo como derrotar a una silla y una mesa hasta lo mas dificil como pasarte el último boss del Post-Endgame sin sufrir ni un rasguño, me parece un buen objetivo conseguir unos cuantos de estos, realmente es divertido.

[h1] Pros y Contras [/h1]

+Tiene una banda sonora realmente buena y pegajosa
+Pixeles y anime juntos
+Trata sobre un conejo y un hada
+Vencer a un boss es realmente satisfactorio
+Montones de habilidades e items por encontrar
+Es largo
+Es difícil

-Hay zonas en las cuales no puedes entrar por ser el final de la historia pero la justificacion es: [i] Siento como si mi cuerpo no quiziera entrar alli [/i]
-Si bucas el 100% tendras que repetir el juego unas 10 veces

39290878.review:
I paid 19€ for this game and all the DLC's for the game, here at the end of last year, and it's all worth it!

While I was playing Rabi-Ribi, I had a very great experience playing the game, because of the games challenging gameplay, and the freedom to explore different places and areas, on the different maps in the game.
Rabi-Ribi's main hero Erina felt really great to play as, and it was also funny and heartwarming to follow her in the game, as the story goes. While I was playing as Erina, I had to face against lots of unforgettable bosses. My favorite boss to fight against was [spoiler]Arurane[/spoiler], because of she’s one of the bosses, I had the hardest time with, she was very challenging, yet very fun to play against. Meanwhile [spoiler]Irisu[/spoiler] was almost impossible to beat, and was very frustrating to play against, which made me T R I G G E R E D a bunch of times, after dying to her over several times, but at least it was VERY satisfying to defeat her, after 6 hours of trying.
In the game, you can do a bunch of cool things, like beating weeaboos with your PIKO Hammer, or try to beat a boss with only your helper [spoiler]Ribbon[/spoiler] or with only Carrot Bombs. The game offers a lot of gameplay, and 186 achievements you can try to get, if you’re a person that wants 100% like me. 

In the end I would say this game is a 10/10!
The only thing that was not enjoyable were the controls. They were a little bit annoying to use from the beginning of the game, since I expected to use W, A, S, D and SPACE, not LEFTARROW, UPARROW, RIGHTARROW and DOWNARROW, but at least the game has the possibility to change the controls.

EDIT: Game's still good!

The only way to make new friends, make someone happy or make someone trust you more is to beat the crap out of them (how even?)

Actual review:
I first found out about this game back in late 2016 when I heard some of the great soundtrack. As time went on I was exposed to even more of the OST so I got the game during the last winter sale. I was expecting a generic platformer with good music. The fact that the default controls are so confusing didn't help either, not to mention the game randomly started in Korean one time so I had to spend like 10 minutes finding where to change the language (one time bug).
HOWEVER
It was all worth it. The more I played the more addicted I got. To put it in perspective, first day I spent just one hour playing but at the end of the week I had 2 sessions of 3 hours in the same day. Despite being bad at bullet hell games (hell I died like 4 times in "casual"), it was just way too much fun for me to care. The story development is well put together. It does get boring sometimes trying to find certain items without many clues but then again it was a good chance to farm points for later upgrades. Also, the "Icy Summit" track is the most mesmerizing song I've heard in years, 10/10

39019989.review:
Don't judge a book by it's cover.
When I first saw this, I thought it was going to be one of those games. How wrong I was. It's a beautiful blast of sprites, waves of bullets, and what-the-heck-are-you-wearing.
First things first. The gameplay  could be summed up like this: 'Imagine if Cave Story and Touhou got spliced together by some mad scientist.' Because that's Rabi-Ribi for you. It combines brilliant platforming with relentless bullet-hell patterns in a way that I really haven't seen before. The last time someone made a game this ingeniously unique was, as much as I fear to say the name, Undertale. It takes two completely different genres and smashes them together into something completely new. And it works like a freaking charm.
The graphics next. (hoo boy.) The sprites are brilliantly made and fit the game perfectly. Joining this is some interesting art that, while initially a bit pervy, mocks this aspect at every opportunity, with people saying that main-lead bunny Erina should really wear more and sidekick Ribbon telling gawking nerds to sod off, saying that this isn't some kind of R-rated game. Yes, this game gets a bit meta at times and I love it for that very reason, but I digress.
The music is downright incredible. Harking to its Touhou genes, it churns out masterpieces at every turn. From upbeat tunes like Adventure Starts Here, to the sombre Floating Graveyard, to the relaxing Unfamiliar Place,  to every one of its battle themes (go play the game, don't spoil yourself. It's infinitely more epic when you don't know what's coming.) every note is beautiful, and always sets the perfect atmosphere for what it's used for.
In all, this is easily one of the best, most beautiful, most fun games I've played in a long while. I would definitely recommend that you go play this already.
Oh, yeah, its utterly brutal when you're playing on any mode other than casual. Just thought I'd point that out before you snap a keyboard or two.

Overall having a lot of fun with this one.  Metroidvania formula is intact, but it's pretty tight so I don't expect any skill-based sequence breaks.  Bosses are as numerous as they are varied, which is a huge plus for me.

The only turn-off is the sheer amount of exposition - I expected a fair amount in the prologue, but it has been a drag clear into 2nd chapter.  It has not made me care about supporting characters at all, and I just mash the start button to skip - it's a real shame.  Some focus could have made the game better, but it ends up hurting it instead.

Cute girls, metroidvania with COMPLETE non-linearity (In fact there are achievements for sequence breaking, and even for beating the game with no upgrades at all, including movement ones). 
Difficult bosses, or not so difficult bosses, depends on what you want from the game when choosing difficulty. The overworld is pretty big as well, but there are teleporters everywhere so it's not bad. 
The writing is also witty and humorous, though sometimes it seems a bit forced to make you fight someone, but fightings the point anyway so I'll give it a pass.
As for the story, even after the post game there are still some unanswered questions. I have not yet gotten the DLC yet, and that presumably answers them. Other than that, the main story is rather simple.
All in all, a wonderful game with tons of polish that WANTS you to try to break it. And I believe the dev is still updating it, so even better!

38757179.review:
As I've been playing through Rabi-Ribi I've wondered why, despite having been out for a while and the Overwhelmingly Positive Steam rating, none of the major review sites have ever had anything to say about it. I can only assume that they've eyeballed some of the art and instantly dismissed it as "weeb game for neckbeard pervs" or, if the Cuphead tutorial debacle's anything to go by, none of them could get far enough to pass any kind of comment at all.

Either way they're fools, because they've missed out on a real treat.

The marriage of metroidvania and bullet hell works so well that in retrospect I'm surprised it's not been done more. It's rare to see sequence-breaking and skipping as actively encouraged as it is here, with a wide variety of achievements on offer for deliberately missing what you thought were key items. Even then there's a lot to see, with 22 areas on offer it's not a small game by any means.  

With such heavy danmaku roots it'd be so easy for the bosses' bullet patterns to descend into maddening walls of relentless bullshit and it's to the designers' immense credit that not only is that never the case, but each fight is unique and memorable. That's not to say there are any gimmes; even on Normal you won't be in for an easy ride and if you're not well prepared you're going to get tonked seven ways from Sunday, but you'll rarely feel like a fight's completely beyond your ability if only you can sharpen up your concentration.

For me personally, getting value for money from my games is a massive plus point, and at £9.10 I feel like I've robbed the devs blind. Even without the POST-post-game bosses (because the game insists on continuing to throw out things for you to do!) and any of the DLC, the wealth of options that unlock after your first playthrough mean you'll always have a reason to come back. Multiple higher difficulties, a speedrun mode, a boss rush mode, and the achievements for no-damage boss fights and sequence breaks mean that although my time spent is currently 27 hours, there's going to be a damn sight more than that by the time I'm through with it.

If I had one tiny issue with the game it'd be with the character conversations. I get that if you're buying a game with bunny girls in it weird plot is going to come with the territory but my efforts at trying to make any sense out of it were consistently hampered by characters, in the middle of discussing what I assumed to be story, spiralling off into meaningless asides about day-to-day life, or their relationships with each other. Rather than give up the game or try to keep track I just decided I'd have more fun if I simply didn't bother, and that's how it proved. 

Rabi-Ribi is a deeply mature game, wrapped inside a deeply childish one. If bunny girls and nonsensical plots are your bag then fair enough, but don't give it a go for those reasons. Give it a go because you almost certainly haven't played anything quite like it before; a tight, finely crafted fusion of two great genres into one superb product that ends up becoming far more than the sum of its parts.

38391980.review:
Honestly this game is just amazing, totally worth the 18$.
If you're into weeb stuff or bullet hell games or both, this is the game for you.
Even if you are not into any of those things, this game might be worth a try anyways.
The gameplay is just lovely, and the story is interesting and funny, with loveable and unique characters you talk to, befriend, and even fight as bosses in the game.

Although I haven't had the time to play it in the last 2 weeks because I've been really busy with the Holidays and what-not, I'll play and finish it real soon. Just felt like writing a review for it atm.

It gives off a 16-bit vibe, with cute, comfortable chibi sprites and characters to enjoy looking at. Don't try to write it off like it's some weeb-shit game, because oh man it's much much more than that. Much better.

Rabi-Ribi offers fun to both casual and challenging players in its game difficulties, even giving you a chance to buff up the difficulty or lower it whenever you want while playing by going to a certain place.

If you are a victim of dying or losing too often it will even offer you help by making you practically invincible and give you buffs, mainly if you become stuck on a boss or stage of the game that proved too difficult for you. This is a great mechanic for those who like it really casual.

I've spent hours playing this game, mainly using a controller for my own preference, and I can tell you that it's not worth looking-over as some weeb game. I recommend buying both the PC and PS4 Versions, to see what fixiates you and your controls best. I actually use an xbox controller for the PC version, funnily enough. After I beat this game I'm going to replay it on the PS4 version and then probably go back to the PC to replay the bossfights and get rid of my previously horrible preformances on them with newer, better ones. You'll get better at the game as you play more of it.

To summarize:
It's a cute, funny game and I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes to experience or explore not only a challenge but a story. It's like a playable visual novel; you aren't just reading the story, but playing it!

If you like bunnies and/or hammers, get this game.
If you like fairies, get this game.
If you like anime girls, get this game.
if you like boss-fighting, get this game.
If you like super-power having anime girls that you fight as bosses, get this game.
If you like cuteness, get this game.
If you like stories and/or visual novels, get this game.
If you like a challenge, get this game (and set it up to a reasonable difficulty for yourself)
If you like it casual, you can also experience the same kind of achievement as someone who likes a challenge that plays it. Therefore, get this game.
If you like bullet hell, get this game.
And most importantly, saved for last, if you like your games having involvement with "sexy" (boobs and ass), get this game.

Well, what are you waiting for?
Just try it and fall in love with it already!

38243408.review:
This seems very much like an original, high-quality anime franchise, encapsulated within a very particular type of Metroidvania! You play as the rabbit-person Erina, who somehow makes friends with the fairy Ribbon, and they have somewhat weird adventures together as they meet other women who seem either fascinated with the fact a rabbit has turned into a not-unattractive woman, or somewhat repulsed by the idea. Or else, they want to capture her and do God knows what to her.

Gameplay more or less follows the basic scheme of a Metroidvania; get powers to get further in the world, but with twists all involving the introduction of Bullet Hell elements! That's right, you're on foot pretty much all the time and you have to constantly dodge everything that your enemies throw at you. It's not especially difficult, but it can be frustrating. Also you can add badges to get various effects like more attack power, more defense, the ability to see your enemies' health upon attacking them, and much more!

The story is so delightfully bizarre I find it hard to wrap my head around sometimes, so I will leave you to discover it! I recommend the game to all who like Metroidvania and quirky anime themes.

38012321.review:
Very fun game. It's an *extremely* open-ended metroidvania that generally lets you proceed in any direction you want, intended order or not. The levels are well-designed and fun, and items are hidden everywhere. The bullet-hell bosses are all very well designed and fun to fight. You're eventually given a wide, wide variety of abilities you can use in combat, and a decent number for exploration.

As for replay value, the game has tons of acheivements for stuff like skipping key items or doing things out of order. And like I said, you can pursue most of the bosses and items in any order. And yes, there's selectable difficulty levels. My first run lasted ~14 hours to see the credit roll on normal, but there's still another chapter and at least half a dozen more bosses, so this is a pretty long game to start with.

Art is good but notexceptional, music is quite good. The plot is mostly an excuse to fight people but that's ok.

Bottom line: This game is very good at all the things it tries to be. Would recommend.

38001263.review:
When I first picked up this game I was a bit hesitant due to the artstyle and gamplay photos. Sometimes boobs are put on mediocre games to make them sell just a little bit. This game however, is far from mediocre.
The particle effects in game makes every attack feel interesting and fair. Never have I wondered what I took damage from during a boss fight, and every time I attempted the same boss again I felt like I was ready to put my skills and knowledge about its attack patterns to the test.
The controls feel responsive, and movement and attack choices unlock in a pace that makes you feel like you always have quite a bit of options without being overwhelmed.
The game offers a bit of replayability due to its different difficulty options, and its different modes that changes the gamplay a bit. And since it will be your second or third time playing, you will aready know where certain key items and bosses are on the map, allowing you to choose your own path through the game (you can even chose to play the game without any items). More so if you master the reverse wall jump and wall kick techniques.
The story is interesting and the characters are cute, and unless you have a problem with the fact that it is an all female cast, you will find yourself quite invested in the world and everyone in it.
The soundtrack is one of the best ones I have heard, and helps create the atmosphere for each area.

37882092.review:
The amount of times I've seen people just dismiss this game because they think it's just anime fanservice or H-game :( . Whatever happened to that saying about not judging a book by its cover? While there is definitely some fanservice, there is no H-Content, and the game even actually jokes about it at one point in a scene that would make the people that are actually into H-games look bad.


But with that minirant done with, this is a very well made Metroidvania with a very balanced level of challenge. The platforming is not really difficult in most areas and gets harder near the end of the postgame areas, but it's nothing too unreasonable. The main strength of the game is in the boss fights where you will need to learn how to deal with all sorts of patterns.

There are lots of hidden items to find. Sequence Breaking is encouraged and sometimes even rewarded(there's even an achievement for doing some of them). Most bosses can be fought in whatever order you like, but there are some cases where you have to beat certain bosses to access some parts of the game or other bosses. While glitches do get patched out, there is an option in game to reenable them, so that speedruns can still use them. 


The game has many difficulty options. From easy modes that anyone who just cares about the story to get through to ones that should satisfy hardcore players. The only downside with this is that the harder ones have to be unlocked. Patterns get more bullets and get faster with increasing difficulty, but at least up to the game's standard highest difficulty of Bunny Extinction, the game is for the most part completely fair. At least during what comes in the game without DLC, if you get hit, it pretty much is always your fault in some way. Some of the DLC content may not necessarily be fully balanced, but I haven't spent as much time on that to see if I'm just missing stuff that would make things fair. There are higher difficulties than Bunny Extinction in the artbook DLC, but they were cut for a reason, there's lots of unfair stuff in those ones, but some people do enjoy that as well.


The achievements in this will also be a decent challenge if you're looking for a difficult game to 100%. Not only do you have to beat almost every standard game boss without getting hit(though final and postgame bosses do allow some hits), you will have to get through a boss rush of 28 bosses in a row, no heals between rounds, and if you die you will go right back to round 1, on Bunny Extinction or harder(The artbook's Unknown and Impossible do let you have 3 of the healing items compared to BEX cap of 1, but everything else about those probably makes it actually harder than BEX even with more healing available, but I have not finished the game on Impossible yet to be able to check that)


Also nominated for Labor of Love award.

37270942.review:
Rabi-Ribi is a wonderful combination of a platformer + bullet hell game in a metroidvania-esque map with a bunny girl and fairy as the protagonists. There's so many places to explore, each with many items and easter eggs to find. Non-Linearity is encouraged with an achievement even rewarding you for completing the game with no items. Do not let the cute artwork fool you, as with 6 different difficulty levels even the most hardcore bullet hell fans will still find the game to be challenging. This game also offers A LOT of replayability, even after 50 hours of playing it I still find myself with so much to do. Though the story is only mediocre, the game makes up for it with the amazing soundtrack.

TL;DR: Cute Girls + Metroidvania Map + Bullet Hell Bosses + Amazing OST = Rabi-Ribi

This is a masterpiece of a Metroidvania, Platformer Bullet Hell game that you play a Bunny/Fairy Tag team. 

I started this game didn’t expecting much knowing it’s a weeb game but my expectation was over turned very quickly as this one is very, very good. 

I like Bullet Hell game such as Touhou Project and 100% orange juice Serie. This game adds an interesting twist to make it into a platform instead of regular flying setting. This however feel super natural and wonderfully smooth. 

Every boss fight is super unique and mesmerizing. Sound effect, Music Effect, Graphics Effect are wonderfully blended together for an enchanting experience. 

Map design are very smart and huge. There are massive number of items and upgrades for you to discover and your bunny and fairy will get stronger and stronger and unlock a lot of extra region/area that you won’t have access to when you first going through the map. 

The story for this game is a bit weak and confusing compare to other aspect of this game. Me finishing first 2 chapter in 2017 and rest chapters in 2021 contributed to my confusion. But even without my real-life time skip the story for this game is still very weird even for a WEEB game. You don’t really need to enjoy the story to enjoy this game through.

This is also a game that I won’t recommend to 100% achievement grabber as the 220 achievements all need to be earned and some of the achievements need an independent playthrough of its own. I estimated at least 200-300 hours of many playthrough to get everything. There are also a whole bunch of DLC available and you need them to get 100% achievements as developer still upgrading this game to add new boss fight, new mode, new area and new time-based event. 

9/10 would be the high mark I gave this game as this is the best platformer, bullet-hell, Metroidvania game on steam. Once you start playing it’s very hard to put down. 

BTW Main Story ends on Chapter 6, With post-game it ends on chapter 8 and there is a DLC that i will buy next steam sale ends on chapter 10 bring the story to a final close.

Es un metroidvania fusionado con un Bullet hell,  con un enfoque hacia las  batallas contra  jefes.

Al principio PUEDE ([spoiler]mas bien llega a[/spoiler]) confudirse con un juego Anime kawaii mas pero es todo lo contrario, goza de  un  excelente diseño tanto de  jefes como de niveles  sin olvidar  el sountrack.

El juego es un reto constante, (aunque tiene mapa) le pide al jugador  recordar a que partes del mundo donde puede aceder conforme va adquiriendo habilidades (clasico de los metroidvania), recopensando cada avance en la historia/mundo con jefes cada vez mas dificiles.

El diseño de los patrones de jefes son ingeniosas cuando menos pero no llega a castigar mucho al jugador por morir  frente a un jefe ya que SIEMPRE hay un auto save antes de cada partida y al morir se carga la partida mas reciente. Asi que cada jefe no consiste en llegar fuerte si no de aprenderse el patron si no de evadirlo lo mejor posible. Los patrones de cada jefe cambian  su orden conforme su vida disminuye asi que morir y repetir un mismo jefe no se siente tan repetitivo.

La historia no es muy compleja (pero tampoco muy simple) pero siempre guarda un misterio que se va revelando poco a poco y que llega a mantener el interes conforme se avanza.

Todos los personajes son carismaticos aunque  se sienten hecho con el molde de Happy go lucky que en momentos pueden llegar  eso conforme la historia lo va requiriendo aunque no tardan en regresar a ese estado de animo semi perpetuo.

La musica puede llegar a sorprender por lo que aparenta el juego pero siendo usual en los bullet hell la musica es buena y esta bien ambientada  a la situacion no dudo que mas de 1 persona quiera comprar la edicion UPRPRC solo por que viene con el soundtrack.

En resumen es un bullet-vania? que sorprende el que lo juzga por la portada y llega a cumplir las espectativas de los amantes del genero, incluso a precio sin rebaja se siente  justo ya que te dara muchas horas de [strike] frustracion[/strike] divercion un 8.5/10

I have to assume it's one of those cases where "the gameplay gets really good 10/15/20/50 hours in", but I'm not willing to waste more time than I already have trying to figure out if that's true.

36586844.review:
Adorable. Deadly. Hectic. Challenging. A bundle of many unusual elements together to form one of the most fun games I've played.

Rabi Ribi is a game that surprises me with how much it has to offer for a single playthrough and beyond, offering a main playthrough that will last most players around at least a couple of hours. In addition to this, there is a lot of incentive to replay the game with ng+, post-game bosses/content, a free Halloween themed DLC with a hell of a fight, and many ways of rewarding players who wish to go the extra mile of challenging yourself via silly handicaps, speedruns, no items, etc. Non-linearity is embraced throughout a majority of the game with only gradual bits of the story restricting you from particular areas. You can determine how difficult bosses become via scaling with story progress or on the area by choice when you start off your playthrough, the first being more friendly for beginners doing mainly story progress and the latter being for those going off the course exploring to your liking.

 Gameplay consists of a chaotic and fun mix of action, platforming, and shmup/bullet-hell elements while navigating a Metroidvania-esque world map with lots of exploration, hidden items, secret spots, and more. While navigating through areas is interesting enough clearing a variety of enemies while looking for fake walls or breakable surfaces, the real meat and bones of how it plays comes together well bundled in the game's many many boss fights, with all having unique patterns that keep you on the edge and get gradually tougher and complex as your difficulty increases. No need to fear though, Erina has an arsenal of different shot types, a hammer to melee with, several unlockable items, and many techniques and tricks up her sleeve to reward skilled players, several which are related to hidden achievements so I will not discuss them here. 

If you feel intimidated by the difficulty or are having a hard time progressing, no need to fear. The game offers easier difficulties, a continue system that offers a special buff to reduce damage taken (not avaliable on hard or higher), and there are healing items avaliable. If you are still struggling with the difficulty you chose, shortly early on in the game is access to an NPC that offers to make the game easier.

On a final note, I wanted to discuss the art style if it is a concern for those who are not generally a fan of anime styled art, chibis, or any of that. I'd implore for you to look past the looks as it more focused on gameplay while not burdened with excessive fan service despite appearances or preconceptions you might have about the looks of this game.  

Still doing post-game as of this review and enjoying it. Highly recommend this game to anyone.

Edit 1: Fixed the note regarding the difficulty change NPC.
