36034537.review:
This game is simply the best and probably loved by the fans and maybe the devs themselves alike. A great platformer, bullet hell featuring cutesy characters and great graphical artwork

Updates, guides, and DLC's still pouring in even after it's initial release a year ago, and with each passing update, makes the game more fun as it is!

For the initial game it can literally be described in a LOT of words, which is probably why reviews here are so short, but here's what I think about it :

The visuals are AMAZING. I love how the backgrounds in each levels are thought out really well and immerses you in the environment. Character artwork and sprites complement each other, accurate that their pixel-y selves are distinct even without even seeing their artwork. And the generous use of light colors in its UI, characters, and environment gives the game it's cute, soft, and adorable charm.

The story is okay, not bad but not that great either. The initial game doesn't tell anything too much about the lore of the island you play on. It does tell you a bit about all the characters and the island itself, along with it's background fairly well. Thanks to that, you might feel attached to one of the characters since all of them have different personalities. (And it might want you to play the game twice or more >:o)

The gameplay itself is extremely diverse... Able to captivate new-comers to the bullet hell genre to hardcore players thriving for the records in really unforgiving scales of difficulties. I'd let you find out what works best for you in there, there's literally a tons of things to beat if you're up for a challenge!

The controls? Simple and straightforward. I've only used a keyboard and it's the only thing you'd ever need playing this game (except when you prefer a controller :L). It might seem alienating at first, but trust me, you'd get fitted into it in no time. Even the devs anticipated this and made it so that boss encounters are events in which even the newest player of this genre can easily overcome thanks to their gradual difficulty increase.

Overall, this game is a great all rounder, considering the price (It lowers to being literally almost free during sales), this game is too much to pass on. Try it, I think you'll really like it if you want to try an entirely different game from what you're playing now!

35945796.review:
This review will probably not be long. Words simply cannot express how good this game is. It is a masterpiece that can be shown to people while teaching them how do one makes a video game. This game will still be good even after 20 years or more pass. It seems that CreSpirit, the developer, understands what a good game is, and not just that – they can also make one!

Rabi-Ribi is essentially a game, in which the player controls a character and explore areas, looking for items, hidden routes and fights with enemies. The game mixes these elements with a bullet hell shooter. It comes out they go with each other really well, although it takes some time to become used to it. The bullet hell elements are present pimarily with boss fights. Regular enemies also attack using bullet patterns, but these are not complex and high in number enough to qualify as bullet hell.

The difficulty lies in that bullet hells are normally shooters, in which you control a flying object and can move in all directions. In Rabi-Ribi, you control a character which moves left and right, and can jump off the ground. Learning how to avoid bullets with this limited movement takes some time. It is an ‘easy to learn, hard to master’ type of game.

The game engine pre-loads a lot of things, so the start-up is slow, but there no loadings later whatoever. If you fail, which you will a lot, even on Casual difficulty, restart happens fast so that you may try again almost instantly. There is plenty of checkpoints and they are in places and times that you would want them to be in and at.

This game has a story, but it is not really significant. It can be completely ignored and the experience will still be as good. The story is actually a right kind of story for this time of game. The story is a mystery one, which invites and motivates the player to explore the island the story takes place on some more.

In such a game, as a player, you want there to be well-designed levels. This game have very good level design. It is really fun to explore the maps. At first, you don’t know about there being hidden passages, but the areas are structured so that you would eventually find them. The game guides the player with an invisible hand. You learn things in a way that you may not even notice that the game has told your about something. For example, the player finds a Carrot Bomb item. One of usages of a Carrot Bomb is that it can destory specific blocks of terrain and open up hidden passages. While playing the game, you learn which areas might be destroyable. You almost never look for things aimlessly without cues.

The game is filled with content and things to do, mainly communicated through the achievement system. It is split into what is referred to as the ‘main game,’ which is the first five chapters and the ‘post game,’ which is the remaining five. There are achievements for simply clearing the game. There are achievements for clearing the game in different difficulties. There are achievements for clearing the game in another mode. There is a speedrun mode. There is a boss rush mode, in which you fight all bosses in turn. There is an Artbook DLC, accessible through the game, which inludes some Beta Content which is playable. You can even try to finish the game without collecting any items or not touching any spikes and there are achievements for that, too. These are actual achievements which encourage players to try different ways and styles of play that the game offers.

The 0% items run is doable, because with the Standard Rule settings, the level of bosses is determined by what you have. In this mode, when one has 0% items, the last boss of the main game is at level 11, which is low. For comparision, in warawaras first playthough it was around 65. The game is also prepared for ‘breaking it’ by doing things out of order by using Hidden Tech moves and hidden passages you have learnt about. There is a harder New Game+, which starts another loop. If you did not obtain an item that increases jump or a weapon, the system adapts to this situation so that you can finish the game, for example, the height of a pillar of bullets changes in a boss fight. As a player, you will certainly spend a lot of time with this product as it is solid like a rock and polished like a diamond.

The game is presented with pixel art graphics. These are very good pixel art graphics. They use pastel colours that introduces to you to a world full of love. There is plenty of animation in the spirtes. They move, jump and do things that brings a smile to one’s face. It is co cute and charming you simply want it to play it some more.

The game is essentially a collection of connected rooms, which are viewed from the side, but – even with this presentation – when in a boss fight, there is actually some camera movement like close-ups! It happens so naturally that you may not even notice it happening.

The background music is simply perfect. It fits really well with all the places on the map and the fights. Actually, warawara bought this game through Steam primarily to get the OST, because the music by Tridust, 3R2 and few others is so great warawara had to own a copy of it. Warawara cannot find the words to describe how the experience of fighing a boss with ‘Get On With It’ or ‘The Truth Never Spoken’ (by 3R2) playing in the background feels like. The right music plays at the right times. Simply hearing some of the pieces and watching the trailer for the console version bought warawara instantly. It is simply amazing how well is goes along with the rest of the game. There are also touches like lowering and increasing the speed of music when you gain status effects that alter the player’s movement speed.

To sum it up, warawara highly recommends this game.

35878034.review:
Rabi-Ribi is a Bunny Exploration Bullet Hell Action game and the best (only?) of its kind.  It bears many gameplay similarities to Super Metroid, like the exploration aspect, and hidden abilities, upgrades, and items, so if that's your thing, you'll probably love this game.  Beyond the core gameplay though, Rabi-Ribi is quite different, and something very special and unique.  This game is all about cute girls, a beautiful world with colourful environments, lighthearted characters, and nice upbeat music.

The world in this game is so beautifully designed and makes you want to keep coming back to spend time in it.  The visuals are lovely and I really could not ask for more there.  The artists did a really good job with the visual presentation for the game.  The areas, artwork, and sprites are all really nice, and all the small details like the characters' facial expressions are really great and add so much to the game.  The characters in this game are an absolute joy to be around and they really make the game.  The interactions are cute and fun and it feels great meeting and getting to know each character.  I don't know what it is, but there's just something special about these characters that makes me really feel attached to them.  They really bring a smile to my face and I can really feel the love that GemaYue put into creating them, and the artists put into drawing them.

The soundtrack is really fantastic as well.  Everything works out really well and fits in with the spirit of the game.  Most of the music is quite cheerful and nice to listen to casually as well.  All of the composers did an amazing job and I'm really happy with the music in this game.  It was also really cool to see 3R2 on the team for the game music, since I've been a fan of his music for years and this was actually part of what got me interested in this game in the first place.

Also there's a ton of content and replay value with this game, with are 6 difficulties (excluding DLC), 5 main game modes, a speedrun mode, and multiple boss rush modes.  Overall this game is a must-play and I would recommend it to anyone who likes games (that means you!).  I came in expecting a pretty good action-platformer Metroid-style game and ended up with what is easily one of my favorite games of all time.  Definitely grab this game whenever you can.  It's wonderful.  I'd say it's easily worth paying full price even, and I'm a pretty cheap person, so there's not many games I say that about!

As a side note, since it isn't obvious from the title, I also want to mention the artbook DLC includes various beta version gameplay content (which is described in the artbook DLC page).  If you're just buying the main game now and thinking about DLC later, then it's something to keep in mind, and if you're on the fence on whether or not to get the full package, then I'd say just go for it.

35315735.review:
Great fun gem were you play as any true weeaboo's fantasy- A cute anime bunny girl accompanied by a scantily clad fairy. 

Now don't let the initial looks of this game deceive you, this game is DEFINITELY quite challenging and can be infuriating for those unable to; "gitgud". However the satisfaction of finally beating that one fucking boss that had those bullshit attack patterns that you had to burn into your skull in order to dodge them feels amazing and is a great pay off.

The controls are fluid which is expected for a game where you need to quickly adjust your positioning and be able to react accordingly to attacks that come at you fast or without much warning. The soundtrack is amazing, personally I feel like some of the soundtracks gave me that extra energy and hype levels to get through some stages. Animations and character designs are top notch, not much else to say there. Although there is supposed to be an order of events in the story, the game is completely non-linear which means you can fight all if not most of the bosses in whatever order you please, and if you consider yourself to be a top-tier player you can even choose to not grab any weapons or health upgrades at all and simply let your fairy friend do all the work throughout your entire playthrough.

Overall, a solid recommend to the base game. If you're looking for more content for the game the DLC is definitely worth grabbing for it's regular price.

35196361.review:
Revised on Feb 10, 2019.

[h1]Pros  [/h1]
Do you like rabbits? Fairies? Characters with animal ears? Cutesy art style? Lighthearted and a little bit silly story on the outside with darker themes on the inside? A variety of different personalities? 

If that didn't spark your interest then perhaps you are more interested in things like a great soundtrack, platforming and map exploration or bullet hell style boss battles? Those things I just listed are only a few reasons why I like this game. 

[h1]Cons [/h1]
I have some performance issues on my laptop. One especially bad room is [spoiler]Seana[/spoiler]'s boss battle room. Aside from that I can't really think of anything else negative about the game. 

[h1]Gameplay [/h1]
Rabi-Ribi is a bullet hell metroidvania that encourages exploring and doing things at your own pace. The game provides hints and suggestions what you can do but never truly forces you to follow them. There are only a few areas locked behind story progression and you can't wander around much in the prologue but aside from that everything is basically available for you from the get-go. For instance, the game warns you once when you try to go in deep water or dark areas 'too early' but it doesn't prevent you from going forward if you ignore the warning. 

[h1]Story summary [/h1]
You play as Erina, a bunny who got transformed into a human for unknown reason while keeping her bunny like features such as bunny ears. Soon you meet Ribbon, a small fairy who acts as your companion and ranged attack. Your main goal is to find Miru, Rumi's sister, who has gone missing. To do this you must find magic users to power up a stone monument called Stele. To recruit helpers you must first persuade them in a form of a battle and trust me, they all find various excuses to have battles with you. 

[h1]Difficulty [/h1]
The base game offers plenty of challenge for both beginners and experts by having six difficulty settings from Casual to Bunny Extinction. The Artbook DLC has a few more difficulty settings that you can try if you dare. At the beginning four difficulties from Casual to Hard are unlocked and higher ones must be unlocked by playing the game. 

I personally think normal is a good difficulty to start with. I don't consider myself being good at bullet hell kind of games (have never played Touhou) and I had heard this game had bullet hell elements so I didn't want to start on hard. On the other hand casual and novice sounded too easy so I went with normal. In return I got plenty of challenge and I felt like I had really improved while playing the game which eventually led me trying it on harder difficulties. If you feel like you've chosen the wrong difficulty to start with then there is an NPC early in the game who can change the difficulty of your game. 

Something to keep on mind is that bosses' levels scale with your progress so the more you do in the game the higher level they get. Their scaling depends on the mode you selected (standard / alternative). They also know what items you already have and use attacks that are possible for you to dodge. A very simple example of this is that in the beginning Erina can't jump very high so the bosses with attacks that you must jump over can't be higher than your maximum jump height. 

The game has consumables that can either heal you or hurt enemies and how many you can carry depends on the difficulty setting. A few items grants you invincibility frames for a short period of time making it possible to avoid taking damage that you'd be otherwise unable to avoid. 

[h1]Replay value [/h1]
I've done multiple playthroughs of the game on various difficulties from Casual to Bunny Extinction. Now you might ask does the game have other replay value than just harder difficulties. In my opinion yes, it has. 

First of all there is a New Game+ option that you can access within the game after you've cleared the post game. Loop 2 starts the game from the beginning but you keep all your items, your stats gets a boost and you even get more pack points for badges. Enemies are also more dangerous. After clearing Loop 2 you can go for Loop 3. You can keep looping as much as you want.  

Secondly you can unlock the speedrun mode. In speedrun mode it cuts cutscenes and story stuff, shows you playtime, map exploration and collected items %. There are also a few achievements related to speedrunning the game. 

Many of the Steam achievements also encourage you to play the game multiple times and some of them are quite interesting. How about trying to find one of the bosses before others or get one of the items while completely avoiding one of the bosses? Or finding a lot of helpers in chapter 1? Or completely forgetting about Ribbon's friends? What if you never picked up the hammer? 

There are also various types of boss rushes available if you are into that kind of thing. It uses characters, items and buffs from the save file you choose. Can you say you've truly mastered the game before doing the True Boss Rush on the hardest difficulty? 

One of the more interesting (but also somewhat tedious) playthroughs I've done has been 0% items playthrough which allows only the bunny amulet, consumables and rainbow eggs. Without the hammer and mobility items all you can really do is jump three tiles high and leave everything else to your trusted fairy companion. Lack of items makes it harder to go through areas for a game that is partly a platformer and it also makes you easy target to enemies. Going through areas requires using two of the hidden techs a lot.

[h1]DLC[/h1]
I won't go into details but I personally like every Rabi-Ribi DLC. The soundtrack is really good. The Artbook even adds some playable content. Cicini's Halloween adds a new area and a boss battle (+ its free). Is the order a DLC? extends the story, adds two quite large map areas and three boss battles. Before Next Adventure adds new costumes, CGs, new SP bosses and new achievements. 

[h1]Other things I'd like to point out [/h1] 
Some players might wonder if the game has a lot of fanservice. I'd say it has and it doesn't have. It depends on where you put the line. Ribbon, a small fairy, doesn't wear much clothing in her default outfit. Some CGs are somewhat fanservicy but overall the tone of the game and CGs is safe. 

Aside from clothing and a CGs there is some dialogue that can be slightly suggestive later in the game. Considering how you can skip cutscenes and story sections with a button and the real selling point of the game is actually solid good platforming with bullet hell bosses rather than fanservice in any form, I'd say anyone who wants to play this game purely for the gameplay but is concerned about fanservice should still give it a try. 

[h1]TLDR [/h1]
In my opinion it's a great bullet hell metroidvania with a lot of content, good DLCs and worth the price.

Extremely well balanced, and actively encourages sequence-breaking and exploration. If the difficulty becomes too much or a certain enemy/boss is really giving you trouble, you can choose to either try over and over until you win, or you can leave and go search the world for more permanent stat boosts (more health, attack, stamina etc.), purchase upgrades at the shop, grind levels (which offers more rewards than just experience), or even search for new abilities that may very well decide whether you win or lose a fight, plus many other options. A masterpiece worthy of your time, money, and support.

35017189.review:
An essential addition for anyone who enjoys 2D action games and gets a thrill from persevering against insanely difficult bosses for hours on end, Rabi-Ribi is at its best when it's testing you to dodge a swarm of bullets (with gravity, no less) in its over 30 boss fights, but is also an enjoyable platforming and exploration game that offers tons of replayablity due to its extremely non-linear design.

First thing's first: This game is fanservice-y, but that's not the focus of the game. It's aware enough of this to lampshade Ribbon's skimpy outfit at times. Don't be turned off by the Steam store page description about a bunny-girl costume, because I would not have sunk 200 hours into this game if I just wanted to look at ecchi. You'll see some humorous dialogue teasing at yuri themes as well, but overall, the story of the game is an actual story about Erina, Rabi-Rabi Island, and some of its inhabitants, though it doesn't truly begin to unfold until halfway through the game. The initial premise is that Erina, formerly a pet rabbit of Rumi but turned human by unknown means, is tasked with trying to track down Rumi's sister Miru, who has been magicked away by a stone tablet, and Erina needs the help of other magic-users on the island to power this tablet and follow Miru. But there's a much more interesting story that you'll uncover about the island's origins and a figure from its past as you progress--though it remains bunny-themed to the end.

Progression in Rabi-Ribi is similar to other Metroidvania games in that you start with just a basic jumping ability and go on to acquire myriad upgrades to your attacks, mobility, and statistics hidden throughout the world. In the prologue, you are railroaded towards the town at the island's center, but afterwards you are free to explore almost the entirety of the fairly large overworld, with just a few areas locked behind certain events. Two big twists that delighted me as I played this game: one, every single item, even Erina's primary attack, is optional, if you look hard enough for alternate routes and can wrap your head around the island's layout; two, while the game explicitly guides you (with waypoints and objectives, even) towards a smoothly curved difficulty progression that will help you pick up important items early, you are free to utterly ignore this and go virtually anywhere in any order. One achievement, for example, requires you to traverse the entire world "backwards" from the start to avoid meeting a boss just outside of town for most of the game.

In addition to simple stat ups and new movement and attack abilities, you will find badges tied to the game's nicely tuned badge system, allowing you to equip a limited point value of badges you've found to tweak your stats, gain immunity to various statuses, earn more currency, and the like. It's a fun system that allows you to heavily prioritize offense or defense, as several badges trade one for the other.

The major attraction in Rabi-Ribi is the boss fights, however. After a few easy bosses in the opening sequence, the game quickly ramps up to a brutal difficulty; outside of the lowest difficulties (which are fairly easy as long as you pick up a few items), this is a game where you will not beat many, if any, bosses on the first attempt. Most fights are fairly short, about five minutes in length, but some late-game bosses can exceed ten or fifteen minutes. If you love the feeling of gradual improvement, learning how to deal with various patterns, progressing farther each time only to be faced with an even more brutal attack, then this game will be a great fit for you. If this is a turn-off, and you're only looking to coast through, it's still a decent game, but you won't get the same sort of value. Those who want to challenge themselves get the option of six difficulties, each of which scales up in difficulty nigh-endlessly with repeated loops of New Game+ (though the actual dodging mechanic starts to fall apart around four or five loops and it just turns into a battle of overpowered offenses). Challenge aside, each boss has their own unique theme (with the exception of two pairs of siblings who have variants of the other's attacks), and it's wonderfully illustrated in their attack patterns. Cocoa, the penniless inventor, fights using an assortment of automated bombs; Pandora, the ancient princess(?) waiting inside a tricky pyramid, can slow your movement and fights with several puzzle- and trap-like attacks; Ashuri feels like a classical Ordinary Magician and takes to her broomstick for several fly-by attacks.

On top of the story mode, Rabi-Ribi offers a speedrun mode which skips the intro segment and all cutscenes automatically and has a frame-accurate timer plus leaderboards for all difficulties, any%, 0%, and 100%, plus an absolutely brutal Boss Rush mode that places you against absurd odds (the "True Boss Rush" mode will easily take over 90 minutes to finish, for perspective).

The game does have a history of technical issues on some PCs due to its requirement of running at 60 FPS (and no more). However, a late 2017 patch seems to have addressed this.

Rabi-Ribi was easily my favorite game of 2016, and continues to occupy me periodically nearing the end of 2017. There is simply so much to do here, especially if you follow the achievement list for ideas for your next challenge, that you are pretty much certain to get insane value from the purchase if the genre is at all to your liking. Please, don't pass on this hidden gem just because the outfits or bunny-girl theme turn you off.

34922529.review:
Many will look at this game and be ready to dismiss it because it looks like a fanservice laden h-game. Those people are fools.

For one, despite some ecchi-ish CG art, nothing's flat out NC-18 (No nudity, certainly no lewd acts), this ends up being one of the most solid Metroidvania titles in a long time. Why? It embraces the non-linearity that makes a good Metroidvania. This is a Metroidvania where you can literally go "Y'know what? I don't WANT my primary weapon. I'm gonna run the game without it." And you can challenge the game with just Ribbon (Your 'gun' of sorts). Sequence breaking isn't actively blocked, in fact it's outright encouraged. Some achievements even *REQUIRE* you to sequence break, playing the game out of the "intended" order of progression. This right here is what makes me love this game so much. A lot of Metroidvanias will try to prevent you from breaking sequences or doing things out of order. You might be able to get one or two items out of order now and then, but nothing hugely game breaking. This on the other hand, is a game that *wants* you to break it. And for the skilled player, it will reward you for doing so.

Oh right, some people may not know what a Metroidvania is. I should clarify that. It's a game where you basically explore a large, interconnected world. More of it becomes available to explore as you find upgrades to traverse more of it.  There's a lot of platforming, as well as fighting. And both are fun as heck here.

On top of this you have a fun bullet-hell esque form of boss fighting that keeps things quite intense, but due to the upgrade nature of the game, you can always snag more health and attack power to get the advantage in a tougher boss fight whose patterns you haven't quite nailed yet.

This is a Metroidvania that gets so much right where other games in the genre get it wrong. Virtually the entire world map is accessible to you from the getgo if you know how to bypass certain obstacles with Erina's hidden techs. If you were the type of person who loved being able to go out of order in Super Metroid via walljumps and Machballs, you are going to love the way this game encourages more of the same.

34180954.review: This is honestly better than any other metroidvania I've played on Steam. Hallow Knight, Axiom Verge, Shadow Complex... all great games, but they all felt like they're missing something, whether it's better controls or perhaps being a bit too derivitave of what's already out there. Rabi-Ribi's graphics can be an eyesore at times (some sprites literally ripped from Touhou, on top of mixing several artstyles), but it's super long, super challenging, and super fun, doesn't hold your hand other than teaching you certain mechanics. For a shitty looking indie game that appears to appeal to horny weeaboos, the amount of content this game offers is staggering and never seems to end. I both love and hate the bosses, as they continuously provide new challenge after challenge after challenge, but tend to be on the long side. The story is completely forgettable moe garbage, but all the cutscenes are skippable. The game starts out slow but after the first hour it completely opens up allowing you to explore the entire game at whatever pace you like starting from Chapter 2. If you're still on the fence... just buy it. There's a lot worse things that can fuck up a game than shitty moe graphics.

33904903.review:
[h1]Rabi-Ribi is a Single-Player, Platforming, Bullet-Hell, Metroid-Style kind of game.[/h1]

In other reviews, and I would agree with as well -- it is like as if Touhou and Metroid were mixed together, making a cute but difficult bullet hell Metroid game.

Other than it being silly at times, it has adorable graphics and tense boss fights. It can be strange buying or playing a game with a bunny-girl on it, but it's rather worth it once you get past that phase. The gameplay was very enjoyable and challenging. Playing it on keyboard was strange, so it is recommended to have a controller if you have one -- but can be played without.

I would say there's about 15~30 hours of gameplay time in one play-through, if we're including the post-game content and all the exploration that is involved.
There is some replay value merit from it; Speed-running if that's up your alley, or doing some of the challenge achievements.

---

In terms of gameplay, it is played as a platformer, with secrets and [i]Easter Eggs[/i] to find. You explore the world (in any way you want), some areas are inaccessible until mobility items are found. You can attack using the Pico Hammer you'll find, or using your magical fairy friend, Ribbon (and eventually more variety of magics that she can use).

In the boss fights that you'll encounter to progress the story, each of the bosses have their own unique patterns and gimmicks that you have to dodge through and find the spots they're vulnerable in -- beat them senseless with your Hammer and magical Ribbon!

In terms of difficulty, there are four initial difficulty settings [i](Casual, Novice, Normal, Hard)[/i], with two unlockable harder difficulties. What these difficulties usually do is change the amount of bullet-density, damage dealt, and patterns used by the bosses. There is also another scaling difficulty, based on how many bosses you have defeated and/or items found. This setting can be found during the initial part of a save file creation.
If the difficulty is too spicy (or isn't spicy enough), There is a chance in the first chapter to alter the difficulty.

Graphics are very cute pixel art sprites during gameplay, but there is some nice CG art during the cutscenes! 
Music is wonderful and fitting to the current scene as well.

---


It also has very cute girls and a wonderful heroic bunny. [b][i]Very Important.[/i][/b]

33871429.review:
Fantastic bullet hell game with obvious roots in Metroidvania. If you enjoy finding wall chicken-esque type of treasure and using your brain/thinking outside of the box to find secrets and progress, then this is the game for you!

The game is as easy or as hard as you'd for it to be; personally, I played on Hard on my first run and have not used a single healing item so far or look up anything on the game. The little treasures are well and cleverly hidden, and a discerning eye and good understanding of mechanics will get you quite far! There's a really good balance between relying on mechanical skill during boss fights and your exploration skills when it comes to progression; if you're lacking in one area, being stronger in the other is more than enough to carry you until your proficency improves!

Fantastic game that was recommended to me by a friend, and I have no regrets whatsoever!

33774124.review:
Rabi Rabi does itself no favours. Going by the art and reviews you’d assume that it was one of the seemingly endless not quite pornographic visual novels being inserted every which way into steam. Look, there’s a bunny girl and a fairy with no clothes! 10/10 would disappoint family again. Guffaw. It’s worth enduring the beady eyed judgemental stares of your awful friends though, as Rabi Rabi is actually one of the best Metroidvanias on steam.

While it’s not as beautiful as something like Ori, Rabi Rabi has very slick presentation with excellent spritework, animation and music, even if the art itself might be more divisive. Rabi Rabi’s big selling point is its non-linearity – this is probably the most open game of its type I’ve ever played, with an expectation that you will explore as signposting is deliberately vague. Like most metroidvanias mobility options increase the speed at which you can traverse and backtrack and encourage doing so with an enormous number of hidden pickups, and the game opens up very organically. Rabi Rabi is absolutely massive as well – even a normal runthrough will take 10-12 hours, and a 100% run could easily double that.

Your basic goal is to recruit characters (in largely any order), a certain number of which will allow you to move onto the next story event. You recruit characters, naturally, by beating them up. There’s a lot of boss fights in this game, and even on normal difficulty they’re no slouch, especially early on. This is where the other selling point of Rabi Rabi comes up - it’s also a bullet hell game, with every boss vomiting forth endless patterns of glowing blobs. Even with your tiny hitbox it will test your platforming and fighting skills – there’s no shame in starting on novice if you’re not a veteran of these genres, whatever the internet might say.

The boss fights end up being both some of the best and worst aspects of Rabi Rabi – at their best they’re tense and challenging, at their worst they’re tiresome slogs through seemingly endless HP bars where you inevitably end up dying five minutes in to a ridiculous super attack right at the end of the fight. The open nature of the game means that there’s always a chance you’ll bite off more than you can chew, though the difficulty of the preceding area gives a pretty good indication of whether or not the boss will thoroughly bum you.

In spite of these flaws Rabi Rabi represents the very best of a crowded genre on steam( alongside Axiom Verge) – it would be a shame if prospective players were put off by the theme, if only because Rabi Rabi could be the gateway to the world of waifus they secretly crave.

33741879.review:
I went into this game skeptical. It's usually my experience that bunny girls and sexy-lolita-pixies are a sign that someone's trying to distract from their deficiencies. That was not the case here.

Rabi-Ribi is an intense Metroidvania bullet-hell, and it handles both genres marvelously. The game has multiple difficulty options, each of which seems to be balanced meticulously. Read the descriptions of the difficulties because they're accurate, and if you find yourself going in blind on Hard mode you ARE going to see the Game Over screen more than once per boss fight on average. There are a [b]LOT[/b] of boss fights.

Normally with a Metroidvania, boss fights at some difficulty start to feel like stat checks. "Did I go find the ____ beam?" "Oh, guess I don't have the ____ armor yet." "I probably need better bombs." And some of those moments do happen here, but more often the conversation you have with yourself goes "OH! So I need to dodge over her and attack her from behind because that attack only hits to the right" or "Damn! I really need to get better at using my invulnerability frames."

It's intense, it's rewarding, and it's going to leave you wanting more. So long as you don't have someone else in the house who you have to justify the groped bunny-woman to, this game is absolutely best-in-class.

33339388.review:
You play as Erina, a bunny who wakes up a human (the "Rabi"). Her partner-in-crime is a fairy named Ribbon (the "Ribi") who shoots magic. Together they combine to form Rabi-Ribi, and set out on a quest to find a bunch of people, none of whom are wearing pants. [i]"This is not some H-game!"[/i]

The overworld is metroidvania, the boss battles are bullet hells, the music is pretty good, the gameplay is very nicely polished, packaged in a whimsical anime skin.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ Excellent gameplay. Knocked it out of the park here. This is just one line here, but so hugely important to this game, that any detractor seems like a nitpick.
+ Lots of stuff to do. Lots of bosses, lots of settings, tons of collectibles for the 100% nutters, speedrun timers for the speedrunners, 0% item mode run for the people who think the ground is too soft, casual mode for the babbies, and several harder difficulty modes for the people who wish more of their bones were broken. Erina has a hammer for melee attacks, and Ribbon has ranged attacks, and there's an achievement for playing through the game without picking up the hammer at the start. 
+ Challenging, especially if you want it to be. Are you a bad enough dude to get the "complete all bosses in MAX rank mode" and "complete all bosses without taking any damage" achievements? Get ready to work for them and git gud or die trying.
+ Not linear, do things in whatever order you like. You can get a few achievements for non-standard sequences.
+ Has an atmosphere the polar opposite of Grimdark, Noblebright. There's the smell of a lazy vacation day, where the worst conflicts are just misunderstandings, suffering is a temporary step before a lesson is learned, and everyone is generally content. All the elements of the game combine to a kind of pleasant and carefree feeling. 
+ Music is good. Most of it is forgettable, but there's a few catchy tunes, and the music sets the mood well, which is what it needs to do.

[h1]YMMV:[/h1]
? Art is very anime. I feel like I shouldn't need to point this out since it's so obvious, but if this is a dealbraker for you, why did you get this far in considering if you're going to buy this? While I'm talking about it, there's nothing more sexualized here than what you can see in the trailer.
? Writing is also very anime. I can appreciate that this game really rolls with the whole "most characters are incapable of understanding innuendo" thing because on some level it's innocent and endearing, but I can also see it becoming grating. 
? Characters. A well-executed combination of the above two points, if you like them or not will be up to your tolerance for anime tropes.
? The island is experiencing a drastic shortage of pants.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- The story. The characters really drive the story along, but there's nothing outstanding to see here. Each boss battle is framed with some dialogue, but most of the reasons for fighting are contrived, and the game knows it. This kind of goes back to the whole Noblebright thing. There's generally the impression that anything bad is just temporary and things will just work out eventually, so there doesn't really feel like there's too much at stake. Ribbon and Erina really care about the main story line, but the way the world is framed makes me think it would have all worked out on its own.

[h1]Verdict:[/h1]
A very solid, thorough, and challenging game in its genres. [b]Recommended[/b]. Basically the only reason not to get this is if you are allergic to anime, have no interest in platforming gameplay, or are playing video games for their deep and compelling stories instead of reading a book.

33306482.review:
GLANCE RECOMMENDATION: [u][b]84% YES[/b][/u] / 16% NO

[h1]GOOD[/h1]
[list]
[*]Cute character designs.
[*]Fun, colorful environments. You'll grow to love a select few as you run around discovering secrets.
[*]Hands down the best things are the comics. Give those a read from the main menu, they're rather funny.
[*]A surprisingly in depth combat system that really tows the line between bullet hell and "I give up". Lots of attacks to string together and variants with the ranged attacks.
[*]There's an absurd amount of things to collect and explore. In some cases you can break the sequence of chapters with clever movement, which is an actual achievement.
[*]There's an adaptive difficulty that is VERY real. You'll die to a boss wondering if you're supposed to be there, but yes this is a (for the most part) tackle bosses as you come across them to unlock more main story. Thankfully if you take too long fighting a boss & die or just die repeatedly to a boss, you'll get the option for angelic buffs which I'm guessing help but I was never sure what it did. It can definitely get frustrating dealing with the bullet hell landscape, but practice patientce and you should find more openings in your next attempts.
[*]The. Item. Shop. Music. Son.
[/list]

[h1]NEUTRAL[/h1]
[list]
[*]Story and dialogue are... odd and rather forgettable. I found myself skipping the dialogue towards the back end and not really caring about the continuation of the story. Almost every single fight just feels shoe horned as the boss needs a reason to fight you.
[/list]

[h1]SUMMARY[/h1]
There's a reason so many people give this a high rating. It's got a lot to do, fun characters, some nice sound tracks, a killer selection of comics in the steam artwork, and deep combat for those looking for it. I'm not particularly a fan of the gameplay, but I appreciated all my options and how it handled the difficulty curve in general.

33145458.review:
I am genuinely happy that i can finally mark this review as positive. The game has made a breakthrough and got a bit of a charm it used to have when i first played this game.


[h1]1: The Game[/h1]
[b]1.1: General[/b]
As for Rabi-Ribi itelf, i love the game's core mechanics. It really was an amazing idea to put Erina in the game. Whatever other people say, i love the lore and story. It wasn't too complicated like the rest and anything that did confuse me a little, got fully explained when i replayed the game on a harder difficulty.  Speaking of difficulty, the game's difficulties actually are different from each other. So thank you for that.

[b]1.2: FPS[/b]
For me, the game is running better. There are two ways to play Rabi-Ribi:
1. Die alot and retry alot.
2. Do not die alot by a running slow pc. This consumes alot more time though.
I am using a low-end pc, but the game runs at 60 fps. I used to not like this, but i have definitely improved in concentration and gameplay strategy to be able to easily go with the flow the game offers during the boss battles.

[b]1.2: DLC's[/b]
[b]1.2.1: DLC 3 [/b]
For the DLC's, i think they all have a strong grip on the game, in a way that it is slightly different than the time you played it without, but still lay heavily close to the original game. Months and months after me quitting Rabi-Ribi, i thought the  third, fourth and fifth DLC would heavily differ. The original game was full of story, amazing music and definetely the most important: the atmosphere. Cicini's Halloween was a twist that would make it easier for the fourth and fifth DLC to be accepted. Cicini's Halloween made the Graveyard alot more interesting. Cheers for that! It was just a bit sad that it was mostly based on skill-based platforming than exploring.

[b]1.2.2: DLC 4 [/b]

The "Order a DLC" DLC is a bit weird. It both does amazing work but ruins some parts. The added story was incredible. Absolutely incredible. It makes a fun happy ending for Noah, which was missing in my book for a long time. The added areas were pretty alright, with an exception of the Lilli & Pixie boss battle area, which was outrageously good. It gave the nostalgia the game used to give me back in 2016. Thank you for that! The Boss Battles were super fun and i am willing to re-do them all over again.

The parkouring in this one was a bit bad, if i may say so. The speedy run you had to do from the top of the ravine down to the Stele was infuriating to do, as not only it forced you down a super specific path (while the game itself is heavily based on it's Open World mechanic), but it also, after finishing this event, blocks you off from the Ravine. In the newly added Hall Of Memories, the fourway passage i had to go down was a painful experience on my mind, but i secretly also like the concept that it requires thinking work. The boss fight in the end brought my opinion fully back up. Again, thanks for the happy ending!

[b]1.2.3: DLC 1 & 2[/b]
I chose to cover DLC 3 & 4 first, because those were easy to remember. The OST was amazing, i truely enjoyed that aspect. The music in Order A DLC and Cicini's Halloween were close to the original game, so thanks for the art you made! The artbook was also to my likings. The warm welcome of the opening menu to the extra content that there is to see is worth the time.

[b]1.2.4: DLC 5[/b]

Before Next Adventure is pretty straightforward. As much as i see, the CG's are pretty nice. It does remove a slight bit of the nostalgia. It advantages and disadvantages are equal, which makes it actually really good!

[h1]2: Community[/h1]
Oh boy, here's the part that takes the game down for me. For Rabi-Ribi, the game isn't toooooo popular, and so it relies on two "unions": RabiDB and the Speedrun Community.

[b]2.1: RabiDB[/b]
Before i go deeper in this, thank you AlexSSZ for the time i was allowed to moderate the place. I certainly wasn't the best at it, but it trained me for other Moderator jobs. RabiDB was the place i spend my time on. I became Moderator in July, 2017.

One thing i especially noticed, is that salt is also included in this game. The community was REALLY sensitive for mistakes. I had to go for my own sake  and my bad job with mistakes. I know loose cannons are bad at it, but they won't go easy on you.

[b]2.2: Speedrun Community[/b]
I. Hate. Speedrunning. Speedrunning ruins 70% what the game is meant for; 50% Atmosphere and 20% Enjoyment. GemaYue actually supports this. The game is very very slowly changing. You'll see, trust me. Since i never joined the speedrun community, i know less about it. But i am certain that i do not want to enter that place.

[b]2.3: Now[/b]
As of now, the community is now able to make workshop items, which i heavily despice.  I only got the Limited PC Packet and the LINE Stickers when merch would have been sold alot. If they would put the shirts back in store, i would continue buying merch again.



[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
So you might want to ask what my point is. The DLC's have pulled me back into the game after my break for a year in Begin 2018. I had so much fun when i bought it, and i still do up to this day. 

As for now, i am disappointed with the community of Rabi-Ribi. I fully neglect it to get the negative influence of them out of my brain. This way, the game will never lose the charm it has always had.

Pro: Innovative metroidvania with bullet hell Touhou-style boss fights. Great chiptune music and expressive sprite work, intrictate and very challenging boss fights. Self aware humor that's subtle enough to be actually funny instead of in-your-face-meta parody such games usually devolve into.

32833331.review:
On first impression I initially thought less of Rabi-Ribi, primarily due to the sexual content present in the trailer.

Yet when I actually caved in and bought the game, I discovered that the hype was real. This is by far one of the best metroidvania titles I've ever played. The combat system is decent, the world feels huge and the characters are surprisingly well-written - even if the story often goes crazy at times.

Boss battles are also really tough, especially if you decide to slide the difficulty up. When the developers described their game as 'bullet hell', they were not kidding. There are times when your screen will fill with loads of projectiles which you have to dodge. Thankfully, Erina has a surprisingly small hitbox for her size, so it is possible to dodge.

There is a surprising amount of hand-holding at the start and there are some places that are pretty much inaccessible until after you've beaten the game. Other than tthat, you are often given the freedom to explore.

Be warned, however. If you don't like fanservice in anime or manga, this game is filled with it.

32509289.review:
This game, man. This game is just absolutely fantastic. If you like metroidvania-type games and bullet hells, you will most likely love this game. It's by far [i]the best action-platformer that I've ever played[/i], and that's not just in gameplay. Ignoring the story itself (which is probably mediocre at best, but charming nonetheless), there are so many ways that you can play and explore this colorful world. Want to complete the entire game without collecting any item whatsoever? You can do that. Want to break the order of which the story progresses? Well, you can do that too.

Rabi-Ribi is the very definition of non-linear. You can do what you want, when you want, and in any order that you want. There's a plethora of hidden passageways and secrets. Some of these things also only appear depending on how you're currently playing. For example: if you are going through the game without collecting items, there is a part where you normally would not be able to progress without some specific items (e.g. double jump), but upon reaching this area on a 0% item run, a spring will appear and you'll be able to move forward. And to be crystal clear, this spring will not appear if you have collected any item at all (except rainbow eggs and three other things that are forced onto you), so you wouldn't be able to abuse this. In that aspect, it's appearent that the developers really put a lot of thought into the game's structure, and I think that that should be respected because, nowadays, you just don't see things like this in games.

The game has eight (six + two DLC) different difficulty levels. Hard and above are there to provide a challenge to those that want it, but those that don't can opt to play on an easier difficulty that is closer to their own skill level.

Casual
Novice
Normal
Hard
Hell (Unlocked after clearing Hard)
Bunny Extinction (Unlocked after clearing Hell)
Unknown (DLC)
Impossible (DLC)

Now, going back to the word 'colorful': Rabi-Ribi is beautiful for a pixelated world. It's very eye-catching and relaxing to look at. Not to mention that the soundtrack is quite fitting for the overall atmosphere of the game. But although the soundtrack is nice, I don't think that it's anything mindblowing and I can see it being repetitive for some people after a while. There could stand to be more tracks for boss fights, as well, because as of right now it's very limited. But that's just a minor complaint for me, as after the 80 hours that I've played so far, I am still enjoying it.

Actually, I think that words cannot accurately express how much I am enjoying this game as a whole. I'm not even good enough at it to do things like True Boss Rush on Hell difficulty or above. In fact, I had some trouble just completing the game on Hard (though, to be fair, I didn't use buffs or consumables). But that doesn't, and never did, take away from the fun that I am having with the game. There are plenty of other things for me to do, and if I ever feel like hating myself, I can just practice until I'm good enough to complete Impossible mode.

Also, to be honest, I feel like the $17.99 price tag is pretty low (I'd gladly pay at least $40) for how many hours one can get out of it. The game itself is not that long and can be beaten in just a few hours or less (if you know what you're doing), but its replay value is off the charts. I mean, just check out those achievements. And although it's not terribly long, the first playthrough for most people, on average, will probably take 15-20 hours. Personally, it took me between 40-50 hours for my first playthrough because I played on Hard and went around collecting all items without using a guide.

... Anyway. TLDR; Rabi-Ribi provides a challenge for players of all skill levels in a way that almost no other game does, and that's letting you, the player, go at your own discretion. It's also pretty spectacular, and if you love the metroidvania/bullet hell genres, you owe it to yourself to buy this game. Don't even think about it--just do it. I can guarantee that you won't regret it.

(Also, the art is very cute and has some ecchi bits to it. If you're not into that, please don't let it turn you off of buying the game. You'll be missing out, greatly.)

31667643.review:
I absolutely love this game.

It's been a while since I've actually enjoyed a decent platformer with a great story and this game personally takes the cake for being an excellent adventure game. The story itself is great and the characters are adorable and loveable. There is so much to interact with and explore. The artwork of the game itself is colorful and attractive. 

The game mechanics and difficulty are top notch. The game allows the players to cater the level of difficulty towards their preference. This goes beyond the standard "easy", "normal", and "hard" difficulties. If things get too hard, the game offers aid which helps the player may accept or decline. This helps the player not feel frustrated or stuck (especially on boss levels).
Being a bullet hell game, true skill comes from mastering the art of movements. Since Rabi-Ribi also has platformer mechanics, not only do you have to deal with gravity and an onslaught of projectiles, you also have to deal with the enemy you're fighting and successfully chain attacks to defeat them. This definitely ups the learning curve but is super rewarding when mastered.
This game definitely provides a challenge when set right.

The soundtrack of the game is very well done and I highly recommend getting the UPRPRC edition which comes with the game OST in FLAC. With the UPRPRC, you can also enjoy the digital artbook. 
Overall, this game holds a special place in my heart and I highly recommend this game.

Combine a metroidvania with bullet hell, along with amazing art and soundtrack. A lot of detail has been put into the game, which can get surreal at times (in a good way!). Some mild fan service of course. Story is pretty generic, but it's there, and not without its charm.

The thing I'll have to praise the most is combat mechanisms and character control. It's pretty rare for a 2D game to have such fast and responsive controls, and it works extremely well with bullet hell fights. Also, you don't control only one character but two! It's possible to use their powers simultaneously, adding to the overall intensity and skill cap. This works well with the fact this game is HARD, and the only way to finish some boss fights with max score is by actually studying the enemy and practicing.

Overall even when not progressing with the story, it's really fun to just explore around and hit mobs.

30947293.review:
This review comes after a Hard Playthrough on Alternative Rule.

Rabi Ribi is a Metroidvania style 2d platform game with a focus on Bullet Hell.  You play as Erina, a rabbit turned human, with her friend Ribbon the fairy, on a journey to discover why Erina became a human.

The gameplay is incredibly fluid. Most of the bullet hell sections are found in the form of Boss Battles, of which there are tons. The premise of a boss fight is to usually learn their patterns and get better at them over multiple tries, although some will be easily conquerable in one attempt. Erina's hitbox is quite forgiving, but you'll still find yourself being hit over and over if you can't react fast enough. Bullet Hell is a very particular type of genre, one not everyone enjoys, but Rabi Ribi tries its best to be appealing to everyone by offering multiple game difficulties from the get go, from masochistic (for people like me), to, 'I'm just here for the 'story''.

Combat itself is simple, you have your main attack, the hammer, which you use for the bulk of close combat damage andRibbon attacks using spells which are very useful for long range combat and keeping up a combo, Erina controls very tightly and very rarely will you take damage out of fault other than your own. There are a multitude of powerups that affect combat, and each makes combat more interesting and fun.

The game, as a 2D platformer, of course offers ton to explore and discover. You can completely bypass some powerups in your first playthrough, and there are tons of upgrades hidden across the map, some in plain sight, others very well hidden. The game also offers multiple ways to play, such as speedruns, boss rushes, and 0% item runs.

Rabi Ribi's main flaw is its story. Its very simple and, while that's not inherently a downside by itself, you won't find any grand tale in this game. It usually just comes down to 'we need helpers, go find some' do a plot point 'we need more helpers'. There are some good moments here and there, and an anime fan would definitely enjoy the entire thing, but its definitely not my cup of tea.

As many others have said before me, do not judge this game before you have played it. The game looks like a girly anime game that should be written off before even being played, but if you're a fan of Metroidvania games like Shantae or Dust, or a fan of Bullet Hell games such as Touhou or Nuclear Throne, you'll find yourself enjoying Rabi Ribi a great bunch.
